First, you will learn the definition of these terms and figure out the key differences between the two concepts. Then you will move to more complicated topics, such as architectural design principles and methods of coupling. Also, the following lesson provides information on cohesion in computer programming.</p> <p></p> <style><!-- .base\_image\_container { width: 100% !important; height: 100% !important; } .base\_image\_container img\[alt="Drop target image"\] { width: 100% !important; } --></style> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@f4f346d17d6e4bc9bf1d603a486ec31f"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@f4f346d17d6e4bc9bf1d603a486ec31f" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Architectural Styles and Patterns: Definitions</h3> <p>Despite the name similarity, styles and patterns in software architecture aim to resolve completely different tasks. First, let&rsquo;s clarify what an architectural style is and how this concept is related to architectural patterns.</p> <p><em>Click on the flip cards to learn more about the difference between architectural styles and patterns. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/6ee05acb34b43f807af0bd622538adc9/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.\_L1\_101.svg" alt="Architecture\_styles" width="200" /> <p><strong>Architectural Styles</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Architectural styles tell you, in broad strokes, how to organize your code. It&rsquo;s the highest level of granularity. It specifies layers, high-level modules of the application, and how those modules and layers interact with each other as well as the relations between them (e.g., Layered, Client-Server, Monolithic, etc.).</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/25a1141a478a759f7b3b4ccfedc946e3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.\_L1\_102.svg" alt="Architecture\_pattern" width="200" /> <p><strong>Architectural Patterns</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>A pattern is a recurring solution to a recurring problem. In the case of architectural patterns, they solve the architectural style problems (e.g., Three-tier, Microkernel, Model-View-Controller, Model-View-ViewModel, etc.).</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- p.dm2-cardsWrap-about.dm2-cardsWrap-about { margin-bottom: 5px; As usual, it all depends on the usage context. But there is another point of view on architectural styles and patterns, which allows them to be defined from a different perspective. Below you will find information from another angle.</p> <p><em>Click on the tabs to learn more. </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">Architectural Style</button><button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Architectural Pattern</button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <p>An <b>architectural</b> style can be defined as a specialization of element and relation types together with a set of constraints on how they can be used.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/8da75c2d7829d654bae43d1f71d20d2a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Problem\_2.svg" style="width: 650px; padding-top: 25px;" alt="image" /></p> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <p>An <b>architectural pattern</b> expresses a fundamental structural organization schema for software systems, provides a set of predefined subsystems, specifies their responsibilities, and includes rules for organizing the relationships between them.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/269ac9b24a1bb3008532650bde10b9fb/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Problem1.svg" style="width: 690px;" alt="image" /></p> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.tab-wrapper-about.tab-wrapper-about-2 { margin-bottom: 5px; There are the five principles to follow when designing a solution: Single Responsibility Principle or Bounded context; Principle of Least Knowledge, Coupling, Cohesion, Stateful/Stateless. Let&rsquo;s take a closer look and pay attention to each of them, starting with the Single Responsibility Principle.</p> <p><em>Click on the video to learn more about the Single Responsibility Principle. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;<a href="/assets/courseware/v1/fcd01206da3ccf0876f640f62fcfa899/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Lesson\_1.\_ASP\_SM5\_Common\_Principles.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a> to download a text script to find out what you will learn. </em></p> <div style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.25%;"><iframe src="//videoportal.epam.com/video/iframe.html?video=na2L3wRY&amp;resolution=1920x1080#" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; top: 0; left: 0;" frameborder="0"></iframe></div> <p></p> <p><em>Refer to the&nbsp;<a href="https://msdp.elearn.epam.com/courses/course-v1:MSDP+EngX360\_2020+2021/course/" target="\_blank">EngX360 Clean Design Submodule</a>to learn more about the Single Responsibility Principle.</em></p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-4" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@d2dbae6e1ffc47aa9ac930aef7e3813c"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@d2dbae6e1ffc47aa9ac930aef7e3813c" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Principle of Least Knowledge</h3> <p>The Principle of Least Knowledge (also known as the Law of Demeter) states that any component or object should not have knowledge about the internal details of other components. This approach avoids interdependency and helps maintainability. Suppose one component knows the other component and program&rsquo;s internals by assuming some of its typical implementations. After some time, the other component gets a makeover and changes the internal implementation. Now the assumptions considered by the other component fail, and so the other component will also fail.</p> <p>It would be best if you always stuck to the public interfaces and did not work on other system components&rsquo; internal knowledge.</p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-5" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@b28ab646a1894890956c0bc431a076c4"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-problem xmodule\_display xmodule\_CapaModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="True" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="problem" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@b28ab646a1894890956c0bc431a076c4" data-type="Problem" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "Problem"} </script> <div id="problem\_b28ab646a1894890956c0bc431a076c4" class="problems-wrapper" role="group" aria-labelledby="b28ab646a1894890956c0bc431a076c4-problem-title" data-problem-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@b28ab646a1894890956c0bc431a076c4" data-url="/courses/course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021/xblock/block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@b28ab646a1894890956c0bc431a076c4/handler/xmodule\_handler" data-problem-score="0" data-problem-total-possible="0" data-attempts-used="1" data-content=" &lt;h3 class=&#34;hd hd-3 problem-header&#34; A software unit may be of any granularity: methods in a class, classes, subsystems, packages, modules, services, systems, etc. A class with high (or strong) coupling relies on many other classes.</p> <p><em>Swipe to see examples of strong and loose coupling.</em></p> <div class="swipe-m-wrapper"> <div class="swipe-m-container"> <div class="swipe-m-inner" style="width: 100%; Cohesion measures the strength of the relationship between pieces of functionality within a given module. For example, in highly cohesive systems, functionality is strongly related. Cohesion is an ordinal type of measurement and is usually described as &ldquo;high cohesion&rdquo; or &ldquo;low cohesion.&rdquo;</p> <p style="font-style: italic;"><span style="vertical-align: inherit;"><span style="vertical-align: inherit;"><span>Click on the dots to learn more about high and low cohesion.</span> </span></span></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/a8514bf82ec1f848df8f2808e766953e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.\_L1\_104.svg" style="height: 150px; padding: 0 20px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>High Cohesion</h3> <p>High cohesion means all elements within a component are directed towards performing a single task. It is associated with several desirable software traits, including robustness, reliability, reusability, and understandability.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/88c8c465cff9b0894daefb16a535f521/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.\_L1\_105.svg" style="height: 150px; padding: 0 10px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Low Cohesion</h3> <p>Low cohesion is associated with undesirable traits such as difficulties in maintaining, testing, reusing, or even <br />understanding.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Cohesion is often contrasted with coupling. data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Stateful vs. Stateless</h3> <p>There are two polar types of design principles related to building services called Stateful and Stateless. In computer software, a state is the condition or quality of an entity at an instant in time. Let&rsquo;s view their key advantages and disadvantages.</p> <p><em>Click on the dropdowns to explore more.</em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>Stateful</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>Stateful service relies on the moments in time and changes the output given the determined inputs and state. In a stateful web service, the response formed from a simple GET request is entirely dependent on the state registered by the server. Without the knowledge of that state, the request cannot be appropriately returned. Stateful service requires a state shared through several requests.</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f5a1d43fca4acec3b48d335a380b6c27/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L1\_Dropdown\_1\_\_\_Stateful.svg" alt="Stateful" width="120px" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Advantages. </b>Less data to transfer since the state is maintained on the server and you don&rsquo;t need to resend this data every time.</p> <p><b>Disadvantages.</b> Synchronization of concurrent requests&mdash;state maintenance and synchronization bring additional complexity, which can also impact performance.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>Stateless</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>Stateless type is the polar opposite of stateful: any given response from the server is independent of any state. Every request contains all information to be processed.</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/aec73bffc6f2064768ebaaebf3837019/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L1\_Dropdown\_1\_\_\_Stateless.svg" alt="Stateless" width="145px" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Advantages.</b> Higher performance&mdash;the server doesn&rsquo;t spend any effort on state and synchronization management.</p> <p><b>Disadvantages. </b>More data to transfer to process a request&mdash;you don&rsquo;t keep the object&rsquo;s intermediate state on the server, so all information must always be passed from client to server and back.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.bint { margin-bottom: 10px !important; align-items: center;"> <div style="display: flex; align-items: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1d60a5f787977d3c9d4126ae9fa912e8/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.\_L1\_106.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 120px; max-width: 30%; margin-bottom: 10px;" /> <div style="padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Each component in the system should be assigned a specific responsibility. Features should not overlap one another, and the users should have a clear understanding of the steps he needs to take to get to a particular feature. It avoids the interdependency of system components and makes the system easy to maintain.</p> <p></p> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-mySlides { min-width: 350px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px; padding: 10px; text-align: center; } .dm-mySlides p { text-align: center; } body.view-in-course div.container .course-wrapper { display: table; } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-11" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@8e2011ceaf57467f871d5531174cc299"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@8e2011ceaf57467f871d5531174cc299" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Summary</h3> <p>In this lesson, you got acquainted with the architectural styles and patterns definitions from different perspectives and learned five main architectural design principles to follow while designing a solution. Additionally, you viewed other principles that should be considered by a solution architect. This knowledge is critical, as all of these principles aim to help overcome countless obstacles when designing software and working with a project team.</p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-12" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@b9309ac5ed194d23837348ce68eb3b92"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@b9309ac5ed194d23837348ce68eb3b92" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Quiz</h3> <p><em>These questions are designed to check your understanding of the key concepts of the lesson. You will look through the general overview of each of them as well as learn their advantages and weaknesses. After completing this lesson, you will be able to determine the most suitable style for a certain task and to migrate from one to another in case of necessity.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@2d1a356346604f279f193877ee47a0ee"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@2d1a356346604f279f193877ee47a0ee" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Definition</h3> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/e7e2f4cd1ae16327679f019398958d7b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L2\_Description.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 130px;" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>A software system is called "monolithic" if it has a monolithic architecture, in which functionally <b>distinguishable</b> aspects (for example, data input and output, data processing, error handling, and the user interface) are not architecturally <b>separate</b> components but are all <b>interwoven</b>.&nbsp;</p> <p>The term "monolith" is increasingly being used as a generic insult in the same way that "legacy" is!&nbsp;<em><a href="http://www.codingthearchitecture.com/2014/11/19/what\_is\_a\_monolith.html" target="\_blank">R.&nbsp;Annet (2014)</a></em></p> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-2" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e9b36db9ac394ef68e11519bbc721512"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e9b36db9ac394ef68e11519bbc721512" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Viewtypes</h3> <p>A monolith can be considered an architectural style or a software development pattern (or anti-pattern if you view it negatively). Styles and patterns usually fit into different Viewtypes and some basic viewtypes which will be discussed are Module, Allocation and Runtime. A monolith could refer to any of these basic viewtypes.</p> <p><em> Click on the hot spots to see the description of the viewtypes. </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 700px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/d25ee2c914809f5e07ae7c822e249bc8/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_ASP\_L2\_101.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-1"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Module. </b>If you have a module monolith then all of the code for a system is in a single codebase that is compiled together and produces a single artifact.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-2"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Runtime. </b>A runtime monolith will have a single application or process performing the work for the system (although the system may have multiple, external dependencies). Many systems have traditionally been written like this (especially line-of-business systems such as Payroll, Accounts Payable, CMS etc).</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-3"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>For an <b>allocation</b> monolith, all of the code is shipped/deployed at the same time. In other words once the compiled code is 'ready for release' then a single version is shipped to all nodes.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><em>If you want to know more please follow the <a href="http://www.codingthearchitecture.com/2014/11/19/what\_is\_a\_monolith.html" target="\_blank">link</a>.</em></p> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-1 { left: 16.6%; } }); }); }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-3" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@dfcaa0f604a94fd78fc558a9058dfde3"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@dfcaa0f604a94fd78fc558a9058dfde3" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Pros and Cons</h3> <p>Despite the fact that microservice is the latest trend nowadays, the monolithic architecture still has a number of advantages, which might be very useful and helpful while designing a modern solution. Let's take a closer look at the pros and cons of this style.</p> <p><em>Click on the dots to learn more.</em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/dbc231643caa6a56c8b979e8785bb266/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_ASP\_L2\_102.svg" style="width: 160px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>PROS</h3> <ul> <li><span>Traditional approach, easy to implement (develop, deploy)</span></li> <li><span>Easy to understand from the architectural point of view</span></li> <li><span>Good for scalability in terms of handling additional load from users, adding new application servers</span></li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ee9bc4c01cac5f5290697356b68e3537/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_ASP\_L2\_103.svg" style="width: 160px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>CONS</h3> <ul> <li><span>Large artifacts</span></li> <li><span>Deployment of the entire application</span></li> <li><span>Large and complex codebase</span></li> <li><span>Bad for scalability in terms of data volume</span></li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- :root { --main-color: #30b6dd; }); }); } }); // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-4" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@89dbfd6e190042bbb9e4de1552723fa8"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@89dbfd6e190042bbb9e4de1552723fa8" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Layered Architecture</h3> <p>Layered architecture is the simplest and quite commonly used style in software development. The cost of its implementation is relatively low compare to other patterns. This method is meant to be self-independent; some of the layers are interconnected but do not depend on each other.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the tabs to learn more about layered architecture. </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">Description </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Principle </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Open/Closed principle </button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <p style="margin-bottom: 7px;">Components within the layered architectural style are organized into horizontal layers, each layer performing a specific role within the application (e.g., presentation logic or business logic, etc.). One of the powerful features of the layered architectural style is the separation of concerns among components/layers.</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/e7e2f4cd1ae16327679f019398958d7b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L2\_Description.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"><ol> <li>It can be logical and physical.</li> <li>Each layer is on top of another layer.</li> <li>There are well-defined interfaces between layers.</li> <li>It reduces complexity, improves modularity, reusability, maintainability.</li> <li>It can affect performance due to communication through all layers.</li> <li>There are different criteria for layering: most notably abstraction.</li> </ol></div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <p>The structure of the system is organized into a set of layers. In this strictly layered structure, a layer can only use the services of the layer immediately below it. Many variations of this pattern, lessening the structural restriction, occur in practice.</p> <p>Normally, requests always go from up to down. A lower layer should never perform a request to the upper layers.</p> <img src="/assets/courseware/v1/77d7b9c1229abbed7fa16c838197f206/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Layered\_architecture\_Principle.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; height: 180px; margin: 0 auto; padding: 5px 0;" /></div> <div class="tab-content"> <p>The Open/Closed principle allows skipping some layers intentionally. A similar concept described by the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) is called layer bridging.</p> <img src="/assets/courseware/v1/8d3809a54a10bb841c4494087d7819d3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Open\_Closed\_Principle\_\_1\_.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; height: 190px; margin: 0 auto;" /></div> </div> <p><em>Please follow the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/software-architecture-patterns/9781491971437/ch01.html" target="\_blank">link</a> to get additional information about Layered Architecture.</em></p> <style><!-- p.tab-wrapper-about.tab-wrapper-about-2 { margin-bottom: 5px; Despite there is no unified definition for microservices, they can be described as self-contained pieces of business functionality with clear interfaces. It is common for this type of architecture to be adopted for cloud-native applications and serverless computing. It structures the application as a collection of loosely coupled services.</p> <p>The smaller services, the smaller responsibilities, and the less coupling, the more infrastructure mess, which leads to more complicated deployment topology/management and support.</p> <p><em>Follow the&nbsp;<a href="https://articles.microservices.com/tagged/learning-microservices" target="\_blank">link</a> to have a more detailed look at microservices.&nbsp;</em></p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-6" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@8a78c4a402714c69b57d1b5cb2a264e8"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-problem xmodule\_display xmodule\_CapaModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="True" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="problem" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@8a78c4a402714c69b57d1b5cb2a264e8" data-type="Problem" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "Problem"} </script> <div id="problem\_8a78c4a402714c69b57d1b5cb2a264e8" class="problems-wrapper" role="group" aria-labelledby="8a78c4a402714c69b57d1b5cb2a264e8-problem-title" data-problem-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@8a78c4a402714c69b57d1b5cb2a264e8" data-url="/courses/course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021/xblock/block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@8a78c4a402714c69b57d1b5cb2a264e8/handler/xmodule\_handler" data-problem-score="0" data-problem-total-possible="0" data-attempts-used="1" data-content=" &lt;h3 class=&#34;hd hd-3 problem-header&#34; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the flip cards to explore the core attributes and challenges of the microservices style. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/85445d87e53c3a84a194db23d80a666e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_ASP\_L2\_104.svg" style="height: 190px;" /> <p><strong>Core Attributes</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>Lightweight SOA</li> <li>Small (easy to understand, quick to deploy)</li> <li>Loose coupling, high cohesion</li> <li>Independent (easier to deploy new versions of services frequently)</li> <li>Faults isolation</li> <li>Accessed using REST; There is a list of characteristics, and it is expected the microservice architectures have a maximum number from this list. Unfortunately, it doesn't always happen. The main characteristics related to microservices are presented below.</p> <p><em>Scroll to overview the details.</em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong><span> Componentization via Services </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/08ad4224e9e76a7b73e380664772474c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_01.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 170px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> Component-based architecture&mdash;components are good because of low coupling, independent deployment, and scalability. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong> Organized Around Business Capabilities </strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7dfad86d1a2588da133a9797b6c11a5a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_02.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> A monolith is split into microservices according to the business "functions", not according to organizational structure. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong><span> Products Not Projects </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/3495ad81c5e5d3b1e3362df3ab7f244e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_03.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> Software is treated not as a job to do, but as a product to be developed over its lifetime. This emphasizes business value for users. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong><span> Smart Endpoints and Dumb Pipes </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c012cc692ffa1196b94abcf645e916c4/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_04.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 180px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> Simple communication with no logic (complex routing, transformation, e.g., ESB) plus smart service that contains logic inside. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong><span> Decentralized Governance </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/636c39f0cad30569f5958bbedb74e0fb/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_05.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> In microservices, you might take advantage of different tools and approaches to better suit a task. Responsibility is distributed as well, and this impacts quality. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong><span> Decentralized Data Management </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7204fb5185dbb95cabcb16f22f90cc91/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_06.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 145px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> Instead of an organizational structure and vendor-licensing driven approach of storing data, microservices use separate databases for each service. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong><span> Infrastructure Automation </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/139104d57b8d0d0722d2969cb4903cfb/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_07.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 180px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> Extensive use of automated-infrastructure platforms (for example, Amazon Web Services) for both deployment and operations. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong><span> Design for Failure </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/776dc2fbd8171abd24166b02a7c5d3de/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_08.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> A special attention is paid to designing software which is tolerant to failures as much <br />as possible. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 5px;"><strong><span> Evolutionary Design </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/496364a108c9778440cbf30d0a674138/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.L2.Characteristics\_09.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px; height: 110px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p><span> Making changes and evolving a system processes are promoted, since you can touch a component with no impact on other components. </span></p> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> <style><!-- body.view-in-course div.container .course-wrapper { display: table; } .dm-mySlides { min-width: 320px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px; padding: 10px; text-align: center; } .dm-mySlides p { text-align: center; } --></style> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-9" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@6b72055bdfa54ea49d26e5a82e66d9d8"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@6b72055bdfa54ea49d26e5a82e66d9d8" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Microservices: Technology-Agnostic Architecture</h3> <p>The diagram below represents the structure of microservices architectural style, which might consist of different components apart from the microservices themselves. Let's examine the diagram, the layers it consists of, and discover how it works. Let's examine the diagram, the layers it consists of, and discover how it works.</p> <p><em>Click on the dropdowns to learn the details.</em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Diagram </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>This diagram depicts a reference architecture for the microservices architectural style.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/ceb6dce7c26936d8dd3ee83f5c137f50/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_ASP\_Technology-agnostic\_architecture.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="width: 750px; margin: 0 auto;" /></p> <p>The <b>consumer layer</b> shows different clients of the product represented by different platforms. The <b>delivery layer</b> balances requests, catches static web content, and addresses requests to the right application. The <b>aggregation layer</b> includes the server-side UI application, different sets of APIs for specific clients, which aggregate business services. The <b>services layer</b> contains gateway and discovery services, business services, system services. <b>System services</b> include existing services in the customer&lsquo;s environment, such as LDAP, printing service, email server, time service. The <b>infrastructure layer</b> provides virtual infrastructure for the platform. <b>API gateway </b> and service discovery internal components provide routing, discovery, balancing and security for the service layer. <b>Business microservices</b> implement business logic and processes. <b>Platform services</b> provide support for security and microservices management. </p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> How It Works </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>This diagram demonstrates a common flow of the requests in a microservices architecture.</p> <img src="/assets/courseware/v1/96f88fdc5191ce57c69760c107de1c31/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_ASP\_How\_it\_works\_\_1\_\_\_1.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 800px; margin: 15px auto;" /> <p>The application performs a call to some API endpoint (usually API gateway). The system authenticates the incoming request, then (by using service discovery) the system determines where to redirect this call. The call routes to corresponding services. All services, when they start, should register themselves in the service discovery registry. Otherwise, the system won&rsquo;t be able to route calls properly. If at some point any service should call another service, it uses service discovery to determine the location (address, port) of that service.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Now, when you became familiar with the components of microservices architectural style, let&rsquo;s overview the common flow of request and consider an implementation example.</p> <p><em>Watch the video to explore microservices architecture and see step-by-step example of implementation. Its main stages and components are represented by the diagram below.</p> <p>API Layer describes a protocol and a contract of interaction. Business Processes and Logic contain main business logic for that particular service. Domain Layer contains domain business objects and repositories for data access. Gateways and HTTP Client allow for redirecting calls to other services. Event-Driven</h2> <div class="bookmark-button-wrapper"> <button class="bookmark-button " aria-pressed="false" data-bookmark-id="volodymyr\_kosmirak\_gmail\_com,block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@5867d9eebb7e4e40a7694d733dcca635" data-bookmarks-api-url="/api/bookmarks/v1/bookmarks/"> </button> <div class="bookmark-tooltip">Bookmark</div> </div> <script> if ($("#seq\_content").length === 0) { $("#contentframe").context.documentElement.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; $(window).context.body.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; } </script> <div class="vert-mod"> <div class="vert vert-0" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@fd2488e836494f8e864beec04769c8cc"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@fd2488e836494f8e864beec04769c8cc" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Introduction</h3> <p>In this lesson, you will get acquainted with the event-driven architectural style commonly used in modern microservice-based applications. Within this approach, events are used to trigger and communicate between decoupled services. You will learn the key characteristics of this style, its two main topologies, and their implementation. In addition, the lesson contains a quiz for self-testing.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .base\_image\_container { width: 100% !important; height: 100% !important; } .base\_image\_container img\[alt="Drop target image"\] { width: 100% !important; } --></style> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@5d62fdaf885d4540be614ef48d935853"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@5d62fdaf885d4540be614ef48d935853" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Event-Driven Architectural Pattern</h3> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <p>The event-driven architectural pattern is a common asynchronous architectural pattern used to produce highly scalable applications. It is also highly adaptable and can be used for small applications as well as large, complex ones. Event-driven architecture comprises highly decoupled, single-purpose event processing components that asynchronously receive and process events.</p> </div> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/28798ed0fa3747def24e70bad96a843b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_Event\_driven\_architectural\_pattern.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 150px;" /></div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-2" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@d301222883a043f689a735c386bc7468"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@d301222883a043f689a735c386bc7468" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>What Is an Event?</span></h3> <p>An event is defined as a change of a system&rsquo;s state. With event-driven architecture, when an event notification is sent, the system captures this change and waits to send the reply to whoever requests it whenever they request it. The application that received that message can either respond or wait to respond until the awaited change in state has occurred.</p> <p>In event-driven architecture, an event will likely trigger one or more actions or processes in response to its occurrence. Let&rsquo;s overview the examples of events and the corresponding responses.</p> <p><em>Swipe the illustration to the left to see events examples and to the right to see corresponding responses.</em></p> <div class="swipe-m-wrapper"> <div class="swipe-m-container"> <div class="swipe-m-inner" style="width: 100%; }); }).on("mouseup touchend touchcancel", function (e) { dragElement.removeClass("draggable"); resizeElement.removeClass("resizable"); }); } // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-3" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@842a1488f93b42b096466b704a04d430"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@842a1488f93b42b096466b704a04d430" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Main Topologies</h3> <p>The main goal of applying the event-driven architectural style is to improve scalability and/or performance. There are two main topologies in event-driven architecture. Because the architecture characteristics and implementation strategies differ between these two topologies, it is crucial to understand each one to know which is best suited for your particular situation.</p> <p><em>Click on the video to learn more about two types of topologies. Alternatively, you may click <a href="/assets/courseware/v1/bc7840ebb3fceeec798e9c79de7c099d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Lesson\_3.\_ASP\_SM5\_Architectural\_Style.\_Event-Driven.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a> to download a text script to find out what you will learn.</em></p> <div style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.25%;"><iframe src="https://videoportal.epam.com/video/iframe.html?video=1oxr8NJr&amp;resolution=1920x1080#" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; top: 0; left: 0;"></iframe></div> <p></p> <p></p> <p><em>Please follow the&nbsp;<a href="http://radar.oreilly.com/2015/02/variations-in-event-driven-architecture.html" target="\_blank">link</a> to learn more about the main topologies.</em></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-4" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@d32364c4973043129595391805a6e6f1"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@d32364c4973043129595391805a6e6f1" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Mediator Topology</span></h3> <p>The mediator topology is applied for events that consist of multiple steps with some level of orchestration that should be used to process the event. <b>For example</b>, a single event to place a stock trade might require you to first validate the trade, then check the trade compliance against various rules, assign the trade to a broker, calculate the commission, and finally place the trade with that broker. All of these steps would require some level of orchestration to determine the order of steps and which can be done serially or in parallel.</p> <p>The mediator topology consists of four main types of architecture: event queues, an event mediator, event channels, and event processors. Now, let&rsquo;s take a closer look at these components as well as the main events within this pattern.</p> <p><em>Scroll to learn more about mediator topology components.</em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Events </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f88dbdd407873a5312690457b5d2effc/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_scroll\_Events.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 110px;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;"><span> There are two types of events within this pattern: an initial event and a processing event. The initial event is the original event received by the mediator, whereas the processing events are generated by the mediator and received by the event-processing components. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong> Event Mediator </strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/61ca3a9d7fc9cfcbcbf5b1da9e05e215/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_scroll\_Events\_mediator.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 110px;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;"><span> The event mediator component is responsible for orchestrating the steps contained within the initial event. For each step in the initial event, the event mediator sends out a specific processing event to an event channel, which is then received and processed by the event processor. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Event Channels </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/767f1d86bbd217f41e837b89080cd3af/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_scroll\_Events\_channels.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 110px;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;"><span> They are used by the event mediator to asynchronously pass processing events related to each step in the initial event to the event processors. The event channels can be either message queues or message topics, although message topics are most widely used with the mediator topology. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Event Queues </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/d31bdbc44e8c43b04ba714eed0da2579/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_scroll\_Events\_queues.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 110px;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;"><span> It is common to have anywhere from a dozen to several hundred event queues in an event-driven architecture. The pattern does not specify the implementation of the event queue component. It can be a message queue, a web service endpoint, or any combination thereof. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Event Processors </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c6c1f93df85c6bd0f229c18e8c5c9409/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_scroll\_Events\_processors.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 110px;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;"><span> They contain the application business logic necessary to process the processing event. Event processors are self-contained, independent, highly decoupled. Each event processor should perform a single business task and not rely on other event processors to complete its specific task. </span></p> </div> </div> </div> <p>Now, when you became familiar with the main concept, let&rsquo;s pay attention to the general mediator topology of the event-driven architecture pattern. For this aim, pay attention to the scheme below.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the hot spots to figure out how the above mentioned components are involved in the mediator topology flow.</em></p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 700px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/544b0ed0999ceeada2ee9c9e1713305b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_L3\_Mediator\_Topology.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-1"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Event. </b>To start the event flow, an event is sent to an event queue by a client. It is used to transmit an event to the event mediator.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-2"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Mediator. </b>The event mediator gets the initial event. After receiving, it is orchestrated by transmitting additional asynchronous events to event channels in order to perform all steps of the process.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-3"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Event Channel. </b>The event mediator uses event channels to pass asynchronously specific processing events associated with each step of the initial event to the event processors.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-4"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Event Processor. </b>Listening to event channels, event processors obtain the event from the event mediator and perform specific business logic to process the event.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-1 { left: 7%; } }); }); }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-5" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@8691f9a26dd44bbfb9dbcfdbeb4efdbb"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@8691f9a26dd44bbfb9dbcfdbeb4efdbb" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Mediator Topology Implementation</h3> <p>There are different ways that allow to implement the event mediator. A solution architect should be aware of all these implementation options to ensure that the solution chosen for the event mediator meets your needs and requirements.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the tabs to overview these ways. </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">Open Source Integration Hubs </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Business Process Execution Language </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Business Process Manager </button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/270e91b478e8e94e5ffe62d034e20603/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_tabs\_Open\_source\_integration\_hubs.svg" style="height: 110px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>The simplest and most common implementation of the event mediator is through open source integration hubs such as Spring Integration, Apache Camel, or Mule ESB. Event flows in these hubs are typically implemented through Java code or a DSL (domain-specific language).</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/43a3dc9824965545fcda83115e670ad3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_tabs\_Business\_process\_manager.svg" style="height: 110px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>For more sophisticated mediation and orchestration, you can use BPEL (business process execution language) coupled with a BPEL engine like the open-source Apache ODE. BPEL is a standard XML-like language that describes the data and steps required to process an initial event.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/888358794b7b89dc8d8486e154e786d5/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_tabs\_Business\_process\_execution\_language.svg" style="height: 110px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>One more way which can be used is the case of extensive applications requiring much more sophisticated orchestration (including steps involving human interactions) refers to mediator implementation using a business process manager (BPM) such as jBPM.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.tab-wrapper-about.tab-wrapper-about-2 { margin-bottom: 5px; } .tab-controls { overflow: hidden; background-color: #30b6dd; border-radius: 6px 6px 0 0; display: flex; } .tab-controls button:not(:last-child) { margin-right: 0px; } .tab-controls button { background-image: none; }); }); } }); // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-6" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@9d46cfe2592b4347aa771c97f7f97bc3"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@9d46cfe2592b4347aa771c97f7f97bc3" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Mediator Topology Example</span></h3> <p>This section is aimed to illustrate how the mediator topology works. Imagine that you are insured through an insurance company, and you decide to move. In this case, the initial event might be called something like <em>relocation event</em>. The steps involved in processing a <em>relocation event</em> are contained within the event mediator. For each initial event step, the event mediator creates a processing event (e.g., <em>change address, recalc quote</em>, etc.), sends that processing event to the event channel, and waits for the processing event to be processed by the corresponding event processor (e.g., customer process, quote process, etc.). This process continues until all of the steps in the initial event have been processed. The single bar over the recalc quote and update claims steps in the event mediator indicate that these steps can be run simultaneously.</p> <p><em>Move the pieces of the image below in order to rebuild the scheme. At the same time, the message flow is distributed between event processor components in a chain manner through a lightweight message broker (e.g., ActiveMQ, HornetQ, etc.). This type of topology can be used for a simple event-processing flow that does not require central event orchestration. Now, let&rsquo;s pay attention to these topology components.</p> <p><em>Click on the dots to learn more about broker topology components. </em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7a27c7a0d0bfbe790131de0ccb1e7178/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_about\_broker\_topology\_components\_dot\_1.svg" style="height: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Broker topology consists of a <b>broker</b> component and an <b>event processor</b> component. The broker component can be centralized or federated and contains all event channels used within the event flow. As ypu already know, the event channels contained within the broker component can be message queues, message topics, or a combination of both.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/a774886db7df7e685d6ad7f6a3412f12/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_about\_broker\_topology\_components\_dot\_2.svg" style="height: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Message queues, message topics, or a combination of both can serve as the event channels contained within the broker component. As a consequence of having no central event-mediator component that controls and orchestrates the initial event, each event-processor component assumes responsibility for processing an event and publishing a new event that reveals the action it has just executed.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Now, let&rsquo;s look at the scheme below. As you can see, there is no central event-mediator component that controls and orchestrates the initial event. Instead, each event-processor component is responsible for processing an event and publishing a new event indicating the action it has just performed.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f9f3dcc327b82cb3fee78953975e3b36/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_scheme\_2.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 500px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p><b>For example</b>, an event processor that balances a portfolio of stocks may receive an initial event called <em>stock split</em>. The event processor may do some portfolio rebalancing based on that initial event and then publish a new event to the broker called <em>rebalance portfolio</em>, which would then be picked up by a different event processor. Sometimes an event may be published by an event processor but not picked up by any another event processor. This is a common situation if you are evolving an application or providing for future functionality and extensions.</p> <style><!-- :root { --main-color: #30b6dd; } .step { display: none; } .slider-linear-wrapper { margin: auto; padding: 20px; background-color: white; font-family: "Raleway", sans-serif; color: #33312E; border-radius: 0.2em; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar { width: 100%; list-style-type: none; display: flex; Let&rsquo;s take the workflow of an insurance company where a customer wants to change the address. In this example, there are two event processors that are interested in the <em>change address</em> event:&nbsp;the quote process and the claims process.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the hot spots to overview the example. </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 450px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/ea609941feec0b1a4752d3da55da91a3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L3\_scheme\_3.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-21"> <span class="hotspot-icon">1</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>After the customer has moved, an initiation event is created and will be handled by the customer processor.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-22"> <span class="hotspot-icon">2</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The customer processor will go through the customer records and update the address.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-23"> <span class="hotspot-icon">3</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>Once updated, the customer process will post a message to a message queue for the other event processors. Those that are &lsquo;interested&rsquo; in address changes will &lsquo;listen&rsquo; and respond.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-24"> <span class="hotspot-icon">4</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>In this case, both the quote and claims processes are listening and will pick up this change address message from the message queue.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-25"> <span class="hotspot-icon">5</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The quote processor will update the quotes and recalculate them on behalf of the customer. After that, it will send a message to the notification message queue.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-26"> <span class="hotspot-icon">6</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>Simultaneously, the claims process will handle the change of address message by updating claims. After that, it will post a message to the message queue for anyone interested in updated claims.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-27"> <span class="hotspot-icon">7</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>Both the notification and adjustment processors pick up this message and generate an email to the customer, indicating that all work has been done.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-21 { left: 28%; It has some significant advantages, but in general, it is relatively complex to implement. So, let&rsquo;s take a closer look at event-driven architecture&rsquo;s pros and cons.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the flip cards to learn more about event-driven architecture advantages and downsides. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9489bbed8784a0e4ba755f34331b6678/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/D\_and\_D\_Pros.svg" style="height: 190px;" /> <p><strong>PROS</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>Loosely coupled architecture</li> <li>Scalability and performance QAs can be achieved relatively easily</li> <li>Overall, it&rsquo;s right from a deployment perspective because all is decoupled</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/68573e6ac46537c10229e6ac232a8838/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/D\_and\_D\_Cos.svg" style="height: 190px;
