<div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-vertical" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="VerticalStudentView" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@2fe67faeb329469585a7d1eb1f8fa3e0" data-block-type="vertical"> <h2 class="hd hd-2 unit-title">L4: Architectural Style. Actor-Based and Module-Based</h2> <div class="bookmark-button-wrapper"> <button class="bookmark-button " aria-pressed="false" data-bookmark-id="volodymyr\_kosmirak\_gmail\_com,block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@2fe67faeb329469585a7d1eb1f8fa3e0" data-bookmarks-api-url="/api/bookmarks/v1/bookmarks/"> </button> <div class="bookmark-tooltip">Bookmark</div> </div> <script> if ($("#seq\_content").length === 0) { $("#contentframe").context.documentElement.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; $(window).context.body.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; } </script> <div class="vert-mod"> <div class="vert vert-0" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@2771bf16443e4df18ebeb4dfd3bc535a"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@2771bf16443e4df18ebeb4dfd3bc535a" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Introduction</h3> <p>This lesson will provide information about the actor-based architectural style, its unique aspects, and cases when it is applicable. First developed in the early 1970s, this style has evolved over the years, but the fundamental concepts remained the same. Besides the general overview, you will learn the languages and frameworks it works with and examine some examples which will allow you to understand this style better. Moreover, you will familiarize yourself with module-based architecture and its main features.</p> <p></p> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@7e8fde2c795342f9861bc53d57119330"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@7e8fde2c795342f9861bc53d57119330" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Actor Model Overview</h3> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <p>The actor model aims to deal with concurrent computations. It identifies standard rules that describe the required behavior of the system&rsquo;s components and their interaction. As a primitive unit of computation, an actor obtains a message and performs a kind of calculation based on it. This model&rsquo;s concept is akin to the object-oriented approach: an object obtains a message (a method call) and acts according to the message it has received (the method you are calling).</p> </div> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ee5090f28dc26cb1fcbd95ee22dda0ec/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_L4\_Actor.svg" alt="Actor Model Overview" width="130" /></div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-2" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@c523c00018c046958f42f2b8cd328912"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@c523c00018c046958f42f2b8cd328912" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <p><em>Click on the video to learn more about the actor and the actor model. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;<a href="/assets/courseware/v1/90e4cf3a30732ccfa080538106617094/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Lesson\_4.\_ASP\_SM5\_Architectural\_Style.\_Actor-Based\_and\_Module-Based.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a> to download a text script to find out what you will learn. </em></p> <div style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.25%;"><iframe src="//videoportal.epam.com/video/iframe.html?video=9oXDeGow&amp;resolution=1920x1080#" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; top: 0; left: 0;"></iframe></div> <p></p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-3" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@212bf3ef210b47f3b31c4358f3c65389"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@212bf3ef210b47f3b31c4358f3c65389" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>How Does the Actor-Based Model Work?</span></h3> <p>Actors send messages to each other. Sending a message does not transfer the thread of execution from the sender to the destination. An actor can send a message and continue without blocking. Therefore, it can accomplish more in the same amount of time. Let&rsquo;s figure out what happens when an actor receives a message.</p> <p><em>Scroll to learn more.</em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll; max-width: 93%;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 285px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/3592b8eb8679d3da811f5e0f23126587/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_101.svg" width="180" height="160" /></span></p> <p style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">First, the actor adds the message to the end of a queue.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 285px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/02a6f93f7a089a8914a2276542623a52/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_102.svg" width="180" height="160" /></span></p> <p style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">If the actor was not scheduled for execution, it is marked as ready to execute.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 285px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/2dc9e5adfed9bcf2795ef28d21965c58/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_103.svg" width="200" height="160" /></span></p> <p style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">A hidden scheduler entity takes the actor and starts executing it.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 285px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/1dd3285e5905c426eb850abc97b75336/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_104.svg" width="200" height="160" /></span></p> <p style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Then, the actor picks the message from the front of the queue.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 285px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/148b18328b91111012ba06619485df3c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_105.svg" width="200" height="160" /></span></p> <p style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">The actor modifies the internal state and sends messages to other actors.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 285px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/dae49084c3e13c51f7ac7a1f0b38fc9a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_106.svg" width="200" height="160" /></span></p> <p style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">At this stage, the actor is<br /> unscheduled.</p> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-mySlides { min-width: 200px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px; padding: 10px; text-align: center; } .dm-mySlides p { text-align: center; } --></style> <p>Actors need to store messages somewhere while processing another message. The mailbox is the place where these messages are stored. There are several things you must keep in mind to move forward.</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c58584c2698d4e03a9a0f190d8735711/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/006\_1.3\_Attention2\_\_2\_\_.svg" alt="attention" width="120" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Although multiple actors can run simultaneously, each actor processes a message in sequence. There is no difference whether the actor you are sending a message to is running locally or in another node. If you consider an actor as a unit of code with a mailbox and internal state which only responds to the messages, it does not matter which machine it is running on. So, multiple computers can be used to recover when one of them fails.</p> </div> </div> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-4" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-problem xmodule\_display xmodule\_CapaModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="True" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="problem" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4" data-type="Problem" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "Problem"} </script> <div id="problem\_dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4" class="problems-wrapper" role="group" aria-labelledby="dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4-problem-title" data-problem-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4" data-url="/courses/course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021/xblock/block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4/handler/xmodule\_handler" data-problem-score="0" data-problem-total-possible="0" data-attempts-used="1" data-content=" &lt;h3 class=&#34;hd hd-3 problem-header&#34; id=&#34;dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4-problem-title&#34; aria-describedby=&#34;block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4-problem-progress&#34; tabindex=&#34;-1&#34;&gt; Test Your Knowledge &lt;/h3&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;problem-progress&#34; id=&#34;block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4-problem-progress&#34;&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;problem&#34;&gt; &lt;div&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;wrapper-problem-response&#34; tabindex=&#34;-1&#34; aria-label=&#34;Question 1&#34; role=&#34;group&#34;&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;This is a non-graded quiz. When you have selected an answer, click the &amp;#8220;Submit&amp;#8221; button below. Once your answer is submitted, click &amp;#8220;Show Answer&amp;#8221; to see the correct answer.&lt;/em&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Suppose you need to process three messages. What should be done if you want these messages to be processed concurrently?&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;choicegroup capa\_inputtype&#34; id=&#34;inputtype\_dba6e5db90c441d49634c8f13d1945c4\_2\_1&#34;&gt; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <h3><span>Ticket Counter Example</span></h3> <p>Let&rsquo;s revise the ticket counter scenario. In this example, the requestors are represented as customer actors. The ticket count is maintained with an actor, and it holds the current state of the counter. Both the customer and tickets actors do not hold threads when they have no messages to process.</p> </div> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/0f3069a3c301c804ea303266cb66454f/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_107.svg" alt="Actors" width="150" /></div> </div> <p>To initiate a buy operation, a customer actor sends a buy message to a single tickets actor. Such buy messages contain the quantity to be purchased. When a tickets actor receives a buy message, it verifies that the purchase amount does not exceed the current remaining count. If the buy request is valid, the count is decremented, and the tickets actor sends a message to the customer actor indicating that the order has been accepted. If the buy amount exceeds the count, the counter actor sends the customer actor a message indicating that the order was rejected. In order to build a clearer understanding, let&rsquo;s examine this example step-by-step and pay attention to some visualizations.</p> <p><em>Click on the step-by-step interactivity to explore the process described in the example. </em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p>In the following diagram, you can see a few customer actors, each sending a buy message to the tickets actor. These buy messages are initially queued in the tickets actor&rsquo;s mailbox.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9bb91037f22f2af6c82b2e135e6c8dc3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_108.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 500px;" /></p> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p>The tickets actor processes each message. The diagram shows the first message, which is a request to buy five tickets.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f7557ba25f607b946d10db0663ae496c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_109.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 500px;" /></p> <p>The tickets actor checks that the buy amount does not exceed the remaining ticket count. In this case, the ticket count is currently 15, so the buy request is approved, the count is decremented, and a message is sent from the tickets actor to the requesting customer actor indicating that the tickets have been purchased.</p> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p>The tickets actor processes each of the messages in its mailbox.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/d3d4c6f854f5cc337a21c3bcf67ef9ff/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_110.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 500px;" /></p> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p>The following diagram shows how the tickets actor handles requests that exceed the remaining ticket count. You can see a request to buy two tickets when only one is available. The tickets actor rejects this purchase request and sends the requesting customer actor a sold-out message.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/3a3c298cf945e3938fb08c02a71b22d3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_111.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 500px;" /></p> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <p>The actor-based implementation provides natural synchronization of operations within each actor and eliminates the potentially large backlog of threads waiting for their turn at the synchronized section. In the ticket example, each customer actor waits for a response without holding a thread.</p> <style><!-- .step-by-step-text .sbs-arrow-wrapper span { position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 50%; width: 10px; The main languages include Scala and Erlang, while the main frameworks refer to Akka, Orleans, and Vert.x. Now, let&rsquo;s have a more detailed look at each of them.</p> <p><em>Click on the flip cards to learn more about the languages.</em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/708c99ca7f52c98eb02b0474cf528ff4/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/scala-4.svg" style="height: 120px;" /> <p><strong><br />Scala</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p><a href="https://www.scala-lang.org/" target="blank"><em>Scala</em></a> is a general-purpose programming language providing support for functional programming and a strong static type system. Scala combines object-oriented and functional programming in one concise, high-level language. Designed to be concise, many of Scala&rsquo;s design decisions aim to address criticisms of Java.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/588c618150d110f9216d01cc0e9266e5/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/erlang.svg" style="height: 120px;" /> <p><strong><br />Erlang</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p><a href="https://www.erlang.org/" target="blank"><em>Erlang</em></a> is a general-purpose, concurrent, functional programming language, and a garbage-collected runtime system. The term &ldquo;Erlang&rdquo; is used interchangeably with Erlang/OTP, or Open Telecom Platform (OTP), which consists of the Erlang runtime system, several ready-to-use components mainly written in Erlang, and a set of design principles for Erlang programs.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- p.dm2-cardsWrap-about.dm2-cardsWrap-about { margin-bottom: 5px; }); // \]\]></script> <p>Now that you&rsquo;ve become familiar with common languages used when applying an actor-based architectural style, let&rsquo;s view additional information about the range of frameworks, which can also be helpful.</p> <p><em>Click on the tabs to learn more about the frameworks.</em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">Akka</button><button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Orleans</button><button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Vert.x</button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c69dd76e4c2e4e0ccabd30a63e0b8e0f/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/akka\_logo.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 160px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center;"> <p><a href="https://akka.io/" target="blank"><em>Akka</em></a> is a toolkit for building highly concurrent, distributed, and resilient message-driven applications for Java and Scala. Akka&rsquo;s use of the actor model provides a level of abstraction that makes it easier to write correct concurrent, parallel, and distributed systems. The actor model spans the full set of Akka libraries, providing you with a consistent way of understanding and using them. Thus, Akka offers a depth of integration you cannot achieve by picking libraries to solve individual problems and trying to piece them together.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/af9b49f336371dc14e4f79375646f85c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/orleans\_logo.png" style="width: 75%; max-width: 160px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center;"> <p><a href="https://dotnet.github.io/orleans/" target="blank"><em>Orleans</em></a> is a cross-platform framework for building robust, scalable distributed applications. Orleans builds on the developer productivity of .NET and brings it to the world of distributed applications, such as cloud services. Implementation of Orleans is based on the Actor Model. However, unlike actors in more traditional actor systems (e.g., Akka), Orleans grains are virtual actors. The biggest difference is that the physical instantiations of grains are completely abstracted away and are automatically managed by the Orleans runtime.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/03e66cdcf3d1cf39458fdc2831fe63a8/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/vertxlogo.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center;"> <p><a href="https://vertx.io/" target="blank"><em>Eclipse Vert.x</em></a> is a tool-kit for building reactive (scalable as workloads grow, and resilient when failures arise) applications on the JVM. It is backed by a large ecosystem of reactive modules with just all you need to write modern services. Vert.x comes with a simple, scalable, actor-like deployment and concurrency model out of the box that you can use to save you writing your own. The model does not claim to be a strict actor-model implementation, but it does share similarities, especially with respect to concurrency, scaling, and deployment.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@596d6b6f6f2f4a0c9742604e99e5baf8" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Use Case: Orleans for Halo 4 Videogame</span></h3> <p>Let&rsquo;s consider an example of Orleans usage. This framework has been used to build and run multiple cloud services by different teams, including all cloud services for the Halo 4 videogame. There are several services made for two separate games. Those services used Orleans to implement different parts of the game backend logic with distinctly different usage patterns and performance characteristics.</p> <p><em>Click on the dropdowns to learn more.</em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>The Presence service</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;">The Presence service is responsible for keeping track of all active game sessions, participating players, and evolving game status. It enhances players&rsquo; matchmaking experience, allows them to join an active game, enables real-time viewing of a game session, and other functionality.</p> <div style="display: flex;" class="code-join-wrapper"> <div style="width: 55%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/d02135b9235337bfa9fbfcd38a00df90/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_Actor-Based\_model-1.svg" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 45%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>The structure of the Presence service is shown in the diagram. There are three types of actors: Router, Game Session, and Player. Incoming heartbeat requests from consoles are delivered to the Router actor, which decompresses the data, extracts the session ID, and forwards the request to the right Session actor. There is one Game Session actor for every session ID. The Session actor updates its internal in-memory state, and periodically, but not on every heartbeat, calls Player actors using the player IDs extracted from the heartbeat data. Player actors also serve as rendezvous points for an external observer, such as a mobile phone companion application, for finding the current game session for a given user.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>The Statistics service</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;">Statistics service processes results of completed and in-progress games with details of important events, such as successful shots, weapons used, locations of events on the map, etc.</p> <div style="display: flex;" class="code-join-wrapper"> <div style="width: 55%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/2e82fad8a8c39708a63c602013af8ca6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_Actor-Based\_model-2.svg" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 45%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>This diagram shows a simplified architecture of the Statistics service. The front-end server that receives an HTTP request with a statistics data payload saves the data in the Azure Service Bus reliable queue. A separate set of worker processes pull the requests from the queue and call the corresponding Game Session actors using the session ID as the actor identity. Orleans routes this call to the Game Session actor&rsquo;s activation, instantiating a new one if necessary. The Game Session actor first saves the payload as-is to the Azure BLOB store, then unpacks it and sends relevant pieces to Player actors of the players listed in the game statistics. Each Player actor then processes its part and writes the results to the Azure Table store. That data is later used for serving queries about the player&rsquo;s status, accomplishments, etc.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- @media only screen and (max-width: 600px) { .code-join-wrapper { flex-direction: column !important; } .code-join-wrapper div { width: 95% !important; justify-content: center !important; } } --></style> <style><!-- p.bint { margin-bottom: 10px !important; } p.dm-pic3-about.dm-pic3-about2 { margin-bottom: 5px; margin: 0 auto; } } --></style> <script>// <!\[CDATA\[ $(".dm-sc-collaps-wrapper").each(function () { $(this).find(".dm-collaps").click(function () { $(this).toggleClass("dm-collaps--active"); $(this).next().toggle(); }) }) // \]\]></script> <p>There is also one more service called Galactic Reign Service. It uses four types of actors: stateful Game Session and stateless Video Manager, Housekeeper, and Notification actors.</p> <p><em>If you&rsquo;d like to learn how it works, pay attention to this <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Orleans-MSR-TR-2014-41.pdf" target="\_blank">article</a>, page 9.</em></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-9" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@7dc4decbad65464e80426ee5ab3ae5df"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@7dc4decbad65464e80426ee5ab3ae5df" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Actor Model Use Cases</span></h3> <p>Now, when you know how exactly the actor model works, let&rsquo;s discover where it can be effectively applied. The actor model can be used as a framework for modeling, understanding, and reasoning about a wide range of concurrent systems.</p> <p><em>Click on the dots to overview how the actor model can be used. </em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1dce2bca64cf6655230e60566ceca18a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_112.svg" style="height: 130px; padding: 0 20px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Electronic Mail</h3> <p>Electronic mail can be modeled as an actor system. In such cases, accounts are modeled as actors, and email addresses are modeled as actor addresses.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/801681084ea86e958cc5e7b3eadbe9d6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_113.svg" style="height: 130px; padding: 0 10px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Web Services</h3> <p>One more use case refers to web services. They can be modeled with Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP) endpoints, which are modeled as actor addresses.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/951f41cdfeeed7821b7fec2fa35c6ca6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_114.svg" style="height: 130px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Objects With Locks</h3> <p>Objects with locks (e.g., as in Java and C#) can be modeled as a serializer, provided that their implementations are such that messages can continually arrive.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/5377ae7a1ffbca9975f0f3ffb17b8501/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_115.svg" style="height: 130px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Testing and Test Control Notation</h3> <p>The actor model is followed by Testing and Test Control Notation, both TTCN-2 and TTCN-3. In TTCN actor is a test component: either the parallel test component (PTC) or the main test component (MTC).</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- :root { --main-color: #30b6dd; } .step { display: none; } .slider-linear-wrapper { margin: auto; padding: 20px; background-color: white; font-family: "Raleway", sans-serif; color: #33312E; border-radius: 0.2em; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar { width: 100%; list-style-type: none; display: flex; padding: 0; justify-content: center; margin-bottom: 3.5em; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar li.progress-bar\_\_dot { display: block; width: 0.6em; height: 0.6em; border-radius: 50%; border: 0.2em solid var(--main-color); background-color: white; cursor: pointer; transition: all 0.5s ease; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar li::before { display: none; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar li.progress-bar\_\_dot.active { background-color: var(--main-color); } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar li.progress-bar\_\_connector { display: block; width: 20%; max-width: 200px; height: 0.1em; background-color: var(--main-color); margin-top: 0.45em; } --></style> <script>// <!\[CDATA\[ $(".slider-linear-wrapper").each(function () { const circles = $(this).find(".progress-bar\_\_dot"); const step = $(this).find(".step"); if (step.length !== circles.length) { $(this).html("<p style='text-align:center; color: red'>ERROR, UNEQUAL AMOUNT OF SLIDES AND CIRCLES</p>"); } else { step.eq(0).show(); circles.each(function (index) { $(this).click(function () { circles.each(function () { $(this).removeClass("active"); }); step.each(function () { $(this).hide(); }); $(this).addClass("active"); step.eq(index).show(); }); }); } }); // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-10" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@7d9ac2096d0a4ffc947bfaad1326733c"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@7d9ac2096d0a4ffc947bfaad1326733c" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Module-Based Architecture</h3> <p>Modular Architecture, as a style, not only helps to view the system in layers or services but goes one level below as a composition of smaller, physical modules. The keywords you should be aware of when considering module-based architecture are &ldquo;modularity&rdquo; and &ldquo;module&rdquo;.</p> <p><span><em>Click on the flip cards to become familiar with modules and modularity.</em></span></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/8b3e9c487ca22587a77298bb0f2362ea/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_116.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong><br />Modularity</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Modularity is a design principle that helps achieve: loose coupling between components; clear contracts and dependencies between components; hidden implementation using strong encapsulation. In a computer-science sense, modularity is when your software application&rsquo;s code is divided into logical parts representing separate concerns.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7bfb0acd245393137a324b2c48ea64ad/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_117.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong><br />Module</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>The module can be defined as a &ldquo;deployable, manageable, natively reusable, composable, stateless unit of software that provides a concise interface to consumers.&rdquo; If you consider Java, a JAR file represents the essence of a module.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>A module has a name and a version. It also declares all required dependencies, has a clear business context, encloses the physical layer, works within the context provided, and expresses its scope through a public interface. Modules help understand, extend, and manage the system during the design process and during run time. These processes are called design-time modularity and run-time modularity, respectively. The scheme below illustrates the module-based architecture.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7a8ab24db3bff0bca2a61fe153d4eb31/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_L4\_Module-Based\_Architecture.svg" alt="module" width="700" /></p> <p></p> <p>The focus of modular architecture is on how you design the physical composition of the application.</p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-11" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e1f2cd4dfa234f02ba5b9c139f554919"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e1f2cd4dfa234f02ba5b9c139f554919" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Why Should You Care About Modularity?</span></h3> <p>Investing in software modularity has many benefits, but it&rsquo;s basically about providing rapidness and flexibility. Fast and frequent development of new features allows you to provide your customer with new software and hardware products they need. You can maintain quality and product reliability while continuously releasing new features. In an integrated or monolithic architecture, there&rsquo;s a risk that when you introduce a new feature update, the whole product goes down. Even if the update feature is small, like a nice new Graphical User Interface (GUI), customers can be afraid to update if it&rsquo;s a part of a big monolithic package. For many companies, the customers&rsquo; reservations about updating have been a real issue. Modular architecture allows you to speed up the development pace, minimize bugs, provide more time for testing issues and release. You&rsquo;re also forced to use old and expensive hardware and run end-of-life hardware projects, often in panic mode. The benefits of modular architecture can be visualized using a traffic metaphor.</p> <p><em>Swipe the illustration to the right to see the graphic representation of monolithic software architecture and to the left to view a an image of modular software architecture.</em></p> <div class="swipe-m-wrapper"> <div class="swipe-m-container"> <div class="swipe-m-inner" style="width: 100%; As a continuation of its modularity support, it introduces a service-oriented programming model, referred to by some as SOA in a VM, to help you clearly separate interface from implementation. OSGi is a modularity layer for the Java platform. OSGi provides you with several benefits, so let&rsquo;s learn more about them.</p> <p><em>Scroll to learn more about several different opportunities provided by OSGi.</em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll; max-width: 93%;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 130px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/95d828a3c8d1075501d9f74114db960d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_120.svg" width="130" height="130" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">OSGi provides you with an opportunity of packaging an application as logically independent JAR files and deploying only the pieces you need for a given installation. This pretty much describes the purpose of OSGi.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 320px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 130px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/db6e7d30175a2a6b162d2a31c885ab7b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_121.svg" width="145" height="145" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Packaging an application as independent JAR files, declaring which code is accessible from each JAR file, and having this visibility enforced. OSGi enables a new level of code visibility for JAR files so you can specify what is visible externally.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 320px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 130px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/d8990cee57f5adb751b4dab868a0a958/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_122.svg" width="120" height="120" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Defining an extensibility mechanism for an application, like a plugin mechanism. OSGi modularity is particularly suited to providing a powerful extensibility mechanism, including support for execution-time dynamism.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 320px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 130px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/a18aa11e3c68550b4b02a0b2e91e5fc3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_123.svg" width="120" height="120" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Execution-time errors from your application due to the wrong version of a dependent library on the class path. OSGi verifies that the set of dependencies is consistent with respect to required versions and other constraints.</p> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-mySlides { min-width: 320px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px; padding: 10px; text-align: center; } .dm-mySlides p { text-align: center; } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-13" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@aff7b63e0140476883eca62da08c174c"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@aff7b63e0140476883eca62da08c174c" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Jigsaw Project</span></h3> <p>Project Jigsaw is an umbrella project with new features aimed at two aspects: the introduction of the module system in the Java language and its implementation in JDK source and Java runtime. This project&rsquo;s primary motivations are to create a module system for the language, apply it to the JDK source, modularize the JDK libraries, update the runtime to support modularity, and provide the opportunity to create smaller runtime with a subset of modules from JDK.</p> <p><em>Click on the hot spots to learn about modularity tools. </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 700px; width: 100%;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/720dfa405c79d0907929623a29220ec3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA.\_S5.L4\_124.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-001"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;">It helps in analyzing the codebase to identify the dependencies on JDK APIs and the third-party JARs. It also mentions the name of the module where the JDK API can be found. This makes it easier to modularize the codebase</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-002"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;">It helps in analyzing the codebase for the usage of any deprecated APIs</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-003"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;">It helps in creating a smaller runtime by combining the application&rsquo;s and the JDK&rsquo;s modules</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-004"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;">It helps in working with jmod files. jmod is a new format for packaging the modules. Also, you examined the main concept and benefits of the module-based architecture. Now you can differentiate two explained styles clearly and use them in solution development.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-15" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e1e61a76323546d3b9fef79b413e76e0"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e1e61a76323546d3b9fef79b413e76e0" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Quiz</h3> <p><em>These questions are designed to check your understanding of the key concepts of the lesson. <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-vertical" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="VerticalStudentView" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@a747f9a0ca464a0da545c4e93a8525d2" data-block-type="vertical"> <h2 class="hd hd-2 unit-title">L5: Architectural Style. REST</h2> <div class="bookmark-button-wrapper"> <button class="bookmark-button " aria-pressed="false" data-bookmark-id="volodymyr\_kosmirak\_gmail\_com,block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@a747f9a0ca464a0da545c4e93a8525d2" data-bookmarks-api-url="/api/bookmarks/v1/bookmarks/"> </button> <div class="bookmark-tooltip">Bookmark</div> </div> <script> if ($("#seq\_content").length === 0) { $("#contentframe").context.documentElement.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; $(window).context.body.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; } </script> <div class="vert-mod"> <div class="vert vert-0" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e7b659c73f574602b5640937305b1a0e"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e7b659c73f574602b5640937305b1a0e" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Introduction</h3> <p>In the following lesson, you will get acquainted with the Representational State Transfer or REST architectural style and learn how to design web-services using its paradigms. You will gain an understanding of the general approach, as well as the Richardson maturity model and the key constraint of the REST application architecture. Diagrams included in the lesson will help you visualize information and make it easier to master it.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@c2679a9f73034155987381db08d5e766"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@c2679a9f73034155987381db08d5e766" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <h3>REST Formal Constraints</h3> <p>Representational State Transfer or REST is a software architectural style that makes it easier for systems to communicate with each other and defines a set of constraints to use for creating web services. This style is often used in the development of web services. REST-compliant systems are characterized by their statelessness and how they separate the client and server&rsquo;s concerns.</p> </div> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/aeefbcaddb43d3494d40e6b4ee6ae492/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3002\_illustration\_API.svg" alt="REST Formal Constraints" width="200" /></div> </div> <p>REST term was coined by Roy Fielding in 2000. REST does not enforce any rule regarding how it should be implemented at a lower level. It just puts high-level design guidelines and lets you think of your own implementation. REST defines six architectural constraints that make any web service a truly RESTful API.</p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-2" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@5a6c0155ebad48cebf8ec6024df8a6a9"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@5a6c0155ebad48cebf8ec6024df8a6a9" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <p><em><span>Click on the dots to learn more about constraints.</span> </em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;" class="code-join-wrapper"> <div style="width: 45%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/8102d2fd1469ab609c9cebaf39e1f263/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3011\_Scheme\_1.svg" alt="IMG" height="350px" /></div> <div style="width: 55%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Client-Server</h3> <p>Client-Server. The REST style separates clients from a server. This basically means that client and server applications should develop individually and have no dependency on each other. Whether the issue is with the server or the client side, things should flow naturally since there is no coupling between them. The client side should not care about data storage, and the server side should not care about the interface at all. A client should be aware only of resource URIs. Today, this can be considered a standard practice in web development, so nothing extraordinary is required from your side.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;" class="code-join-wrapper"> <div style="width: 45%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f5982e57726208a6926777f5ef161358/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3011\_Scheme\_2.svg" alt="IMG" height="350px" /></div> <div style="width: 55%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Stateless</h3> <p>Stateless. The data from the client&rsquo;s latest HTTP request is not stored on the server, and each request is treated as a new one. There is no session and no history. The client application is required to be a stateful application for the end user, meaning that the user logs in once to perform other authorized operations. All information essential to service the request should be included in each request from the client and contain authentication and authorization details. After the server handles the request, the state changes, and it gets sent back to the requestor with the appropriate HTTP status code.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;" class="code-join-wrapper"> <div style="width: 45%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/99d9a29f6c2be200e54180a2bbdfccf3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3011\_Scheme\_3.svg" alt="IMG" height="350px" /></div> <div style="width: 55%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Cacheable</h3> <p>Cacheable. Caching allows improving the client side&rsquo;s performance and simplifying the server&rsquo;s scope and scalability due to a load reduction. In REST, it can be used for resources when applicable, and these resources are required to declare themselves as cacheable. Caching aims never to have to generate the same response more than once. The request flows through a cache or a series of caches in front of the service hosting the resource. If any of them match any criteria during the request (e.g., the timestamp or the client ID), the data is returned based on the cache layer, and if the caches cannot satisfy the request, the request goes to the server.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;" class="code-join-wrapper"> <div style="width: 45%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/77981380499fb06b53f99b28d3edcdfe/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3011\_Scheme\_4.svg" alt="IMG" height="350px" /></div> <div style="width: 55%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Layered System</h3> <p>Layered system. REST provides an opportunity to use a layered system architecture. Within this approach, the APIs are deployed on Server A, data is stored on Server B, and requests are authenticated on Server C. Under usual circumstances, the client can&rsquo;t tell if it is connected directly to the end server or to an intermediary one. For instance, when you need to scale a service, you might use a proxy working as a load balancer&mdash;that way, the incoming requests are deliverable to the appropriate server instance. The client side does not need to understand how the server works; it just makes requests to the same URI.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;" class="code-join-wrapper"> <div style="width: 45%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c156e4861783346159414f5975fb8c2b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3011\_Scheme\_5.svg" alt="IMG" height="350px" /></div> <div style="width: 55%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>(Optional) Code-On-Demand</h3> <p>Code-on-demand. This constraint is the only optional constraint in the REST style. Mainly static representations of resources are sent in XML or JSON format. In summary, a code-on-demand pattern means that the server can add more functionality to the REST client by sending code that can be executable by that client. It allows the executable code to be returned to support a part of the application, if necessary. For example, to receive a UI widget rendering code, clients can call your API. It is permitted. The constraint says that this strategy improves scalability since the code can execute the server independently on the client side.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;" class="code-join-wrapper"> <div style="width: 45%; align-self: center; text-align: center; padding: 50px 0;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9fa19d4e2f684af81e8a95986a7ef19b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3011\_Scheme\_6.svg" alt="IMG" height="250px" /></div> <div style="width: 55%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Uniform Interface</h3> <p>Uniform interface. This constraint describes a contract between clients and servers. A resource in the system is required to have only one logical URI. It must ensure a way of getting related or additional information. It is recommended to synonymize a resource with a web page. Each resource shouldn&rsquo;t be too large or include everything in its representation. Where applicable, a resource has to contain links to correspondent URIs to receive related information. Once there is a contract aligned with the client and server parts, they can start their works independently. The way that they will communicate is firmly based on the interface.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><em>Please follow the&nbsp;<a href="https://restfulapi.net/" target="\_blank">link</a> to read more about REST.</em></p> <p>Now, when you have familiarized yourself with the main constraints, let&rsquo;s figure out how the general approach to REST style can be illustrated and observe the diagram below. Let&rsquo;s examine some information that can help find a suitable HTTP method for API action.</p> <p><em>Click on the tabs to learn about the most widely used HTTP methods. </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">GET</button><button class="tab-controls\_\_button">POST</button><button class="tab-controls\_\_button">PUT</button><button class="tab-controls\_\_button">DELETE</button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <p>GET requests should be used <b>to retrieve resource representation/information only </b>&ndash; and not to modify it in any way. As GET requests do not change the state of the resource, these are said to be <b>safe methods</b>. Note that GET APIs should be <b>idempotent</b>, which means that making multiple identical requests must produce the same result every time until another API (POST or PUT) changes the resource&rsquo;s state on the server.</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>Example request URIs:</p> <ul> <li>HTTP GET http://www.appdomain.com/users</li> <li>HTTP GET http://www.appdomain.com/users?size=20&amp;page=5</li> </ul> </div> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/3b77b722527fd9c5afae0bf5327a3d6d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_tab\_get.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <p>Use POST APIs <b>to create new subordinate resources</b>. For example, a file is subordinate to a directory containing it, or a row is subordinate to a database table. POST methods are used to create a new resource into the collection of resources. If a resource has been created on the origin server, the response SHOULD be HTTP response code <code>201 (Created)</code> and contain an entity that describes the request&rsquo;s status and refers to the new resource.</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>Example request URIs:</p> <ul> <li>HTTP POST http://www.appdomain.com/users</li> <li>HTTP POST http://www.appdomain.com/users/123/accounts</li> </ul> </div> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/a454ef165f85f1f752642c308fda945e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_tab\_post.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <p>PUT APIs are primarily used <b>to update an existing resource</b> (if the resource does not exist, then API may decide whether to create a new one or not). If the PUT API has created a new resource, the origin server MUST inform the user agent via the HTTP response code <code>201(Created)</code> response. If an existing resource is modified, either the <code>200 (OK)</code> or <code>204 (No Content)</code> response codes SHOULD be sent to indicate successful completion of the request.</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>Example request URIs:</p> <ul> <li>HTTP PUT http://www.appdomain.com/users/123</li> <li>HTTP PUT http://www.appdomain.com/users/123/accounts/456</li> </ul> </div> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/a9779ef4cab4de5ddb80ac908a27d24c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_tab\_put.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <p>Use DELETE <b>to delete resources </b>(identified by the Request-URI). A successful response of DELETE requests SHOULD be HTTP response code <code>200 (OK)</code> if the response includes an entity describing the status, <code>202 (Accepted)</code> if the action has been queued, or <code>204 (No Content)</code> if the action has been performed, but the response does not include an entity. If you DELETE a resource, it&rsquo;s removed from the collection of resources.</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>Example request URIs:</p> <ul> <li>HTTP DELETE http://www.appdomain.com/users/123</li> <li>HTTP DELETE http://www.appdomain.com/users/123/accounts/456</li> </ul> </div> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/eaf827968e3c58b17e1a75b25a142661/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_tab\_delete.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> </div> </div> </div> <p><em>Refer&nbsp;<a href="https://restfulapi.net/http-methods/#patch" target="\_blank">here</a> for additional information about HTTP Methods.</em></p> <style><!-- p.tab-wrapper-about.tab-wrapper-about-2 { margin-bottom: 5px; }); tabs.each(function () { $(this).hide(); }); $(this).addClass("active"); tabs.eq(index).show(); }); }); } }); // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-6" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@0bfd5c5328cd4a619b0541efcf1bb34d"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@0bfd5c5328cd4a619b0541efcf1bb34d" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Richardson Model Overview and Example</h3> <p>Leonard Richardson is an expert on RESTful API design. Richardson Maturity Model was developed to help explain the specific properties of a system. The model can be helpful when thinking about using different techniques.</p> <p><em>Click on the video to learn more about the Richardson model. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;<a href="/assets/courseware/v1/9c8dbaf99a678042c1904a417fa2ef17/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Lesson\_5.\_ASP\_SM5\_Architectural\_Style.\_REST.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a> to download a text script to find out what you will learn.</em></p> <div style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.25%;"><iframe src="//videoportal.epam.com/video/iframe.html?video=nJQ3dDor&amp;resolution=1920x1080#" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; top: 0; left: 0;" frameborder="0"></iframe></div> <p></p> <p></p> <p></p> <p>As you&rsquo;ve figured out, the Richardson model breaks down the key elements of the Representational State Transfer approach into several steps. Now, let&rsquo;s overview each of these steps in detail.</p> <p><em><span>Click at the step-by-step interactivity to learn more about the mentioned layers.</span> </em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p><b>Level 0 </b></p> <p>Essentially, what is done at this stage is using HTTP as a tunneling mechanism for your own remote interaction mechanism, usually based on Remote Procedure Invocation. Let&rsquo;s consider an <strong>example</strong> suggested by Martin Fowler. Assume you want to book an appointment with your doctor. First, the appointment software needs to know what open slots the doctor can provide on a given date. It makes a request to the hospital appointment system to obtain that information. In a level 0 scenario, the hospital will expose a service endpoint at some URI. Then you post a document containing the request&rsquo;s details to that endpoint, and the server returns a document with the requested information. The next step is to book an appointment, which can be done by posting the document to the endpoint. In case of success, a response saying the appointment is booked is received. If there is a problem (someone else booked it before you), then you&rsquo;ll get an error message in the reply body.</p> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; text-align: center; margin: 0 auto;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/285665b7933a28c86af73e6f52a0010b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3007\_schema\_Level0-01.svg" alt="Title" /></div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p><b>Level 1: Resources</b></p> <p>At this stage, rather than making all the requests to a singular service endpoint, you can start talking to individual resources. With the initial query, you might have a resource for the given doctor. The reply carries the same necessary information, but each slot is now a resource that can be addressed individually. With specific resources booking an appointment means posting to a particular slot. If it goes right, you get a similar reply. The difference is that if the appointment needs to be (i.e., to book additional tests), first you need to obtain the appointment resource, which might have a URI like<code> http://royalhope.nhs.uk/slots/1234/appointment</code>. After that, you can post to this resource.</p> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; text-align: center; margin: 0 auto;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/27bcd26604d13b40374baeb65a60d57e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3008\_schema\_Level1-01.svg" alt="Title" /></div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p><b>Level 2: HTTP Verbs</b></p> <p>Level 2 uses the HTTP verbs as closely as possible to how they are used in HTTP itself. For the list of slots, this means using GET (the use of GET for a request like this is crucial).</p> <pre><code>GET /doctors/mjones/slots?date=20100104&amp;status=open HTTP/1.1 Host: royalhope.nhs.uk </code></pre> <p>To book an appointment, you need an HTTP verb that changes state; for example, a POST or a PUT. If it succeeds, the service replies with a response code of 201 to indicate that there&rsquo;s a new resource. The 201 response includes a location attribute with a URI that the client can use to GET the current state of that resource in the future. There is also a difference if something goes wrong. Let&rsquo;s imagine that someone else has booked the session. In this case, a 409 (conflict) seems the right choice to indicate that someone else has already updated the resource in an incompatible way.</p> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; text-align: center; margin: 0 auto;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/fa9016f44e22c2d325e9051a14de57ce/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3009\_schema\_Level2-01.svg" alt="Title" /></div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p><b>Level 3: Hypermedia Controls</b></p> <p>As was mentioned in the video, the final level introduces the HATEOAS (Hypertext As The Engine Of Application State) acronym. You can begin with the same GET that you have received in Level 2. This time the response has a new element: each slot now has a link element that contains a URI to tell how to book an appointment. Hypermedia controls tell what can be done next and the URI of the resource you need to manipulate to do it. In this case, the response to your POST will contain several hypermedia controls for different things to do next.</p> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; text-align: center; margin: 0 auto;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/a88ea37b1e0eb5b23173e9dc04b38b59/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_3010\_schema\_Level3-01.svg" alt="Title" /></div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <p><em>For a more detailed overview of this example and code samples, refer <a href="https://martinfowler.com/articles/richardsonMaturityModel.html" target="\_blank">here</a>. </em></p> <style><!-- .step-by-step-text .sbs-arrow-wrapper span { position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 50%; width: 10px; height: 10px; margin-left: -5px; border-left: 2.5px solid #fff; border-bottom: 2.5px solid #fff; -webkit-transform: rotate(-45deg); transform: rotate(-45deg); -webkit-animation: arrow-animation-sbs1 2s infinite; } } --></style> <script>// <!\[CDATA\[ $(document).ready(function () { let allStepBySteps = document.querySelectorAll('.step-by-step-wrapper'); for (let y = 0; y < allStepBySteps.length; y++) { let textBlocks = allStepBySteps\[y\].querySelectorAll('.step-by-step-text'); let sbsButtons = allStepBySteps\[y\].querySelectorAll('.step-by-step-button'); console.log(textBlocks) console.log(sbsButtons) for (let i = 0; i < sbsButtons.length; i++) { if (i === sbsButtons.length - 1) { let current = sbsButtons\[i\]; sbsButtons\[i\].onclick = () => { for (let n = 0; n < sbsButtons.length; n++) { let current = sbsButtons\[n\]; $(textBlocks\[n + 1\]).slideUp(800); $(current).toggleClass('step-by-step-button-flip'); } } } else { let current = sbsButtons\[i\]; sbsButtons\[i\].onclick = () => { $(textBlocks\[i + 1\]).slideToggle(500); $(current).toggleClass('step-by-step-button-flip'); } } } } }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-7" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@900bf804172741fabefaf7f347e0be65"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@900bf804172741fabefaf7f347e0be65" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>HATEOAS Example</h3> <p>As you already know, HATEOAS means that hypertext should be used to find your way through the API. Let&rsquo;s learn more about HATEOAS introduced in the previous block and consider an example. A REST client enters a REST application through a simple fixed URL. All future actions the client may take are discovered within the resource representations returned from the server. The media types used for these representations and the link relations they may contain are standardized. User transitions through the application states by selecting from the links within a representation or by manipulating the representation in other ways allowed by its media type. In this way, RESTful interaction is driven by hypermedia rather than out-of-band information.</p> <p><span><em>Click on the dropdown to see the example.</em></span></p> <p></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>GET Request</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>This GET request fetches an account resource requesting details in a JSON representation.</p> <pre><code>GET /accounts/12345 HTTP/1.1 Host: bank.example.com Accept: application/vnd.acme.account+json ...</code></pre> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>The Response</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>Apart from the statement that there are 100 dollars (US) in the account, the received response includes several possible follow-up links: make a deposit, withdrawal, or transfer; close the account. The "link" tags allow to find the URLs needed for the specified actions.</p> <pre><code>HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/vnd.acme.account+json Content-Length: ... { "account": { "account\_number": 12345, "balance": { "currency": "usd", "value": 100.00 }, "links": { "deposit": "/accounts/12345/deposit", "withdraw": "/accounts/12345/withdraw", "transfer": "/accounts/12345/transfer", "close": "/accounts/12345/close" } } } </code></pre> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>Overdrawn Account</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>When the account information is retrieved, the account is overdrawn. Now you are 25 dollars in the red. You can only deposit money, and you don&rsquo;t have access to other options. As long as you are in the red, the account cannot be closed; it is not possible to transfer or withdraw any money . The hypertext is telling what is allowed and what is not.</p> <pre><code>HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/vnd.acme.account+json Content-Length: ... { "account": { "account\_number": 12345, "balance": { "currency": "usd", "value": -25.00 }, "links": { "deposit": "/accounts/12345/deposit" } } } </code></pre> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><em>Follow the&nbsp;<a href="https://restfulapi.net/hateoas/" target="\_blank">link</a> to find more information regarding&nbsp;HATEOAS Driven REST APIs.</em></p> <style><!-- .dm-pic3 img { height: auto; margin: 10px 10px; } .dm-collaps-wrap { margin-bottom: 15px; box-shadow: 0 1px 2px 0 rgba(44, 47, 60, 0.06), 0 3px 10px 0 rgba(44, 47, 60, 0.09); border-radius: 6px; } .dm-collaps { background-color: #30b6dd;
