font-size: 15px; } .dm-collaps i.fa-angle-down { font-style: inherit; margin-right: 10px; } .dm-collaps--active i.fa-angle-down { transform: scaleY(-1); } button.dm-collaps--active, button.dm-collaps:hover, button.dm-collaps:focus, button.dm-collaps:active { background-color: #1f98bb; color: #fff; background-image: none; box-shadow: none; border: none; text-shadow: none; } .dm-collaps-content { padding: 0 18px; display: none; border-radius: 6px; overflow: hidden; background-color: #fff; } .dm-collaps-content p { margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 15px; } .dm-picnorm { display: flex; align-items: center; } .dm-picnorm img { width: auto; max-height: 150px; margin-left: 10px; } @media only screen and (max-width: 980px) { .dm-picnorm { flex-direction: column; margin: 0 auto; } } --></style> <script>// <!\[CDATA\[ $(".dm-sc-collaps-wrapper").each(function () { $(this).find(".dm-collaps").click(function () { $(this).toggleClass("dm-collaps--active"); $(this).next().toggle(); }) }) // \]\]></script> <style><!-- .flex-content-wrapper { display: flex; } .flex-content-wrapper div:first-child { width: 40%; align-self: center; text-align: center; } .flex-content-wrapper div:last-child { width: 60%; align-self: center; padding-left: 15px; } @media(max-width: 1024px) { .flex-content-wrapper { flex-wrap: wrap; } .flex-content-wrapper div:first-child { width: 100%; align-self: center; text-align: center; } .flex-content-wrapper div:last-child { width: 100%; } } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-8" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@abeb5894f24d47e2b5e20b2b301673d0"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@abeb5894f24d47e2b5e20b2b301673d0" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>REST Architecture Style Best Practices</span></h3> <p>Now, let&rsquo;s examine how to design REST APIs to be easy to understand for anyone consuming them, future-proof, fast, and secure since they may be used to serve confidential data to the clients. For this reason, there are numerous ways for a networked application to break. It should be guaranteed that REST APIs handle errors gracefully using standard HTTP codes.</p> <p><em>Scroll to explore the best practices for creating REST APIs. </em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll; max-width: 93%;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong><span>Accept and Respond <br />with JSON</span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/14b2dce289b5ee598c2f54e3507fb294/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Accept\_and\_respond\_with\_JSON.svg" width="140" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">REST APIs should accept JSON for request payload and send responses to JSON. JSON is the standard for transferring data. Almost every networked technology can use it: JavaScript has built-in methods to encode and decode JSON either through the Fetch API or another HTTP client. Server-side technologies have libraries that can decode JSON without doing much work.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong>Nouns Instead of Verbs in <br />Endpoint Paths</strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/d1a0736294e1bc4b3f0000fec95b0c0a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Nouns\_instead\_of\_verbs\_in\_endpoint\_paths.svg" width="140" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">Your HTTP request method already has the verb, so use the nouns representing the entity that you are retrieving or manipulating as the pathname. Keep in mind, that you should create routes like GET <code>/articles/</code> for getting news articles. Likewise, POST <code>/articles/</code> is for adding a new article, etc.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong><span>Naming Collections with <br />Plural Nouns</span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/1bce063ee0e85296dfef1fe1c8156bb2/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Naming\_collections\_with\_plural\_nouns.svg" width="140" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">Unless you want to retrieve a single item, you should use plural nouns. Tables usually have more than one entry and are named to reflect that, so to be consistent with them, you should use the same language as the table the API accesses. With the <code>/articles</code> endpoint, you have the plural form for all endpoints, so you do not need to change it.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong><span>Nesting Resources for <br />Hierarchical Objects</span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/a3f2af3d32a85e098a11b4eb9c750808/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Nesting\_resources\_for\_hierarchical\_objects.svg" width="150" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">For the endpoints' path that deals with nested resources, append the nested resource as the name of the path that comes after the parent resource. What you consider a nested resource should match what you have in the database tables. If you want an endpoint to get the comments for a news article, append the <code>/comments</code> path to the end of the <code>/articles</code> path.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong><span>Graceful Error Handling and <br />Standard Error Codes</span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/b8a5dbdd19ae19e8cf78d2d4e78e8af6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Errors\_graceful\_handling\_and\_standard\_error\_codes.svg" width="140" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">To eliminate confusion for API users when an error occurs, you should handle errors gracefully and return HTTP response codes that indicate what kind of an error occurred. This gives API maintainers enough information to understand the problem. Prevent the errors that could bring down your system, and don&rsquo;t leave them unhandled.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong><span>Filtering, Sorting, <br />and Pagination</span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/07d12a39101ac9db92baac2c9c9ea028/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Filtering\_sorting\_and\_pagination.svg" width="150" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">The databases behind a REST API can get very large. It can get to the point that the data should not be returned all at once because it slows the system or even brings it down. Items should be filtered. Also, data should be paginated so that only a few results at a time are returned. The usage of server resources can be reduced significantly by filtering and paginating.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong><span>Maintain Good <br />Security Practices</span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/450199fb3366b59c027981d8e4b1f2b6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Maintain\_Good\_Security\_Practices.svg" width="160" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">Most communication between the client and the server must be private. People should not be able to access more information than they requested. For example, a user should not be able to access the data of another user. To enforce the principle of least privilege, you need to add role checks for a single role or have more granular roles for each user.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong><span>Cache Data to Improve<br /> Performance</span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/e797ab4f942ba1df87d7848b411412a6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Cache\_data\_to\_improve\_performance.svg" width="160" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">To return data from the local memory cache, you can add caching. This will help you prevent querying the database to retrieve the data upon a user&rsquo;s request. With caching, users can get data faster. Make sure that the data is up-to-date. There are caching solutions like Redis, in-memory caching, etc. Change the way data is cached as the needs change.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 360px;"> <p style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 0;"><strong><span>Versioning the <br />APIs</span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/56259e948f7482e96b1d2418718fef84/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_scroll\_Versioning\_the\_APIs.svg" width="160" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 0;">You should have different versions of API if you want to make any changes that could negatively affect your clients. The versioning can be done according to semantic version (e.g., 2.0.6 to indicate a major version two and the sixth patch) like most apps do nowadays. This way, you can gradually phase out old endpoints instead of forcing everyone to move to the new API at the same time.</p> </div> </div> </div> <p><em>Refer&nbsp;<a href="https://stackoverflow.blog/2020/03/02/best-practices-for-rest-api-design/" target="\_blank">here</a> if you want to know more.</em></p> <style><!-- .dm-mySlides { min-width: 350px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px; padding: 10px; text-align: center; } .dm-mySlides p { text-align: center; } body.view-in-course div.container .course-wrapper { display: table; } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-9" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@091e6e0fb3fb450d9c9e2ba676cb5492"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@091e6e0fb3fb450d9c9e2ba676cb5492" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Is REST the Best Fit for All Scenarios?</span></h3> <p>REST is the right style to use for most applications. It has an active tooling community and developers are generally comfortable with it. REST is applicable for many use cases. However, there are some exceptions. According to Henric Stene, REST is a good fit for any of the traditional use cases, but there are other technologies that will help &lsquo;supercharge&rsquo; APIs and make them better.</p> <p>Thibault Ducret specifies three distinct areas where REST is not the best option. They include messaging, internal microservices, and performance with GraphQL and gRPC.</p> <p><em>Click on the flip cards to learn more about these areas.</em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/20bb52f12f2d52458fcfa7946a5da19c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_flipcarts\_Messaging.svg" style="height: 120px;" /> <p><strong><br /><br />Messaging</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Messaging-style APIs aren&rsquo;t a good fit for REST because they force users to do constant polling. According to T. Ducret, the architecture should be designed around the Publish-subscribe pattern and implemented through the web socket protocol.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/fe249f520eb85a5f7d7599689e8515d5/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_flipcarts\_\_Internal\_microservices.svg" style="height: 120px;" /> <p><strong><br /><br />Internal microservices</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Another instance where REST is insufficient is when you break apart a monolith and have microservices that must communicate with each other. In this scenario, &ldquo;you may be tempted to replace function calls of the monolithic application with synchronous REST API requests,&rdquo; said Thibault. This creates a series of sequential API requests, essentially perpetuating the monolith.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/10301f4ecaa96ae70204247a64be2ef8/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L5\_flipcarts\_Performance\_with\_GraphQl.svg" style="height: 130px;" /> <p><strong><br />Performance with GraphQl</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>REST isn&rsquo;t the best option if high <b>performance</b> is critical for users. In REST, developers are unable to call multiple resources with a single API call or retrieve only the properties the client requires. For these scenarios, GraphQL can be a more elegant option. Alternatively, other options include adding a fields query parameter or using an optimized (but less readable) payload like gRPC.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- p.dm2-cardsWrap-about.dm2-cardsWrap-about { margin-bottom: 5px; You have also reviewed a Richardson maturity model and hypermedia as the Engine of Application State, which is a constraint for the REST application architecture.</p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-11" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@121ddf8e1a694f0c99aca29ebff6d033"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@121ddf8e1a694f0c99aca29ebff6d033" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Quiz</h3> <p><em>These questions are designed to check your understanding of the key concepts of the lesson. This is a graded quiz. The result of this quiz is going to be included into your cumulative score for&nbsp;Solution Architecture module. <strong>Remember</strong> that to complete the course successfully you need to have cumulatively at least 70% of correct answers. You have two attempts to do the quiz, so please answer carefully!</em></p> <p></p> <p></p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-12" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-problem xmodule\_display xmodule\_CapaModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="True" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="problem" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8" data-type="Problem" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "Problem"} </script> <div id="problem\_7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8" class="problems-wrapper" role="group" aria-labelledby="7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8-problem-title" data-problem-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8" data-url="/courses/course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021/xblock/block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8/handler/xmodule\_handler" data-problem-score="4.0" data-problem-total-possible="5.0" data-attempts-used="2" data-content=" &lt;h3 class=&#34;hd hd-3 problem-header&#34; id=&#34;7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8-problem-title&#34; aria-describedby=&#34;block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8-problem-progress&#34; tabindex=&#34;-1&#34;&gt; &lt;/h3&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;problem-progress&#34; id=&#34;block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8-problem-progress&#34;&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;problem&#34;&gt; &lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;1. role=&#34;group&#34;&gt;&lt;div class=&#34;choicegroup capa\_inputtype&#34; id=&#34;inputtype\_7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8\_2\_1&#34;&gt; &lt;fieldset aria-describedby=&#34;status\_7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8\_2\_1&#34;&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;field&#34;&gt; &lt;label id=&#34;7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8\_2\_1-choice\_0-label&#34; class=&#34;response-label field-label label-inline&#34; aria-describedby=&#34;status\_7906d0314e0a4fc19525dc4bd37098c8\_2\_1&#34;&gt; <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-vertical" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="VerticalStudentView" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@a3eae9202a9344e6b5dfc26d4e6985b6" data-block-type="vertical"> <h2 class="hd hd-2 unit-title">L6: Architectural Patterns. Performance and Scalability</h2> <div class="bookmark-button-wrapper"> <button class="bookmark-button " aria-pressed="false" data-bookmark-id="volodymyr\_kosmirak\_gmail\_com,block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@a3eae9202a9344e6b5dfc26d4e6985b6" data-bookmarks-api-url="/api/bookmarks/v1/bookmarks/"> </button> <div class="bookmark-tooltip">Bookmark</div> </div> <script> if ($("#seq\_content").length === 0) { $("#contentframe").context.documentElement.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; $(window).context.body.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; } </script> <div class="vert-mod"> <div class="vert vert-0" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@085c68b65f7c4c90a2d11ae825e7e997"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@085c68b65f7c4c90a2d11ae825e7e997" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Introduction</h3> <p>When you design software architecture for a complete system, you need to make sure it will accommodate additional sets of requirements beyond the basics. Performance and scalability are essential quality attributes that require particular attention. The following lesson will focus on architectural patterns that help manage potential challenges regarding the system&rsquo;s ability to deal with an increased number of users and execute any action within a given time interval.</p> <style><!-- .base\_image\_container { width: 100% !important; height: 100% !important; } .base\_image\_container img\[alt="Drop target image"\] { width: 100% !important; } --></style> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@2e82d5be2519470081ffad65e964dab0"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@2e82d5be2519470081ffad65e964dab0" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Performance and Scalability Patterns</h3> <p>There are three most frequently used performance and scalability patterns: Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS), Event Sourcing pattern, and Sharding patterns. Let&rsquo;s view them in detail and dive deep into the context they are used in, problems they deal with, and optimal solutions.</p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-2" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@817022623b764109a83664d09be7739d"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@817022623b764109a83664d09be7739d" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 60%; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <h3>Traditional CRUD Architecture</h3> <p>The acronym CRUD, which stands for Create, Read, Update and Delete, is the standardized use of HTTP Action Verbs. In traditional architectures, the same data model is used to query and update a database, as shown in the diagram. It is simple and works well for basic CRUD operations. However, in more complex applications, this approach can become unwieldy and lead to several downsides.</p> </div> <div style="width: 40%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/eeeb17da6f07576805d3e556cfc8d390/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_L6\_Traditional\_CRUD\_Architecture.svg" alt="Traditional CRUD Architecture" width="260px" /></div> </div> <p>For <b>example</b>, the application may perform many different queries on the read side, returning data transfer objects (DTOs) with different shapes. This can complicate object mapping. As for the write side, the model may implement complex validation and business logic. This can result in an overly complicated model, trying to do too much. Read and write workloads usually have different performance and scale requirements and are asymmetrical. Now, let&rsquo;s learn more about CRUD disadvantages.</p> <p><em>Click on the flip cards to learn more about these disadvantages.</em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/27f1b2b2509f0e1b754fc9e5d8e5c62a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Disadvantages\_of\_Traditional\_CRUD\_Approach.svg" style="height: 200px;" /> <p><strong>Mismatch Between the Read and Write Representations</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p style="font-size: 15px;">There is often a discrepancy between the read and write representations of the data. For example, additional columns or properties that must be correctly updated even though they aren&rsquo;t a part of an operation.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/5bb5ef63c1258fef82f8f9b051a10d2b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Disadvantages\_of\_Traditional\_CRUD\_Approach\_2.svg" style="height: 170px;" /> <p><strong><br />Data Contention and Update Conflicts</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p style="font-size: 15px;">Data contention can be caused by locking the records in the data store in a collaborative domain, where multiple actors operate in parallel on the same set of data. Also, update conflicts can be attributable to concurrent updates with optimistic locking. As the system&rsquo;s complexity and throughput grow, the risks increase with them. The traditional approach can harm performance due to load on the data store and data access layer and the complexity of queries required to retrieve information.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/bc31e03461caec4185fc7ff1d26d519a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Disadvantages\_of\_Traditional\_CRUD\_Approach\_3.svg" style="height: 200px;" /> <p><strong>Complexity in Managing <br />Security</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p style="font-size: 15px;">Each entity is subject to read and write operations, making managing security and permissions more complicated and exposing data in the wrong context.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-3" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@28933eb11e804efc93275308e081fe7b"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@28933eb11e804efc93275308e081fe7b" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) Pattern</h3> <p>Let&rsquo;s focus on the Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) pattern, explore it in detail, and dive deep into the context it is used in, problems it deals with, and how it can be applied to resolve these problems effectively.</p> <p><em>Click on the hot spots to learn more about each aspect.</em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 700px; width: 100%;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/1e6f4cd3d08afd699a9bc324511e7bbf/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3003\_Hotspot\_Command\_and\_Query\_Responsibility\_Segregation.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-001"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="margin: 0;"><b>Context/Risk.</b> As a rule, all create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) operations may be used in the same representation of the entity. However, as previously mentioned, this approach has several disadvantages.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-002"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="margin: 0;"><b>Intention.</b> Data should be divided into separate physical stores to perform read and write operations, and eventual consistency between data stores must be supported.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-003"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="margin: 0;"><b>Solution.</b> Utilizing separate interfaces segregate read data from update data operations.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-001 { left: 17%; top: 85%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-002 { left: 45%; top: 85%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-003 { left: 72%; top: 85%; } --></style> <style><!-- p.dm-sc-img-modals1.dm-sc-img-modals1-2 { margin-bottom: 5px; Implementing CQRS in your application can maximize its performance, scalability, and security. The flexibility created by migrating to CQRS allows a system to evolve better over time and prevents update commands from causing merge conflicts at the domain level. Let&rsquo;s figure out how exactly the described pattern can be used to overcome the abovementioned limitations of traditional CRUD architecture.</p> <p><em>Click on the dots to learn more.</em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <p>CQRS helps separate reads and writes into different models using <b>commands</b> to update data and <b>queries</b> to read data. Rather than being data-centric, commands should be task-based. <b>For example</b>, you should use &ldquo;Book hotel room&rdquo; instead of &ldquo;set ReservationStatus to Reserved&rdquo;. Commands may be placed on a queue for asynchronous processing rather than being processed synchronously. Queries never modify the database. A query returns a DTO that does not encapsulate any domain knowledge. The models can then be isolated although it&rsquo;s not an indispensable requirement.</p> <p style="text-align: center;" class="d-j-w"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/6acd82810dd561d808254ce96e97b14a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3001\_Scema\_1.svg" alt="CQRS separates" height="250" /></p> </div> <div class="step"> <p>For better isolation, you can physically set the read data apart from the write data. In this case, the read database can use its own data schema optimized for queries. <b>For example</b>, it can store a materialized view of the data to avoid complex joins or complex O/RM mappings. If you choose to use separated read and write databases, they must be kept in sync. Usually, this is accomplished by having the write model publish an event whenever it updates the database. Updating the database and publishing the event must occur in a single transaction.</p> <p style="text-align: center;" class="d-j-w"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/bbde84ba292cf19b31030ef6cfd0672a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3002\_Scema\_2.svg" alt="CQRS separates" height="250" /></p> </div> </div> <style><!-- @media only screen and (max-width: 600px) { .d-j-w img{ width: 100%; height: auto !important; } } --></style> <style><!-- :root { --main-color: #30b6dd; } .step { display: none; } .slider-linear-wrapper { margin: auto; padding: 20px; background-color: white; font-family: "Raleway", sans-serif; However, in some cases applying this pattern should be avoided. Let&rsquo;s have a look at the good and bad use cases of CQRS.</p> <p><em>Scroll to learn more about scenarios where CQRS can be applied effectively. </em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll; max-width: 93%;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/63d6eb4aa0e1b15848e6528a71ac40a4/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3004\_Scroll\_1.svg" width="140" height="140" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Collaborative domains where many users access the same data in parallel. CQRS allows you to define commands with enough granularity to minimize merge conflicts at the domain level.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 320px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/3a273f254b3b9961091041e2c35e6463/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3005\_Scroll\_2.svg" width="145" height="145" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Scenarios with task-based user interfaces where users are guided through a complex process as a series of steps or with complex domain <br />models.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade" style="min-width: 320px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/52cb1342ad769799ff6913357f5468ce/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3006\_Scroll\_3.svg" width="145" height="145" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Scenarios where data reads performance must be fine-tuned separately from the performance of data writes, particularly when the number of reads is much higher than the number of writes.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 320px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/0123e95b085d18695d893ddb8e4779db/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3007\_Scroll\_4.svg" width="145" height="145" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Scenarios where one team of developers can focus on the complex domain model that is part of the write model, and another team can concentrate on the read model and the user interfaces.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 320px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/52fd833ece6505cd201349c950ea891f/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3008\_Scroll\_5.svg" width="145" height="145" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Scenarios where the system is expected to evolve over time and might contain multiple versions of the model, or where business rules change regularly.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade" style="min-width: 320px;"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><span style="font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;"><img style="display: block; margin: auto;" alt="img" src="/assets/courseware/v1/a93042c9197c187f23b42053392635fd/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3009\_Scroll\_6.svg" width="145" height="145" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;">Integration with other systems, especially in combination with Event Sourcing, where one subsystem&rsquo;s temporal failure shouldn&rsquo;t affect the availability of the others.</p> </div> </div> </div> <p>At the same time, this pattern isn&rsquo;t recommended when the domain or the business rules are simple, and when a simple CRUD-style user interface and data access operations are sufficient. In some cases, CQRS can be replaced with a Reporting Database. Now, let&rsquo;s examine this pattern&rsquo;s strengths and learn more about when it should not be used.</p> <style><!-- .dm-mySlides { min-width: 320px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px; padding: 10px; text-align: center; } .dm-mySlides p { text-align: center; } body.view-in-course div.container .course-wrapper { display: table; } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-6" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@4eb7e4383ebd4fa1a2f4619be6d13ab7"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@4eb7e4383ebd4fa1a2f4619be6d13ab7" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <p><em>Click on the video to learn more about CQRS. The event log can be used to reconstruct past states and as a foundation to adjust the state to cope with retroactive changes automatically. Let&rsquo;s examine which problems Event Sourcing is aimed to solve and how exactly this can be achieved.</p> <p><em>Click on the flip cards to learn more about these aspects. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/6e8fb3161d0be423e65b0dafaa9b62dd/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3010\_Flip\_Context\_Risk.svg" style="height: 120px;" /> <p><strong><br /><br />Context/Risk</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>The majority of applications working with data use the usual approach meaning that the application supports the current state of data making updates as far as users work with it. It may result in poor performance and slow responsiveness caused by conflicts, history loss, and requisite to process it overhead.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div style="font-size: 120px; color: #ccc;" class="flip-arrow">&rsaquo;</div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/bad554fb5230d8dac26fcf219e18ff39/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3011\_Flip\_Intention.svg" style="height: 120px;" /> <p><strong><br /><br />Intention</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>The intention is to support events consistency and provide practical ways of retrieving the object&rsquo;s current state.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div style="font-size: 120px; color: #ccc;" class="flip-arrow">&rsaquo;</div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/5423a9286c79015c9234be71dd7cb964/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3012\_Flip\_Solution.svg" style="height: 130px;" /> <p><strong><br />Solution</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Introduce an approach to handle operations on the data driven by a sequence of events. Each of these events is recorded in an append-only store that acts as the record system (the authoritative data source) for the data&rsquo;s current state.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-9" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@a66ccaee491543aa9808772809545853"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@a66ccaee491543aa9808772809545853" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>How does Event Sourcing Work?</span></h3> <p>Now that you have discovered which problems Event Sourcing is aimed to solve, let&rsquo;s figure out how exactly this pattern works. As you already know, the Event Sourcing pattern defines an approach to handling data operations driven by a sequence of events, and each of them is recorded in an append-only store.</p> <p><em>Click on the step-by-step interactivity to overview this process. </em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/10f24a24c63d6828ce1149b7ba8f5793/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3013\_Steps\_1.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 125px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>A series of events, which imperatively identifies each action that occurred on the data, is sent to the event store by the application code. Each event describes changes made to the data.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/6ccd62104669eeadcb0c4f5e188ad796/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3014\_Steps\_2.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>An event store where the events are persisted serves as the system of records (the authoritative data source) that provides details about the current state of data. The event store usually publishes these events to notify the consumers and handle them if needed. E.g., consumers could initiate tasks that apply the operations in the events to other systems or execute any other associated action that&rsquo;s required to complete the operation.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/de1cad04f40c25e1ca832610f7229700/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3015\_Steps\_3.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>The events published by the event store are usually used to maintain materialized views of entities as actions in the application change them, and for their integration with external systems. For example, a system can maintain a materialized view of all customer orders that used to populate parts of the UI.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/37cd84890c7c31c95a1633e21e61de9b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3016\_Steps\_4.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 135px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Applications can read the history of events at any point. This history can be used to materialize the entity&rsquo;s current state by playing back and consuming all the events related to that entity.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <p>The figure shows an overview of the pattern, including some of the options for using the event stream, such as creating a materialized view, integrating events with external applications and systems, and replaying events to create projections of the current state of a specific entity.</p> <p><em>Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild it. Let&rsquo;s start with seven key situations when the Event Sourcing pattern is the most corresponding and continue with the scenarios where this pattern should be avoided.</p> <p><em>Click on the dots to figure out when to use Event Sourcing.</em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9b2f867464b483c54de43677242288a1/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_when\_to\_use\_Event\_sourcing\_dot\_1.svg" style="width: 110px; padding: 0 20px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>When you need to understand the intent, goal, and reason in data. For example, you can track changes to a customer entity as a set of specific event types such as &ldquo;moved home&rdquo;, &ldquo;closed account&rdquo;, or &ldquo;deceased&rdquo;.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f178192b3e0582458147ed9a27499ab3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_when\_to\_use\_Event\_sourcing\_dot\_2.svg" style="width: 110px; padding: 0 10px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>When you need to register events that arise and respond to them to restore the state of the system, roll back changes or track the history and audit log.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c1126081443b5c6bdc3bb3128858a043/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_when\_to\_use\_Event\_sourcing\_dot3.svg" style="width: 110px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>When working with events is considered a basic feature of the application&rsquo;s operation and needs minor efforts for additional development and implementation.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/2bb93b4b7f4a4a30fd5f56f14bdbb06b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_when\_to\_use\_Event\_sourcing\_dot4.svg" style="width: 110px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>When decoupling of input and output data processes is required. For example, when you need to improve UI performance or to distribute events to other listeners that perform their functions when the event arises.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/3e7138384afaefdbc84df37583f51535/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_when\_to\_use\_Event\_sourcing\_dot5.svg" style="width: 110px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>When you need the flexibility to change the format of materialized models and entity data in case of requirements changes and when combined with CQRS to adjust a read model or the views exposing the data.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/56a927e98e916d0a5e5831369b53135e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_when\_to\_use\_Event\_sourcing\_dot6.svg" style="width: 110px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>In combination with CQRS, when eventual consistency is acceptable and a read model is updated. It can be used when the performance impact of rehydrating entities and data from an event stream are tolerable.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/bb8f56d1f7b4bc85329a63c129cb2a65/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_when\_to\_use\_Event\_sourcing\_dot7.svg" style="width: 110px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Finally, the Event Sourcing pattern can be effectively applied in scenarios when it is crucial to minimize or prevent conflicting updates to data.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>With all the scenarios where the Event Sourcing pattern fits the need, there are several situations where it might not be useful. Let&rsquo;s move to the next interactivity to build an understanding of when you should avoid using this pattern.</p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-11" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@03683838305c4937857b16c68b0dbdea"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@03683838305c4937857b16c68b0dbdea" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <p><em>Scroll to figure out when not to use Event Sourcing.</em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Event Sourcing Example</span></h3> <p>Let&rsquo;s consider the next example. A conference management system has to track the number of completed bookings for a conference. It checks whether there are seats still available when a potential attendee tries to make a booking. The total number of bookings for a conference can be stored in at least two ways.</p> <p><em>Click on the tabs to overview these ways.</em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">Storing as a Separate Entity</button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Storing as Events in the Event Store</button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <p>The system could store information about the total number of bookings as a separate entity in a database that holds booking information. As bookings are made or canceled, the system could increment or decrement this number as appropriate. This approach can cause scalability issues if a large number of attendees are trying to book seats in a short period of time (e.g., on the last day or so prior to the booking period closing).</p> </div> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/624a7580d3c8396741450020d463143a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_Tab\_1\_Storing\_as\_separate\_entity.svg" alt="Storing as separate entity" width="130" /></div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <p>The system could store information about bookings and cancellations as events held in an event store. It could then calculate the number of seats available by replaying these events. This approach can be more scalable due to the immutability of events. The system only needs to be able to read or append data to the event store. Event information about bookings and cancellations is never modified.</p> </div> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/dbd74d8f1665defc288b98391e32e5ee/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_Tab\_2\_Storing\_as\_events\_in\_event\_store.svg" alt="Storing as events in event store" width="130" /></div> </div> </div> </div> <p>The diagram below illustrates how you can implement the seat reservation subsystem of the conference management system using Event Sourcing. Let&rsquo;s overview this process more in detail and pay attention to the sequence of actions for reserving two seats.</p> <style><!-- .tab-wrapper { margin-bottom: 20px; } .tab-controls { overflow: hidden; background-color: #30b6dd; border-radius: 6px 6px 0 0; display: flex; } .tab-controls button:not(:last-child) { margin-right: 0px; } .tab-controls button { background-image: none; text-shadow: none; background-color: inherit;
