} } --></style> <script>// <!\[CDATA\[ $(".tab-wrapper").each(function () { const buttons = $(this).find(".tab-controls\_\_button"); const tabs = $(this).find(".tab-content"); if (tabs.length !== buttons.length) { $(this).html("<p style='text-align:center; color: red'>ERROR, UNEQUAL AMOUNT OF TABS AND BUTTONS</p>"); } else { tabs.eq(0).show(); buttons.each(function (index) { $(this).click(function () { buttons.each(function () { $(this).removeClass("active"); }); tabs.each(function () { $(this).hide(); }); $(this).addClass("active"); tabs.eq(index).show(); }); }); } }); // \]\]></script> <p></p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-14" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@8c19c5cef2d74d00927a0186d3b01834"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@8c19c5cef2d74d00927a0186d3b01834" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <p><em>Click on the hot spots to learn more.</em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 700px; width: 100%;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/dd137be99017630bc146e7b4e3b5c887/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6-3017\_Scema\_3.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-211"> <span class="hotspot-icon">1</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The user interface issues a command to reserve seats for two attendees. A separate command handler handles this command. A piece of logic decoupled from the user interface is responsible for handling requests posted as commands.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-212"> <span class="hotspot-icon">2</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>An aggregate containing information about all reservations is constructed by querying the events that describe bookings and cancellations. This aggregate is called <code>SeatAvailability</code>, and is contained within a domain model that exposes methods for querying and modifying the aggregate data.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-213"> <span class="hotspot-icon">3</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The command handler invokes a method exposed by the domain model to make the reservations.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-214"> <span class="hotspot-icon">4</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The <code>SeatAvailability</code> aggregate records an event containing the number of seats that were reserved. The next time the aggregate applies events, all the reservations will be used to compute how many seats remain.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-215"> <span class="hotspot-icon">5</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The system appends the new event to the list of events in the event store.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>If a user decides to cancel a seat, the system follows a similar process. However, in this case, the command handler issues a command that generates a seat cancellation event and appends it to the event store.</p> <p><em>If you want to know more about Event sourcing read <a href="https://martinfowler.com/eaaDev/EventSourcing.html" target="\_blank">here</a>.</em></p> <p><em>The benefits of Event Sourcing are summarized <a href="/assets/courseware/v1/577c336fd72ca84f861c043263e73918/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/L6\_Event\_Sourcing\_Benefits.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a>. </em></p> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-211 { left: 16%; top: 30%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-212 { left: 67.5%; top: 80%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-213 { left: 35%; top: 30%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-214 { left: 51%; top: 80%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-215 { left: 67.5%; top: 16%; } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-15" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@162959c5779d46dfb17a9ed347c1bf7e"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@162959c5779d46dfb17a9ed347c1bf7e" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Sharding Pattern</h3> <p>Dividing the data store into horizontal partitions or shards became convenient in a wide variety of use cases. Each shard has the same schema but holds its own distinct subset of the data. A shard is a kind of a data store since it can contain the data for many entities of different types. This shard is running on a server acting as a storage node. Now, let&rsquo;s overview the main aspects of the Sharding pattern.</p> <p><em>Click on the step-by-step interactivity to learn more about the Sharding pattern.</em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p><b>Context/Risk</b></p> <p>A data store hosted by a single server can be limited in one of the following ways:</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/90467549a7d1c57b31101835d65deba5/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_Step\_Context\_Risk.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 140px;" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <ul> <li><span>Storage space. The system will eventually reach a limit where increasing the storage capacity on a given server isn&rsquo;t easily achieved.</span></li> <li><span>Computing resources. A single server hosting the data store might not be sufficient to provide the necessary computing power in order to support this load, resulting in extended response times for users and frequent failures.</span></li> <li><span>Network bandwidth. The volume of network traffic might exceed the network&rsquo;s capacity used to connect to the server, which can result in failed requests.</span></li> <li><span>Geography. If the users are dispersed across different countries or regions, storing the entire application&rsquo;s data in a single data store might not be possible.</span></li> </ul> </div> </div> <p>The effects of some limitations can be postponed by scaling vertically and adding more disk capacity, processing power, memory, and network connections. However, it&rsquo;s likely only a temporary solution.</p> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/68bef48fe091e4eaa40a0170e988d52d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_Step\_Intention.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 140px;" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Intention</b></p> <p>Store data in the most effective way in terms of performance, cost, and location.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/295e7561c3d40feaa9c57e5d61c66e07/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_Step\_Solution.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 140px;" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Solution</b></p> <p>You can divide a data store into a set of horizontal partitions or shards. Doing this can improve scalability when storing and accessing large volumes of data. When dividing a data store up into shards, you must decide which data should be placed in each shard. Splitting the data in the way appropriate for the types of queries that the application performs is essential in order to ensure optimal performance and scalability.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-16" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@8959ddedcd194cd9b7871e8d8bdbd682"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@8959ddedcd194cd9b7871e8d8bdbd682" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Sharding Strategies</h3> <p>If you intend to divide a data store into shards, you should decide which data must be placed in each shard. Items aligned with a specific range defined by one or more data attributes usually comprise one shard. A shard key&mdash;sometimes called a partition key&mdash;is composed of these attributes. A shard key is typically static and based on changeable data. To choose a shard key and decide how to divide data across shards, you can use one of three commonly used strategies.</p> <p><em><span>Click on the dropdowns to overview these strategies.</span> </em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>The Lookup Strategy</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>In this strategy, the sharding logic implements a map that routes a request for data to the shard containing that data by using the shard key. In a multi-tenant application, all the tenant data might be stored together in a shard using the tenant ID as a shard key. Multiple tenants might share the same shard, but the data for a single tenant won&rsquo;t be spread across various shards. The figure illustrates sharding tenant data based on tenant IDs.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/406243b9ebdb2714217aa07b51760b40/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_Sharding\_diagram\_1.svg" style="width: 600px;" alt="image" /></p> <p>This strategy allows you to control how shards are configured and used. When data is being rebalanced, applying virtual shards weakens impact as new physical partitions may be added to even out the workload. You can modify the mapping between a virtual shard and the physical partitions that implement the shard without affecting the application code, which uses a shard key to store and retrieve data.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>The Range Strategy</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>In the range strategy, related items are grouped together in the same shard and ordered by a shard key. It&rsquo;s useful for applications that frequently retrieve sets of items using range queries (queries that return a set of data items for a shard key that falls within a given range). If an application regularly needs to find every order in a given month, this data could be retrieved more quickly if all orders for a chosen month are stored in date and time order in the same shard. If each order were stored in a different shard, you would need to perform a large number of point queries (queries that return a single data item) to fetch each of them individually.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/3932ebb6c25f2b35bb9dc17b39b93e3e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_Sharding\_diagram\_2\_.svg" style="width: 600px;" alt="image" /></p> <p>In the illustrated example, the shard key is a composite key containing the order month as its most significant element, followed by the order day and the time. When new orders are created, the data for orders is naturally sorted and added to a shard. This strategy allows you to schedule updates in a time zone based on the local load and demand pattern if users of the same region are in the same shard. However, ideal balancing between shards is not provided by the range strategy.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i>The Hash Strategy</button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>This strategy is aimed to reduce the chance of hotspots (shards that receive a disproportionate amount of load). It distributes the data across the shards so that a balance between each shard&rsquo;s size and the average load that each shard will encounter is achieved. The shard is computed to store an item based on a hash of one or more data attributes. The chosen hashing function distributes data evenly among the shards. The diagram illustrates sharding tenant data based on a hash of tenant IDs.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7a7a344c1018ed492150f79a7930918f/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_Sharding\_diagram\_3.svg" style="width: 600px;" alt="image" /></p> <p>This strategy provides an opportunity to have more even data and load distribution. Applying hash functions allows you to complete the request routing directly. A map shouldn&rsquo;t be maintained. Keep in mind that computing the hash may impose an additional overhead.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> <script>// <!\[CDATA\[ $(".dm-sc-collaps-wrapper").each(function () { $(this).find(".dm-collaps").click(function () { $(this).toggleClass("dm-collaps--active"); $(this).next().toggle(); }) }) // \]\]></script> <style><!-- p.bint { margin-bottom: 10px !important; } p.dm-pic3-about.dm-pic3-about2 { margin-bottom: 5px; margin-top: 0px !important; } .container-dm-pic3 { margin-bottom: 25px; } .dm-pic3 img { height: auto; margin: 10px 10px; } .dm-collaps-wrap { margin-bottom: 15px; box-shadow: 0 1px 2px 0 rgba(44, 47, 60, 0.06), 0 3px 10px 0 rgba(44, 47, 60, 0.09); border-radius: 6px; } .dm-collaps { background-color: #30b6dd; color: #fff; background-image: none; text-shadow: none; width: 100%; font-family: inherit; cursor: pointer; padding: 18px; width: 100%; border: none; border-radius: 6px 6px 0 0; text-align: left; outline: none; font-size: 15px; } .dm-collaps i.fa-angle-down { font-style: inherit; margin-right: 10px; } .dm-collaps--active i.fa-angle-down { transform: scaleY(-1); } button.dm-collaps--active, button.dm-collaps:hover, button.dm-collaps:focus, button.dm-collaps:active { background-color: #1f98bb; color: #fff; background-image: none; box-shadow: none; border: none; text-shadow: none; } .dm-collaps-content { padding: 0 18px; display: none; border-radius: 6px; overflow: hidden; background-color: #fff; } .dm-collaps-content p { margin-top: 10px; /\* margin-bottom: 100px; \*/ } .dm-picnorm { display: flex; align-items: center; } .dm-picnorm img { width: auto; max-height: 150px; margin-left: 10px; } @media only screen and (max-width: 980px) { .dm-picnorm { flex-direction: column; margin: 0 auto; } } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-17" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@ed47c4797f0e46539123c469c38481a7"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@ed47c4797f0e46539123c469c38481a7" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Sharding Tips</h3> <p>Now, when you became familiar with the main Sharding strategies, let&rsquo;s have a special look at the list of tips that can be helpful when applying the Sharding patterns. They include shard balancing, key uniqueness, reference data replication, referential integrity, and others.</p> <p><em>Click on the hot spots to receive the tips.</em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 800px; width: 100%;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/601b4ea4c84fb5d3bbfbb97107f0d21a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L6\_HOtSpots.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-111"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Complementing Other Partitioning Forms. </b>Vertical and functional forms of partitioning can be complemented by sharding. For example, a single shard may include entities partitioned vertically, and a functional partition can be implemented as multiple shards.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-112"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Shard Balancing. </b>Shards should be kept balanced to process a similar volume of I/O. It is required to rebalance the shards at regular intervals in order to ensure even distribution and diminish the chance of hotspots as data is inserted and deleted. Rebalancing operations can increase costs.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-113"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Stable Data for Shards Keys. </b>Changes in shard keys can result in moving the correspondent data item between shards, increasing the amount of work executed by update operations.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-114"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Key Uniqueness. </b>Shard keys must be unique.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-115"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Query Effectiveness/Complexity. </b>Try not to implement a sharding system that leads to applications dealing with a large number of queries joining data stored in different shards. Accessing a single shard is more effective than retrieving data from multiple shards.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-116"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Reference Data Replication. </b>Consider replicating reference data to all shards. If an operation retrieving data from a shard also references static or slow-moving data as a part of the same query, add this data to the shard.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-117"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Referential Integrity and Consistency. </b>Minimize operations that impact data in multiple shards as it can be hard to maintain referential integrity and consistency between shards.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>The Sharding pattern provides multiple benefits. You can add further shards running on additional storage nodes to scale the system. This way, the system can use off-the-shelf hardware instead of specialized and expensive computers for each storage node. You can reduce contention and improve performance by balancing the workload across shards. In the cloud, shards can be located physically close to the users that will access the data. Note that the Sharding pattern should be used when a data store will likely need to scale beyond the resources available to a single storage node or improve performance by reducing contention in a data store.</p> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-111 { left: 23%; top: 35%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-112 { left: 48%; top: 35%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-113 { left: 74%; top: 35%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-114 { left: 100%; top: 35%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-115 { left: 23%; top: 91%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-116 { left: 49%; top: 91%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-117 { left: 77%; top: 91%; } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-18" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@9effe12d22ed407d844721bdab62d2dd"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@9effe12d22ed407d844721bdab62d2dd" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Summary</h3> <p>In this lesson, you received detailed information about three primary performance and scalability patterns, learned their key characteristics, what can be achieved by applying them, and cases when using each of these patterns is recommended. <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-vertical" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="VerticalStudentView" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@e5e28afa34b64f6aa473676e2b4cb3cb" data-block-type="vertical"> <h2 class="hd hd-2 unit-title">L7: Architectural Patterns. Integration Patterns</h2> <div class="bookmark-button-wrapper"> <button class="bookmark-button " aria-pressed="false" data-bookmark-id="volodymyr\_kosmirak\_gmail\_com,block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@e5e28afa34b64f6aa473676e2b4cb3cb" data-bookmarks-api-url="/api/bookmarks/v1/bookmarks/"> </button> <div class="bookmark-tooltip">Bookmark</div> </div> <script> if ($("#seq\_content").length === 0) { $("#contentframe").context.documentElement.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; $(window).context.body.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; } </script> <div class="vert-mod"> <div class="vert vert-0" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@496b9ddbd78f44c3b611db9632dad0a5"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@496b9ddbd78f44c3b611db9632dad0a5" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Introduction</h3> <p>This lesson provides an introduction to the integration pattern as well as gives more detailed information about messaging systems and their components. Understanding of the integration styles, message concepts, and system management patterns can help guide solution architects toward employing practices that translate across any integration project regardless of the industry.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@22e2b1873970454e96705b4d2923cbcf"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@22e2b1873970454e96705b4d2923cbcf" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Integration Patterns</h3> <p>Integration aims to make component agnostic and usable quickly across the business, so it can be accessed and handled by its constituents. And in order to make that data usable even more quickly, integration patterns can be created to standardize the integration process.</p> <p>There are commonly used patterns in the integration category&mdash;the File Transfer, Shared database, Remote Procedure Invocation, and Messaging. The majority of the Messaging patterns are summarized below. The upcoming sections look at some of them in more detail.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the hot spots to learn more about them. </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 900px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/24894ce3b4e44d4eba5b33d9d4fb20b8/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Integration\_patterns\_diagram.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%; padding-top: 40px;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-1"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="text-align: left;"><b>Messaging patterns:</b> Message; Command Message; Document Message; Event Message; Request-Reply; Return Address; Correlation Identifier; Message Sequence; Message Expiration; Format Indicator.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-2"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p style="text-align: left;"><b>Message Routing: </b> Pipes-and-Filters; Message Router; Content-based Router; Message Filter; Dynamic Router; Recipient List; Splitter; Aggregator; Resequencer; Composed Msg. } }); }); }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-2" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@cd1fcca4fce34a0e87aff949a5903da7"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@cd1fcca4fce34a0e87aff949a5903da7" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Messaging As a Way of Applications' Integration</span></h3> <p>This lesson explains how to use <b>messaging</b> to integrate applications. <b>Messaging</b> is a technology that enables high-speed, asynchronous, program-to-program communication with reliable delivery. Programs communicate by sending packets of data called <b>messages</b> to each other.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the flip cards to learn about messaging process components. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ff2043d50dc34053da90fa1b0b7540fc/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3001\_Flip\_Channels.svg" style="height: 85px; padding-bottom: 9px; padding-top: 12px;" /> <p><strong>Channels</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Channels, also known as queues, are logical pathways that connect the programs and convey messages. A channel behaves like a collection or array of messages, but one that is magically shared across multiple computers and can be used concurrently by multiple applications.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/b555e97caafcb50e0c0f7a4be5106d82/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3002\_Flip\_Sender.svg" style="height: 100px;" /> <p><strong>Sender</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>A sender or producer is a program that sends a message by writing a message to a channel.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/a8d0b7de2ba10e7690ff301e27e24cc5/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3003\_Flip\_Receiver.svg" style="height: 100px;" /> <p><strong>Receiver</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>A receiver or consumer is a program that receives a message by reading (and deleting) it from a channel.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Messaging capabilities are typically provided by a separate software system called a messaging system or message-oriented middleware, which manages messaging in the way a database system manages data persistence.</p> <p>If you are wondering <b>why you should use messaging</b>, there are some reasons. Messaging is more immediate than File Transfer, better encapsulated than Shared Database, and more reliable than Remote Procedure Invocation. However, that's just the beginning of the advantages that can be gained using messaging.</p> <style><!-- p.dm2-cardsWrap-about.dm2-cardsWrap-about { margin-bottom: 5px; margin-top: 5px; } body.view-in-course div.container .course-wrapper { display: table; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <h3>Messaging Gateway</h3> <p><b>How to encapsulate access to the messaging system from the rest of the application?</b> Use a Messaging Gateway, a class that wraps messaging-specific method calls and exposes domain-specific methods to the application. The Messaging Gateway encapsulates messaging-specific code (e.g., the code required to send or receive a message) and separates it from the rest of the application code. This way, only the Messaging Gateway code knows about the messaging system; the rest of the application code does not.</p> </div> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/866185f2973fcd0f671ad8026fe01e51/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3004\_Messaging\_gateway.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 120px;" /></div> </div> <p>The Messaging Gateway provides a business function to the rest of the application in a way that it doesn't require the application to set such properties as <code>Message.MessageReadPropertyFilter.AppSpecific</code>. It is a gateway that exposes methods like <code>GetCreditScore</code> that allows you to accept strictly typed parameters as any other method. A Messaging Gateway is considered as a messaging-specific version of the more common Gateway pattern.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/dcd1332f5e9eb8398966e61dd387902b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_L7\_Messaging\_gateway.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 700px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p>Many Messaging Gateways send a message to another component and expect a reply. Such a Messaging Gateway can be implemented in two different ways: Blocking (Synchronous) Messaging Gateway and Event-Driven (Asynchronous) Messaging Gateway. Now, let's figure out some reasons to use this pattern.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the tabs to learn more about why to use Messaging Gateway.</span> </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">State Maintenance </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Testing </button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9c3063743294428df4b4691838862fac/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3005\_TAB\_State\_maintenance.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>The Messaging Gateway makes it easier for the application to maintain state if it allows the application to pass a reference to an arbitrary set of data to the request method. The Messaging Gateway will then pass this data back to the application with the callback. This way, the application has all the necessary data available when the asynchronous callback is invoked. This type of interaction is called ACT (Asynchronous Completion Token).</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/73d7ad8daa072ac1462d4c7b690d8b2a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3006\_TAB\_Testing.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>Messaging Gateways make great testing vehicles. Because all the nasty messaging code is wrapped behind a narrow, domain-specific interface, you can easily create an implementation of this interface. Simply separate interface and implementation and provide two implementations: one "real" implementation that accesses the messaging infrastructure and a "fake" implementation for testing purposes.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.tab-wrapper-about.tab-wrapper-about-2 { margin-bottom: 5px; }); }); } }); // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-4" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@b538dcd900744ba4ba81ec1bef6c76c9"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@b538dcd900744ba4ba81ec1bef6c76c9" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Request-Reply</h3> <p><strong>When an application sends a message, how can it get a response from the receiver?</strong> Send a pair of Request-Reply messages, each on its own channel. When two applications communicate via Messaging, the communication is one-way. In some cases, applications may want a two-way conversation.</p> <p>The Request-Reply integration pattern facilitates two-way communication by ensuring that a sender gets a response or reply from the receiver after sending a request message. This pattern sends a pair of Request-Reply messages, each on its own channel. Request-Reply has two participants.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the hot spots to learn more about these participants.</span> </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 600px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/8a6da51feda8ad15d3553b2e57a9b6e6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_L7\_Request-Reply\_.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-21"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Requestor. </b>Sends a request message and waits for a reply message.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-22"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Replier. </b>Receives the request message and responds with a reply message.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-23"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Request Channel. </b>The request channel can be a Point-to-Point Channel or a Publish-Subscribe Channel. The difference is whether the request should be broadcast to all interested parties or should only be processed by a single consumer.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-24"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Reply Channel. </b>The reply channel is almost always point-to-point because it usually makes no sense to broadcast replies&ndash;they should only be returned to the requestor.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>An <b>example</b> of using Request-Reply is SOAP messages. SOAP messages come in Request-Reply pairs. A SOAP request message indicates a service the sender wishes to invoke on the receiver, whereas a SOAP response message contains the result of the service invocation. The response message either contains a result value or a fault&mdash;the SOAP equivalent of an exception.</p> <p><em> You can also find some additional examples for using Request-Reply <a href="https://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/patterns/messaging/RequestReplyNetExample.html" target="\_blank">here</a>. </em></p> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-21 { left: 9.5%; top: 37.6%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-22 { left: 86.2%; top: 37.6%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-23 { left: 58.5%; top: -1%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-24 { left: 37%; top: 56%; } --></style> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-5" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@42de9b0844d848ed8b4736221b71b959"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@42de9b0844d848ed8b4736221b71b959" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Guaranteed Delivery</h3> <p><b>How can the sender make sure that a message will be delivered, even if the messaging system fails?</b> Use Guaranteed Delivery to make messages persistent so that they are not lost even if the messaging system crashes.</p> <p><em>Click on the video to explore more about Guaranteed Delivery. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;<a href="/assets/courseware/v1/52e7bdf018b51439c98e28b36604e700/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Lesson\_7.\_ASP\_SM5\_Architectural\_Patterns.\_Integration\_Patterns.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a> to download a text script to find out what you will learn.</em></p> <div style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.25%;"><iframe src="//videoportal.epam.com/video/iframe.html?video=xazrv1aG&amp;resolution=1920x1080#" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; top: 0; left: 0;" frameborder="0"></iframe></div> <p></p> <!-- <p>With Guaranteed Delivery, the messaging system uses a built-in data store to persist messages. Each computer has an installed messaging system and its own data store so that the messages can be stored locally. When the sender sends a message, the send operation does not complete successfully until the message is safely stored in the sender's data store. Subsequently, the message is not deleted from one data store until it is successfully forwarded to and stored in the next data store. In this way, once the sender successfully sends the message, it is always stored on disk on at least one computer until it is successfully delivered to and acknowledged by the receiver.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/8f5afd375adfe77e494b1fcd43729bca/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_L7\_Guaranteed\_delivery.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 700px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p>--> <p><span>Now, let's figure out when it is better to use or avoid this pattern. Persistence increases reliability but at the expense of performance. Thus, <b> if it's OK to lose messages when the messaging system crashes or is shut down, avoid using Guaranteed Delivery </b> so that messages will move through the messaging system faster. Let's overview the scenarios when you should consider using Guaranteed Delivery.</span></p> <p><span><em>Click on the dots to learn more about Guaranteed Delivery use-cases.</em></span></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/4466c499292cd2efa9a6653c25969a72/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3007\_dots\_High-traffic\_Scenarios.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>High-traffic Scenarios</h3> <p>Guaranteed Delivery can consume a large amount of disk space in high-traffic scenarios. If a producer generates hundreds or thousands of messages per second, then a network outage that lasts multiple hours could use up a huge amount of disk space. Because the network is unavailable, the messages have to be stored on the producing computer's local disk drive, which may not be designed to hold this much data. For these reasons, some messaging systems allow you to configure a retry timeout parameter that specifies how long messages are buffered inside the messaging system. In some high-traffic applications (e.g., streaming stock quotes to terminals), this timeout may have to be set to a short time span, for example, a few minutes.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/678315a6a47dfa095da6b33226c29acd/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3008\_dots\_Testing\_and\_Debugging.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Testing and Debugging</h3> <p>It can also be useful to turn off Guaranteed Delivery during testing and debugging. This makes it easy to purge all message channels by stopping and restarting the messaging server. Messages that are still queued up can make it very tedious to debug even simple messaging programs. <b>For example</b>, you may have a sender and a receiver connected by a Point-to-Point Channel. If a message is still stored on the channel, the receiver will process that message before any new message that the sender produces. This is a common debugging pitfall in asynchronous, guaranteed messaging. Many commercial messaging implementations also allow you to purge queues individually to allow a fresh restart during testing.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span>Now, let's figure out how this pattern can be applied in real-life examples. The first example describes the use of Guaranteed Delivery in a stock trading system; the second refers to the IBM WebSphere MQ, which is a family of message-oriented middleware products.</span></p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the dropdowns to explore examples.</span> </em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Example: Stock Trading </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/2b49d043265a3359f6736f7a2d9f8252/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3009\_drop\_Stock\_Trading.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>In a stock trading system, trade requests and trade confirmations should probably be sent with Guaranteed Delivery to help ensure that none are lost. Likewise, change-of-address announcements should probably be sent with Guaranteed Delivery. On the other hand, price updates probably do not require Guaranteed Delivery; losing some of them is not significant, and their frequency makes the overhead of Guaranteed Delivery prohibitive.</p> </div> </div> <p>The stock trading example says that some price-change subscribers may wish to be durable. If so, then perhaps the price-change channel should guarantee delivery as well. Yet other subscribers may not need to be durable nor want to suffer the overhead of Guaranteed Delivery. How can these different needs be met? The system may wish to implement two price-change channels, one with Guaranteed Delivery and another without. Only subscribers that require all updates should subscribe to the persistent channel, and their subscriptions should be durable. The publisher may wish to publish updates less frequently on the persistent channel because of its increased overhead.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Example: IBM WebSphere MQ </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/0f4d437d7fdc1331a54cff4da0013a22/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3010\_drop\_IBM\_WebSphere\_MQ.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>In WebSphere MQ, Guaranteed Delivery can be set on a per-channel basis or a per-message basis. If the channel is not persistent, the messages cannot be persistent. If the channel is persistent, the channel can be configured such that all messages sent on that channel are automatically persistent or such that an individual message can be sent persistently or non-persistently.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.dm-pic3-about.dm-pic3-about2 { margin-bottom: 5px; } .container-dm-pic3 { margin-bottom: 25px; } .dm-pic3 img { width: 180px; height: auto; margin: 10px 10px; } .dm-collaps-wrap { margin-bottom: 15px; box-shadow: 0 1px 2px 0 rgba(44, 47, 60, 0.06), 0 3px 10px 0 rgba(44, 47, 60, 0.09); border-radius: 6px; } .dm-collaps { background-color: #30b6dd; color: #fff; background-image: none; text-shadow: none; width: 100%; font-family: inherit; cursor: pointer; padding: 18px; width: 100%; border: none; border-radius: 6px 6px 0 0; text-align: left; outline: none; font-size: 15px; } .dm-collaps i.fa-angle-down { font-style: inherit; margin-right: 10px; } .dm-collaps--active i.fa-angle-down { transform: scaleY(-1); } button.dm-collaps--active, button.dm-collaps:hover, button.dm-collaps:focus, button.dm-collaps:active { background-color: #1f98bb; color: #fff; background-image: none; box-shadow: none; border: none; text-shadow: none; } .dm-collaps-content { padding: 0 18px; display: none; border-radius: 6px; overflow: hidden; background-color: #fff; } .dm-collaps-content p { margin-top: 5px; } .dm-collaps-content img { width: 75px; margin: 0 auto; } } --></style> <script>// <!\[CDATA\[ $(".dm-sc-collaps-wrapper").each(function () { $(this).find(".dm-collaps").click(function () { $(this).toggleClass("dm-collaps--active"); $(this).next().toggle(); }) }) // \]\]></script> <style><!-- :root { --main-color: #30b6dd; } .step { display: none; } .slider-linear-wrapper { margin: auto; padding: 20px; background-color: white; font-family: "Raleway", sans-serif; color: #33312E; border-radius: 0.2em; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar { width: 100%; list-style-type: none; display: flex; padding: 0; justify-content: center; margin-bottom: 3.5em; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar li.progress-bar\_\_dot { display: block; width: 0.6em; height: 0.6em; border-radius: 50%; border: 0.2em solid var(--main-color); background-color: white; cursor: pointer; transition: all 0.5s ease; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar li::before { display: none; } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar li.progress-bar\_\_dot.active { background-color: var(--main-color); } .slider-linear-wrapper .progress-bar li.progress-bar\_\_connector { display: block; width: 20%; max-width: 200px; height: 0.1em; background-color: var(--main-color); margin-top: 0.45em; } --></style> <script>// <!\[CDATA\[ $(".slider-linear-wrapper").each(function () { const circles = $(this).find(".progress-bar\_\_dot"); const step = $(this).find(".step"); if (step.length !== circles.length) { $(this).html("<p style='text-align:center; color: red'>ERROR, UNEQUAL AMOUNT OF SLIDES AND CIRCLES</p>"); } else { step.eq(0).show(); circles.each(function (index) { $(this).click(function () { circles.each(function () { $(this).removeClass("active"); }); step.each(function () { $(this).hide(); }); $(this).addClass("active"); step.eq(index).show(); }); }); } }); // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-6" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@3284a30b7b88487e85bb942e99ab377d"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@3284a30b7b88487e85bb942e99ab377d" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Aggregator</h3> <p><strong>How to combine the results of individual but related messages so that they can be processed as a whole?</strong> Use a stateful filter, an aggregator, to collect and store individual messages until a complete set of related messages has been received. Then, the aggregator publishes a single message distilled from the individual messages.</p> <p>The aggregator is a special filter that receives a stream of messages and identifies messages that are correlated. Once a complete set of messages has been received, the aggregator collects information from each correlated message and publishes a single, aggregated message to the output channel for further processing.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/155e1a4801ee93ee53fcc07cc2d5199a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/L7\_Aggregator.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 700px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p>There are a number of strategies for aggregator completeness conditions. The available strategies primarily depend on whether you know how many messages to expect or not. The aggregator could know the number of sub-messages to expect because it received a copy of the original composite message or because each individual message contains the total count. So, let's consider aggregation strategies.</p> <p><span><em>Scroll to learn more about these strategies.</em></span></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 10px;"><strong><span> "Wait for All" </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/02a63b3f42293a8bcb38072131782100/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3011\_scroll\_Wait\_for\_All.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 120px; height: 100px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;"><span> Wait until all responses are received. An incomplete order may not be meaningful. So, if not all items are received within a certain timeout period, an error condition should be raised by the aggregator. This approach may give you the best basis for decision-making but may also be the slowest and most brittle (and you need to know how many messages to expect). </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 10px;"><strong> "Time Out" </strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/0a5fe522d16b16d51763673279fef52d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3012\_scroll\_Time\_Out.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 120px; height: 100px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;"><span> Wait for a specified length of time for responses and then make a decision by evaluating those responses received within that time limit. If no responses are received, the system may report an exception or retry. This is useful if incoming responses are scored, and only the message with the highest score is used. This approach is common in "bidding" scenarios. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 10px;"><strong><span> "First Best" </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><br /><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/4d23768d4339e8ffddc4e9db7c86f4d8/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3013\_scroll\_First\_best.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 120px; height: 100px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;"><span> Wait only until the first (fastest) response is received and ignore all other responses. You should keep in mind that this approach is the fastest but ignores a lot of information. However, note that it may be practical in a bidding or quoting scenario where response time is critical. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 10px;"><strong><span> "Time Out with Override" </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ba41ed6332e12c3813922686196e82f3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3014\_scroll\_Time\_Out\_with\_Override.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 120px; height: 100px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;"><span> Wait for a specified amount of time or until a message with a preset minimum score has been received. In this scenario, you are willing to abort early if you find a very favorable response; otherwise, you keep on going until time is up. If no clear winner was found at that point, rank-ordering among all the messages received so far occurs. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 10px;"><strong><span> "External Event" </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f07353716ef0c89d233df75fbdf4dcf0/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3015\_scroll\_External\_Event.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 120px; height: 100px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;"><span> Sometimes the aggregation is concluded by the arrival of an external business event. E.g., in the financial industry, the end of the trading day may signal the end of an aggregation of incoming price quotes. The aggregator can listen for the Event Message on a special control channel or receive a specially formatted message that indicates the end of the aggregation. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 10px;"><strong><span> Select the "Best" Answer </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ceed48679c68c6f241e674e2fe867b24/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3016\_scroll\_Select\_the\_best\_answer.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 120px; height: 100px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;"><span> This approach assumes that there is a single best answer, e.g., the lowest bid for an identical item. The aggregator can make the decision and only pass the "best" message on. In real life, selection criteria are rarely this simple. E.g., the "best" bid for an item may depend on the time of delivery, the number of available items, whether the vendor is on the preferred vendor list, etc. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 10px;"><strong><span> Condense Data </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/8dd56e46f5715344e524f384c9ae9b8e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3017\_scroll\_Condense\_data.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 120px; height: 100px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;"><span> An Aggregator can be used to reduce message traffic from a high-traffic source. In these cases, it may make sense to compute an average of individual messages or add numeric fields from each message into a single message. This works best if each message represents a numeric value, for example, the number of orders received. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 10px;"><strong><span> Collect Data for Later Evaluation </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/137f645537fc1cc1b5644ab5561a7aac/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3018\_scroll\_Collect\_data\_for\_later\_evaluation.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 120px; height: 100px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin: 0;"><span> It is not always possible for an aggregator to make the decision of how to select the best answer. In those cases, it makes sense to use an Aggregator to collect the individual messages and combine them into a single message. This message may simply be a compilation of the individual's message data. The aggregation decision may be made later by a separate component. </span></p> </div> </div> </div> <p>In many instances, the aggregation strategy is driven by parameters. <b>For example</b>, a strategy that waits for a specified amount of time can be configured with the maximum wait time.</p> <p>Now, let's explore how aggregators can be useful in different aggregations. Let's consider a <b>Loan broker</b> as an <b>example</b>. An Aggregator can be used to select the best loan quote from the loan quote messages returned by the banks. The loan broker example uses an initialized Aggregator&mdash;the Recipient List informs the aggregator of the number of quote messages to expect.</p> <style><!-- body.view-in-course div.container .course-wrapper { display: table; } .dm-mySlides { min-width: 370px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px; padding: 10px; text-align: center; } .dm-mySlides p { text-align: center; } --></style> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-7" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@f4a4195ce60a4d55ae7ce81edb407dba"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@f4a4195ce60a4d55ae7ce81edb407dba" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Guaranteed Delivery and Aggregator Example</span></h3> <p>Let's figure out how an Aggregator can be used as Missing Message Detector. The system sends a message through a sequence of components, which are unfortunately quite unreliable. Even using Guaranteed Delivery will not correct this problem because, typically, the systems themselves fail after they consumed a message. Because the applications are not Transactional Clients, the message-in-progress is lost. Now, let's pay attention to the scheme below.<br /><br /></p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/25ef35019d4574cf08c345e3da770648/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3019\_schema1.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 600px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p><br />To help remedy this situation, an incoming is routed through two parallel paths: once through the required but unreliable components and once around the components using <b>Guaranteed Delivery</b>. An <b>Aggregator</b> recombines the messages from the two paths. Now, let's examine this example more specifically.</p> <p style="margin-bottom: 15px;"><em> Click on the step-by-step interactivity to explore the process shown in the scheme above. </em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c0be2f6ea38d72e9b9d3f55ad911aa47/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3020\_Step\_1.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 130px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>The aggregator uses a "Time Out with Override" completeness condition, which means that the aggregator completes if either the timeout is reached or the two associated messages have been received.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/94f1c9a0263288fd30c601df8b693cc4/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3021\_Step\_2.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 130px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>The aggregation algorithm depends on which condition is fulfilled first. If two messages are received, the processed message is passed on without modification. If the timeout event occurs, you know that one of the components failed and "ate" the message.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/48f47242d4da1415fe28bd4b217c98b6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3022\_Step\_3.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 130px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>As a result, you instruct the aggregator to publish an error message that alerts the operators that one of the components has failed. Unfortunately, the components have to be restarted manually, but a more sophisticated configuration could likely restart the component and re-send any lost messages. Unfortunately, the components have to be restarted manually, but a more sophisticated configuration could likely restart the component and re-send any lost messages.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <style><!-- .step-by-step-text .sbs-arrow-wrapper span { position: absolute; let sbsButtons = allStepBySteps\[y\].querySelectorAll('.step-by-step-button'); console.log(textBlocks) console.log(sbsButtons) for (let i = 0; i < sbsButtons.length; i++) { if (i === sbsButtons.length - 1) { let current = sbsButtons\[i\];
