} } } else { let current = sbsButtons\[i\]; sbsButtons\[i\].onclick = () => { $(textBlocks\[i + 1\]).slideToggle(500); $(current).toggleClass('step-by-step-button-flip'); } } } } }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-8" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e4a3368111814fa5b854223cd0a44c19"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@e4a3368111814fa5b854223cd0a44c19" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Content Enricher</h3> <p><strong>How to communicate with another system if the message originator does not have all the required data items available?</strong> Use a specialized transformer, a content enricher, to access an external data source in order to augment a message with missing information.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/72d2e4e527fbbcdfff8a3e55a3e40819/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_L7\_Content\_Enricher.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 550px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p>You should be aware that when sending messages from one system to another, it is common for the target system to require more information than the source system can provide.</p> <p><em>Click on the dots to learn more about content enricher.</em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ee6d56e81fee3bb0a5d9822fdef93c0f/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3023\_Dot\_1.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>For example</b>, incoming address messages may just contain the ZIP code because the designers felt that storing a redundant state code would be superfluous, or an order message sent by the order management system may just contain an order number, but you need to find the customer ID associated with that order, so you can pass it to the customer management system.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/63b8a5c1836b151f1adb1848f940f8f8/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3024\_Dot\_2.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>The Content Enricher uses information inside the incoming message (e.g., key fields) to retrieve data from an external source. After the Content Enricher retrieves the required data from the resource, it appends the data to the message. The original information from the incoming message may be carried over into the resulting message or may no longer be needed, depending on the specific needs of the receiving application.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-9" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@cc4d6fd92f364b788152a9b00f9e30af"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@cc4d6fd92f364b788152a9b00f9e30af" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Content Enricher Examples</span></h3> <p>Let's consider the following example. A hospital scheduling system publishes a message announcing that the patient has completed a doctor's visit. The message contains the patient's first name, his or her patient ID, and the date of the visit. In order for the accounting system to log this visit and inform the insurance company, it requires the full patient name, the insurance carrier, and the patient's social security number. However, the scheduling system does not store this information; it is contained in the customer care system. There are three options, as described below.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the tabs to overview these options. </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">Replicate Data </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Request Data from the Customer Care System </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Have Customer Care System Transform Msg </button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/4a4c0128aefab647421326a2f487c4a3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3025\_Tab\_Replicate\_Data.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>The scheduling system can be modified so it can store additional information. When the customer's information changes in the customer care system, the changes need to be replicated to the scheduling system. The scheduling system can now send a message that includes all required information. Unfortunately, this approach requires a modification to the scheduling system's internal structure. In most cases, the scheduling system is a packaged application and may not allow this type of modification. Also, even if the scheduling system is customizable, you need to consider that you are making a change to the system based on the specific needs of another system. For example, if you also want to send a letter to the patient confirming the visit, you have to change the scheduling system again to accommodate the customer's mailing address.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/73a9f6d2a3745eb01b0bb9e44de065c5/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3026\_Tab\_Request\_data\_from\_customer\_care\_system.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>The scheduling system could request the SSN and carrier data from the customer care system just before it is sending the "Doctor Visit" message. This solves the first problem&mdash;you no longer have to modify the storage of the scheduling system. However, the scheduling system needs to know that the SSN and carrier information is required in order to notify the accounting system. Therefore, the semantics of the message is more similar to "Notify Insurance" than "Doctor Visit". In a loosely coupled system, you rather send an event message and let the other systems decide what to do. In addition, this solution couples the scheduling system more tightly to the customer care system. This ties the scheduling system to both the accounting system and the customer care system. This type of coupling is undesirable because it leads to brittle integration solutions.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c2ea9971ccabb0b36faf63fbf090d12d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3027\_Tab\_Have\_customer\_care\_system\_transform\_msg.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>The message can be sent to the customer care system first instead of the accounting system. The customer care system can then fetch all the required information and send a message with all the required data to the accounting system. This decouples the scheduling system nicely from the subsequent flow of the message. However, now you implement the business rule that the insurance company receives a bill after the patient visits the doctor inside the customer care system. This requires modifying the logic inside the customer care system. If the customer care system is a packaged application, this modification may be impossible. Even if it is implemented, the customer care system is now indirectly responsible for sending bill messages. If some of the fields have to be retrieved from other systems, it is the same situation as in the beginning.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-10" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@drag-and-drop-v2+block@f240d2b934dd4e6982ae5ce0030b466a"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-drag-and-drop-v2" data-graded="True" data-has-score="True" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="DragAndDropBlock" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@drag-and-drop-v2+block@f240d2b934dd4e6982ae5ce0030b466a" data-block-type="drag-and-drop-v2"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"show\_problem\_header": false, "url\_name": "f240d2b934dd4e6982ae5ce0030b466a", "is\_drag\_disabled": false, "graded": true, "title": "Test Your Knowledge", "display\_zone\_labels": false, "weighted\_max\_score": 0.0, "max\_items\_per\_zone": null, "problem\_text": "\\u003cp\\u003e\\u003cem\\u003eThis is a non-graded quiz. data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@d8f8e8f43b9045f2b080e6110ade8922"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@d8f8e8f43b9045f2b080e6110ade8922" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <p>Now, let's figure out how to apply a Content Enricher to this use-case. You can <b>insert the Content Enricher</b> to retrieve the additional data from the customer care system, as shown in the scheme below.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/e90644168da2891f9af84d7021f5a407/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3031\_schema2.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 640px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p>This way, the scheduling system is nicely decoupled from having to deal with insurance information or the customer care system. All it has to do is publish the "Doctor Visit" message. The Content Enricher component takes care of retrieving the required data. The accounting system also remains independent of the customer care system.</p> <p>If you want to receive some more examples, let's have a look at one additional use-case for the Content Enricher.</p> <p><em> Click on the dropdown to discover additional use-case. </em></p> <!--<p class="dropotab-wrapper-about dropotab-wrapper-about2"><em> Click on the droptabs to discover additional use-cases. </em></p> <div class="dropotab-wrapper"> <div class="tab"><button class="tablinks1" data-open-id="functions\_small\_tab1"><i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Communicate with External Parties </button> <button class="tablinks1" data-open-id="functions\_small\_tab2"><i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Remove Data or Simplify Message Structure </button></div> <div id="functions\_small\_tab1" class="tabcontent"> <p></p> <p>A Content Enricher is also commonly used <b>when communicating with external parties that require messages to be compliant with a specific message standard</b>. Most of these standards require large messages with a long list of data. You can usually simplify your internal operations significantly if you keep internal messages as simple as possible and then use the Content Enricher to add the missing fields whenever you send a message outside of the organization. Likewise, you can use a Content Filter to strip unnecessary information from incoming messages (see the scheme below).</p> <img src="/assets/courseware/v1/407eab00aa5908f319c0fa4a595f8814/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3032\_schema3.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 420px; margin: 15px auto;" /></div> <div id="functions\_small\_tab2" class="tabcontent"> <p></p> <p>A Content Filter is also useful to <b>remove unimportant data or simplify the structure of the message</b>. Often times, messages are represented as tree structures. Many messages originating from external systems or packaged applications contain many levels of nested, repeating groups because they are modeled after generic, normalized database structures. Frequently, known constraints and assumptions make this level of nesting superfluous, and a Content Filter can be used to "flatten" the hierarchy into a simple list of elements that can be more easily understood and processed by other systems.</p> <img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c12e3546d218064198c68cf35ecae203/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3033\_schema4.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 362px; margin: 15px auto;" /><br /> <p></p> </div> </div>--> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Communicate with External Parties </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>A Content Enricher is also commonly used <b>when communicating with external parties that require messages to be compliant with a specific message standard</b>. Most of these standards require large messages with a long list of data. You can usually simplify your internal operations significantly if you keep internal messages as simple as possible and then use the Content Enricher to add the missing fields whenever you send a message outside of the organization. When retrieving a message from a message channel, a message recipient neither know nor care which application sent the message to the channel. The message doesn't refer to any specific sender, and according to the definition, it is considered as self-contained. This fact is known as an architectural strength of message-based systems.</p> <p><em> Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one. </em></p> <div class="article\_wrapper\_game"> <div class="pieces" id="piece-1" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5e8e4d8a99fcc813bfe9d2278f0bdfef/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3035\_Puzzle\_1-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-2" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/08a3d41e6f8d6f8d2c9576513d7a09b2/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3035\_Puzzle\_2-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-3" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/c6a3d85b5b247b904730934cbc4758a0/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3035\_Puzzle\_3-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-4" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/b9d1dd26ff8a65ef09d5b0899c3f6111/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3035\_Puzzle\_4-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-5" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/7e982de9db8c79613bba52321f243212/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3035\_Puzzle\_5-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-6" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/e164f7d8d217b6dad575b62ced00e5b5/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L7\_3035\_Puzzle\_6-01.svg');"></div> </div> <div class="image-game-result-container"><button class="play-again-button"> Play again </button> <div class="moves\_amount"></div> </div> <p>However, one and the same property may complicate the process of debugging and analyzing dependencies. Is it possible to analyze the effect of a change in the message format if you are not sure where a message goes, and, moreover, is it hard to fix a problem with the message if you don't know which application issued a message? The list of all components that the message passed through is included in the Message History. The originator and each component that handles the message adds one entry to the list. The Message History should be included in the message header as it comprises system-specific control information. If you keep this information in the header, the message body, which contains application-specific data, will be separated from it. Now, let's pay attention to the <strong>example</strong>.</p> <!--<p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the dropdown to receive an example.</span> </em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> TIBCO ActiveEnterprise </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div>--> <div style="display: flex; align-items: center; margin-bottom: 25px;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/46501863c81acd03aa940197775c00fd/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/tibco-software-official-logo.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 150px; max-width: 30%; flex-grow: 0; flex-shrink: 0;" /> <div style="padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Many EAI integration suites include support for a Message History. For example, the message header of every ActiveEnterprise message includes a tracking field that maintains a list of all components through which the message has passed. In this context, it is important to note that a TIBCO ActiveEnterprise component assigns outgoing messages the same message ID as the consumed message. This makes tracking of messages through multiple components easier, but it also means that the message ID is not a system-wide unique property because multiple individual messages share the same ID.</p> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> <p><em>If you know to read more about integration patterns, pay attention to this <a href="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/vaquarkhan/vaquarkhan/master/integration%20design%20pattern/Addison%20Wesley%20-%20Enterprise%20Integration%20Patterns%20-%20Designing%2C%20Building%20And%20Deploying%20Messaging%20Solutions%20-%20With%20Notes.pdf" target="\_blank">book</a>.</em></p> <style><!-- .article\_wrapper\_game { width: calc(var(--game-pieces-width) \* 3); <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-vertical" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="VerticalStudentView" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@3e7fbfd7d3f74d4b8f162cf4abf5a104" data-block-type="vertical"> <h2 class="hd hd-2 unit-title">L8: Architectural Patterns. Fault Tolerance Patterns</h2> <div class="bookmark-button-wrapper"> <button class="bookmark-button " aria-pressed="false" data-bookmark-id="volodymyr\_kosmirak\_gmail\_com,block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@3e7fbfd7d3f74d4b8f162cf4abf5a104" data-bookmarks-api-url="/api/bookmarks/v1/bookmarks/"> </button> <div class="bookmark-tooltip">Bookmark</div> </div> <script> if ($("#seq\_content").length === 0) { $("#contentframe").context.documentElement.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; $(window).context.body.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; } </script> <div class="vert-mod"> <div class="vert vert-0" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@f7f87e92b7034899a98c3f7706561f62"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@f7f87e92b7034899a98c3f7706561f62" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Introduction</h3> <p>This lesson will cover the fault tolerance patterns in microservices. You will learn the definition of fault tolerance and get acquainted with an important redundancy concept, its types, and methods. You will also become familiar with the algorithms that can be applied to prevent errors and manage system failures if they occur. You will learn how the isolation patterns help not to let faults in one part of a solution to take the entire system down.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .base\_image\_container { width: 100% !important; height: 100% !important; } .base\_image\_container img\[alt="Drop target image"\] { width: 100% !important; } --></style> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@0f55f7d6619a491a8e1acdf1d1f4123c"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@0f55f7d6619a491a8e1acdf1d1f4123c" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Fault Tolerance Definition</h3> <p>Let&rsquo;s start with a definition of &ldquo;Fault Tolerance&rdquo;. According to Wikipedia, &ldquo;Fault tolerance is the <strong>property</strong> that enables a system to continue operating properly in the event of the <strong>failure</strong> of some (one or more faults within) of its components. A fault-tolerant design enables a system to continue its intended operation, possibly at a reduced level, rather than failing completed, when some part of the system fails.&rdquo;</p> <p></p> <div id="gtx-trans" style="position: absolute; left: 643px; top: 62px;"> <div class="gtx-trans-icon"></div> </div> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-2" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@0e408c3809d043a5a8e3e9c01331e841"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@0e408c3809d043a5a8e3e9c01331e841" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Error Life Cycle</h3> <p>Several things can be done during the design of the software process to support fault-tolerant operation and a variety of fault-tolerant patterns that cover all the stages of the error lifecycle. The following sections describe just some of them.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/27817b8a441c022233b149bc72d11bec/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Error\_life\_cycle.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 750px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-3" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@efc0461466984ff08110b8a05b094b1b"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@efc0461466984ff08110b8a05b094b1b" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Redundancy Overview</h3> <p>Software poses some particular challenges and also provides new opportunities to exploit redundancy. <b>For example</b>, while simple replication of components can handle some classes of production faults typical of hardware design, it cannot deal with many failures that derive from the development and integration problems that often occur in software systems. On the other hand, software systems are amenable to various redundancy forms not found in hardware systems.</p> <p>Redundancy is the duplication of critical components or functions of a system aimed to increase its reliability.</p> <p style="margin-bottom: 15px;"><em>Click on the step-by-step interactivity to overview the process of using redundancy.</em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/df72628f4c3d9e6c17d0011f3554d620/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_steps\_Context\_Risk.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Context/Risk</b></p> <p>In case of errors, the system, which is composed of many software and hardware components, can be unavailable.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/15b4bde49a2113a4245c8f0ca4858fb6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_steps\_Intention.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Intention</b></p> <p>Reduce the amount of time between error detection and the resumption of normal operation after error recovery.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/5c4fa58047b4fbd2182438b2bc0241fa/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_steps\_Solution.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Solution</b></p> <ul> <li>Introduce redundancy in your system</li> <li>Redundancy can be spatial, temporal, and informational <ul> <li>Spatial redundancy can be Active-Active, Active-Passive, N+1 <ul> <li>In Active-Passive mode, the standby can be hot, warm, or cold</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> </ul> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <p>Redundant components can be either triggered preventively to avoid failures, or exploited reactively in response to failures. In the second case, the system must at a minimum detect a failure, and therefore decide how to exploit the redundancy of the system to cope with the failure. The component of the system that makes these decisions is called the adjudicator.</p> <p><span>From the <b>Software Architecture viewpoint</b>, redundancy can be introduced either at the intra- or inter-component level. When introduced at the intra-component level, redundancy does not alter the structure of the connections between components, but only the single components. This is <b>the case for example</b> of wrappers that filter component interactions, robust data structures that introduce redundancy at the data structure level to handle data related faults, and automatic workarounds that exploit redundancy that is implicitly present in the program. When introduced at the <b>inter-component level</b>, you can recognize a few recurrent patterns.</span></p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the hot spots to overview these patterns.</span> </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 1200px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/c50c9f7275461e96e03c3badb1af27ee/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_hotspots\_\_1\_.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-1"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Parallel evaluation. </b>In the parallel evaluation pattern, an adjudicator evaluates the results of several alternative implementations that are executed in parallel. The adjudicator is often a simple voting mechanism that identifies failures. This is <b>the case for example</b> of N-version programming that runs N different versions with the same input configuration.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-2"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Parallel selection. </b>In the parallel selection pattern, the adjudicator is active at the end of each program executed in parallel to validate the result and disable failing components. The pattern is implemented in self-checking programming.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-3"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Sequential Alternative. </b>In the sequential alternative pattern, alternative programs are activated when adjudicators detect failures. This pattern is implemented by recovery blocks.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>As was already mentioned, there are several types of redundancy. They refer to spatial, temporal, and informational redundancy. Now, let&rsquo;s overview these types more specifically and learn about each of them.</p> <p><em> Click on the video to learn more about redundancy types. Alternatively, you may click <a href="/assets/courseware/v1/e163164934a7743f49e10b83c2690526/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Lesson\_8.\_ASP\_SM5\_Architectural\_Patterns.\_Fault\_Tolerance\_Patterns.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a> to download a text script to find out what you will learn. </em></p> <div style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.25%;"><iframe src="https://videoportal.epam.com/video/iframe.html?video=6RnvP2Rr&amp;resolution=1920x1080#" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; top: 0; left: 0;" frameborder="0"></iframe></div> <p></p> <p></p> <p><em>If you want to know more about redundancy, examine this <a href="https://software.imdea.org/~alessandra.gorla/papers/Carzaniga-Redundancy-ADS09.pdf" target="\_blank">resource</a>.</em></p> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-1 { left: 1%; $(current).toggleClass('step-by-step-button-flip'); } } } } }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-4" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@3d5c87826c1a4b0fa41a528a607ab9f0"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@3d5c87826c1a4b0fa41a528a607ab9f0" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Spatial Redundancy Methods</h3> <p>After getting acquainted with key types of redundancy, let&rsquo;s move to the methods applicable to spatial redundancy. Let&rsquo;s explore the three most common techniques, which include Active-Active, Active-Passive, and N+M redundancy.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the dropdowns to learn more about spatial redundancy methods. </em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Active-Active </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <div style="display: flex; align-items: center; margin-bottom: 25px;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/912fedc75f9a75bdbf6eb3fce2ed49ec/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_Dropdown\_1\_Active\_active.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 140px; max-width: 30%; flex-grow: 0; flex-shrink: 0;" /> <div style="padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Active-Active method provides totally redundant units of mitigation for critical functionality. At any given time, both of the elements are active and load sharing. However, either of the elements is capable of processing the entire load. Active-Active contributes the fastest recovery, but it also has a high cost because there is much more capability in the system than needed for an ordinary workload. Active-Active implies a pairing between the two active units.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Active-Passive </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <div style="display: flex; align-items: center; margin-bottom: 25px;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/905799a7c9f59620e2d98a571d0a262c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_Dropdown\_2\_Active\_Standby.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 140px; max-width: 30%; flex-grow: 0; flex-shrink: 0;" /> <div style="padding-left: 20px;"> <p>When in an Active-Passive situation, the standby element is again paired with the active one. It does not perform useful work, meaning that the same resources are required as in the Active-Active situation, but the standby is idle during the normal operation. If you have chosen a redundancy regime, it might greatly affect the speed of switching. When redundant elements are &ldquo;hot&rdquo; standbys, the switchover can be very fast with minimum outage of the main application. If the standby element is &ldquo;warm&rdquo;, it will need time to to the same application state. Checkpoints will assist in getting there faster. When the standby is considered &ldquo;cold&rdquo;, it should be started from an inactive state, which requires additional time. You can treat it as a warm standby once it starts.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> N+1 (Generally N+M) </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <div style="display: flex; align-items: center; margin-bottom: 25px;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/79b48a2c892fcf10405bc2597c4093b7/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_Dropdown\_3\_N\_1\_\_Generally\_N\_M\_.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 150px; max-width: 30%; flex-grow: 0; flex-shrink: 0;" /> <div style="padding-left: 20px;"> <p>In situations where a one-to-one relationship, such as described by the previous two methods, is too expensive, N+M Redundancy is a useful technique. In this configuration, there are N active elements processing the workload of the system. There are also M redundant standby elements in the system, ready to assume control when a failure occurs in any of the N.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.dm-pic3-about.dm-pic3-about2 { margin-bottom: 5px; A special case of heartbeat is when the process being monitored periodically resets the watchdog timer in its monitor to prevent it from expiring and thus signaling a fault. For systems where scalability is a concern, transport and processing overhead can be reduced by piggybacking heartbeat messages onto other control messages exchanged between the process monitored and the distributed system controller. The big difference between heartbeat and ping/echo is who holds the responsibility for initiating a health check: the monitor or the component itself.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the flip cards to learn more about the heartbeat pattern. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ff9fc0159fac6465bdb72a4f3684fc7b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_Flip\_card\_1\_Context\_Risk.svg" style="height: 135px; color: #ccc;" class="flip-arrow">&rsaquo;</div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/8278f129af9e156ae952cb9bb68aea21/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_Flip\_card\_3\_Solution.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Solution</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>The health reports, or heartbeats, should occur at regular intervals</li> <li>During busy periods the realistic threshold is very important to reduce the unnecessary overhead that is draining processing and messaging bandwidth from real work</li> <li>Can be from the monitor to monitored task, or vice versa</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- @media only screen and (max-width: 686px) { .flip-arrow { display: none; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <h3>Leaky Bucket Counter</h3> <p>The leaky bucket is an algorithm based on how a bucket with a leak will overflow if either the average rate at which water is poured in exceeds the rate at which the bucket leaks or if more water than the capacity of the bucket is poured in all at once and how the water leaks from the bucket at an (almost) constant rate.</p> <p><span>The gif shows the general principles of a leaky bucket counter. Error reports fill the bucket, while an allowable number of errors is deducted from the bucket constantly as it leaks. If the rate at which the bucket fills is larger than the leaking rate, an error is triggered.</span></p> </div> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c08bc78229a74e392254ccc64d71aa8d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_gif2.gif" alt="some image" style="width: 120px;" /></span></div> </div> <p><span>Let&rsquo;s figure out how this algorithm can be applied for error preventions and managing system failures.</span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 15px;"><span><em>Click on the step-by-step interactivity to overview the process of leaky bucket counter defining.</em></span></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/47191eb7e76795d3e9af9e336f2cd4c4/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_step\_1\_Context\_Risk.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Context/Risk</b></p> <p>Your system is intended to recognize and correct errors automatically. Not all errors are so critical that their first occurrence stimulates error processing.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1c76ae3676357d2e9b649ae6907789b9/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_step\_2\_Intention.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Intention</b></p> <p>You need to know if an error is transient or intermittent.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/eeea0a44a44215f2dcfde452ab2468c5/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_step\_3\_Solution.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Solution</b></p> <p>You need to define your leaky bucket counter</p> <ul> <li>Initial value at system start-up</li> <li>Incrementing when a specified issue occurs</li> <li>Decrementing over a specified period (but never less than initial value)</li> <li>If exceeding a predetermined upper threshold, handle the error as permanent</li> </ul> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <p><span>A leaky bucket counter can be used (but is not limited to these use-cases) in traffic shaping or traffic policing. Now, let&rsquo;s pay attention to some real examples and use-cases which require the leaky bucket counter implementation.</span></p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the tabs to overview examples for using leaky bucket counter.</span> </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">1A/1B processor systems </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Network device </button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/78aa0a315bbbf9cd41746b41f3676d21/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_using\_Leaky\_bucket\_counter\_Dot\_1.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 160px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>The example from 1A/1B processor systems in <b>AT&amp;T telecommunication products</b> is as follows: As memory words (dynamic RAM) got weak, the memory module would generate a parity error trap. Examples include both 1A processor dynamic RAM and 1B processor static RAM. The counter is decremented for each fault and incremented periodically. There are different initial values and leak rates for different subsystems: e.g., it is a half-hour for the 1A memory subsystem. The 1A dynamic RAM strategy specifies that the first failure in a store causes the store to be taken out of service, diagnosed, and then automatically restored to service. On the second, third, and fourth failure you just leave it in service. For the fifth episode within the timing window, take the unit out of service, diagnose it, and leave it out.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/a4a6caa275fef47aea03f3a0f07a62d8/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_using\_Leaky\_bucket\_counter\_Dot\_2.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 130px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>A leaky bucket counter is used in the <b>network device with traffic shaping functions</b>. A network device with bandwidth usage control functions uses a leaky bucket algorithm to provide a traffic service conforming to given user parameters. A <b>leaky bucket counter</b> produces a new leaky-bucket (LB) count at predetermined cell slot intervals by adding an output rate parameter to the previous count and then by subtracting therefrom a full rate parameter if a cell output request signal is active. An upper limit calculator determines an upper limit for such a limit, thereby producing a modified LB count. When the modified LB count from the count modifier equals or exceeds an output reference value, a comparator activates an output timing signal, allowing transmission of a pending cell in a buffer.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.tab-wrapper-about.tab-wrapper-about-2 { margin-bottom: 5px; }); }); } }); // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-7" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@98b81b7a837b4c2da22ff4eb0b8c9075"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@98b81b7a837b4c2da22ff4eb0b8c9075" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Voting</h3> <p>Voting was briefly introduced in the<em> Quality Attributes submodule, <a href="https://msdp.elearn.epam.com/courses/course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2020/courseware/10b4674d146c4053ac6a98a1140ab92c/9670de1a4b454f378007256abb8bc368/6?activate\_block\_id=block-v1%3AMSDP%2BSA1.0%2B2020%2Btype%40vertical%2Bblock%40b7baa86b6eee4c83976280508e7bda69" target="\_blank">Lesson Reliability</a></em>. However, in order to build a more comprehensive view, let&rsquo;s observe how this pattern works more deeply. This pattern prevents a single component&rsquo;s failure from causing a failure of a complete system.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the hot spots to learn more about the voting pattern.</span><br /><br /> </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 575px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/c61382c982ea3106a1e91a3a3f1c7f90/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_scheme.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 90%; width: 90%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-21"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Components. </b>The components are replicated to perform the same operation in parallel.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-22"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p><b>Voter. </b>The N produced results are compared by a majority-voting system (a voter) in order to determine the correct result. The system functions correctly as long as the majority of components are fault-free.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-23"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The outputs of N components are processed by a majority voter that can mask (N &ndash; 1)/2 faults.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>In order to make majority voting possible, N is selected to be odd. In the basic case, N is selected to three, then a fault of one component can be masked. Now, let&rsquo;s figure out some additional aspects of this pattern applying.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the flip cards to see the main aspects. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/2e67cdcd2aa93100277a83c0638ae5e1/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_how\_to\_use\_Voting\_pattern\_Flip\_card\_1\_Context\_Risk.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Context/Risk</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>There is a case when redundancy provides multiple answers, and a need to decide what answer should be used.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div style="font-size: 120px; color: #ccc;" class="flip-arrow">&rsaquo;</div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/781d3e9ef96f07efd356e2da03babeaa/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_how\_to\_use\_Voting\_pattern\_Flip\_card\_2\_Intention.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Intention</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Arbitrate the results from the redundant components.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div style="font-size: 120px; color: #ccc;" class="flip-arrow">&rsaquo;</div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/bccbb4e8af519f671d15424c4220dd5d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_how\_to\_use\_Voting\_pattern\_Flip\_card\_3\_Solution.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Solution</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>Devise a voting strategy: <ul> <li>Majority vote (uneven node number)</li> <li>Generalized median voting &ndash; select a result that is the median by removing extremes</li> <li>Formalized plurality voting &ndash; divide results into partitions, choose random from the largest partition</li> </ul> </li> <li>In case of any disagreement, treat the element that loses the vote as erroneous</li> <li>Make sure you can trust the entity taking the vote (triple-mode redundancy)</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-21 { left: 45.2%; top: 41.4%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-22 { left: 73.1%; top: 41.4%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-23 { left: 95.8%; top: 41.4%; } --></style> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-8" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@bf18b52b1e22464cbb92a51361e4c616"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@bf18b52b1e22464cbb92a51361e4c616" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Isolation Patterns</h3> <p>The general goal of any isolation pattern is to avoid faults in one part of a solution to take the entire system down. Splitting the system into parts that are isolated from each other helps to avoid cascade failures. The most well-known patterns of this type are bulkheads, which connect elements into a &ldquo;unit of failure&rdquo; and loose coupling characterized by asynchronous communication and complete isolation.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/44277af8ff3f55e717b42f5aae7a5911/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/sa\_S5\_L8\_gif3.gif" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 600px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p><span>A ship is split into multiple small compartments using bulkheads. Bulkheads are used to seal parts of the ship to prevent the entire ship from sinking in case of a flood. Similarly, failures should be expected when you&rsquo;re designing software. Let&rsquo;s consider the bulkhead pattern by focusing on the example.</span></p> <p><span>In the <b>example</b> below, the bulkhead pattern is applied to a database cache. In the non-partitioned database cache, the failure of the cache spreads to the services interacting directly with the database, leading to an application failure. But in the partitioned example, the partition for <strong>service C</strong> has failed independently, resulting in the failure of <strong>service C</strong> without immediately causing failure in the other two services.</span></p> <p><span><em>Swipe the illustration to the&nbsp;right to see the non-partitioned database cache and to the&nbsp;left to see the way of bulkhead pattern applying.</em></span></p> <div class="swipe-m-wrapper"> <div class="swipe-m-container"> <div class="swipe-m-inner" style="width: 100%; max-width: 760px;"> <div class="comparison-m-wrapper"> <div class="comparison-m-swipe"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/d162a91ae799c73282ab2426f2021e30/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_swipe\_scheme\_right.svg" alt="img2" style="background-color: #fff;" /> <div class="resize-m-swipe"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/79679de1fc7bce7a41cda8034945e1f2/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_swipe\_scheme\_left.svg" alt="img1" style="background-color: #fff;" /></div> <div class="divider-m-swipe"> <div class="img-comp-slider"></div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>While useful for preventing catastrophic failures, the bulkhead pattern does add complexity to your application. You should be careful when applying this pattern and other ones in the isolation group. Let&rsquo;s figure out when isolation patterns should be used and when they should be avoided.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the flip cards to learn more about good and bad isolation pattern use-cases. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/bf59d67044e8cd713a6b29cab1ce86bb/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_Flip\_card\_1\_Use\_Isolation\_pattern.svg" style="height: 150px;" /> <p><strong><br />Use Isolation Pattern</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>To isolate resources used to consume a set of backend services, especially if the application can provide some level of functionality even when one of the services is not responding.</li> <li>To isolate critical consumers from standard consumers.</li> <li>To protect the application from cascading failures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><br /><br /><img <p><strong>Avoid isolation Pattern</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>This pattern may not be suitable when less efficient use of resources may not be acceptable in the project.</li> <li>It is also not suitable when the added complexity is unnecessary.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .swipe-m-wrapper { user-select: none; } .swipe-m-wrapper { position: relative; margin: 0; padding: 0; data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@ade72402bd0f4b30a1914e278e885a36"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@ade72402bd0f4b30a1914e278e885a36" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Circuit Breaker</h3> <p>This pattern describes how to safely connect different parts of the system so that failures do not spread uncontrollably across them. Its origin lies in electrical engineering: in order to protect electrical circuits from each other and introduce decoupled failure domains, a technique was established of breaking the connection when the transmitted power exceeds a given threshold. <span>Let&rsquo;s discover what problems this pattern is aimed to solve by viewing an <strong>example</strong>.</span></p> <p><span><em>Click on the dots to overview the example.</em></span></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1464a1443594968ddba6588ae4aa3889/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_problems\_Circuit\_breaker\_is\_aimed\_to\_solve\_by\_considering\_an\_example\_dot\_1.svg" style="width: 190px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Assume you are making a service request to buy 100 shares of Microsoft. As the service consumer, the last thing you want to do is time out the request just when the service has successfully placed the trade and is about to give you your order confirmation number. You can try to resubmit the trade, but you have to add complexity into your service to determine if this is a new trade or a duplicate. Since you don&rsquo;t have a confirmation number from the first trade, it&rsquo;s going to be challenging to see whether the trade was successful or not.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1572d2102897c3238205a24770fb6cee/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_problems\_Circuit\_breaker\_is\_aimed\_to\_solve\_by\_considering\_an\_example\_dot\_2.svg" style="width: 190px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Usually, a timeout value is peak load performance time multiplied by two: i.e., if a service gives a response in two seconds and three seconds in normal and peak load, respectively, then the time out value should be six seconds. On the surface, this idea seems good. However, later on, while creating a waiting time period of six seconds for each request call to determine whether the service is available does not sound like a good idea. Usually, the end-users click the &ldquo;Submit&rdquo; button within two to three seconds of no response.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/0534f15876173f2e16a6663f4a3d6a97/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_problems\_Circuit\_breaker\_is\_aimed\_to\_solve\_by\_considering\_an\_example\_dot\_3.svg" style="width: 120px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>To solve this anti-pattern, you can use a circuit breaker design pattern, which can improve the stability and resiliency of an application. The general concept of the circuit breaker is pretty simple. A protected function call is wrapped in a circuit breaker object that checks the failures. If the failure achieved a particular threshold, the circuit breaker trips, and all further calls to the circuit breaker return with an error, and no protected call has been made at all. Typically, a monitor alert is needed if a circuit breaker trips.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>A simple circuit breaker can avoid making a protected call when the circuit is open but needs an external intervention to reset it when things are well again. For electrical circuit breakers used in buildings, it is a reasonable approach, but with software circuit breakers, you can have the breaker itself detect if the underlying calls are working again. You can implement this self-resetting behavior by trying the protected call again after a suitable interval and resetting the breaker should it succeed.</p> <p><em>Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.</em></p> <div class="article\_wrapper\_game"> <div class="pieces" id="piece-1" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/b4fcbd9f324128455e5773afc861a34f/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SASM5L8\_1-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-2" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/b00048dabfcaf1b85d8f9d9c5ca5f816/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SASM5L8\_2-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-3" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/578ddd2d31c24d6d24379ee6c1c1229c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SASM5L8\_3-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-4" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/8a88718256d96b8e8890cc652a743586/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SASM5L8\_4-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-5" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/e10c0706317820ccae2f4ab911c7879a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SASM5L8\_5-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-6" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/6577d030ca43eb423f73ca31df7d65f9/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SASM5L8\_6-01.svg');"></div> </div> <div class="image-game-result-container"><button class="play-again-button"> Play again </button> <div class="moves\_amount"></div> </div> <p><span>As you saw in the scheme above, circuit breaker pattern can be implemented as a stateful software component that switches between three states: <b>closed</b> (requests can flow freely), <b>open</b> (requests are rejected without being submitted to the remote resource), and <b>half-open</b> (one probe request is allowed to decide whether to close the circuit again). Now, let&rsquo;s consider one more example.</span></p> <p><span><em>If you want to know more about these states, click <a href="https://medium.com/@soumendrak/circuit-breaker-design-pattern-997c3521c1c4" target="\_blank"><span>here</span></a>.</em></span></p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the dropdown to view an example.</span> </em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Payment service example </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>First, imagine a payment service as a part of a shopping platform. When a client wants to make a payment, the payment service should ensure there&rsquo;s no fraudulent intention. To do that, it asks for a fraud check service.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ab09f25abeb3b90cf1f5aceca35711e9/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_gif5\_\_1\_.gif" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 560px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p>The request from the payment service to the fraud check service is passed through the circuit breaker. After two internal server errors, the circuit opens, and subsequent requests are blocked. After some waiting time, the circuit goes to the half-open state. In this state, it will allow one request to pass and change back to the open state in case it fails or to the closed one in case of success. The next request succeeds, so the circuit is closed again.</p> <p><em>If you want to know more, follow this <a href="https://blog.codecentric.de/en/2019/06/resilience-design-patterns-retry-fallback-timeout-circuit-breaker/" target="\_blank">link</a>.</em></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span>Same as with the other patterns, there are some good use-cases for the circuit breaker pattern. However, in some situations, its usage should be avoided. Let&rsquo;s have a more detailed look at the situations when you should or should not use this pattern.</span></p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em><span> Click on the flip cards to learn when to use or avoid using a circuit breaker.</span> </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/6ef9958bcdaccdba61743ea6b4a993cf/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_Flipcard\_1\_Use\_this\_pattern.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Use this pattern</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>To prevent an application from trying to invoke a remote service or access a shared resource if this operation is highly likely to fail.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/56e11223148730a62dcf143fab19e7dd/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L8\_Flipcard\_2\_This\_pattern\_isn\_t\_recommended.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>This pattern isn&rsquo;t recommended</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>For handling access to local private resources in an application, such as in-memory data structure. In this environment, using a circuit breaker would add overhead to your system.</li> <li>As a substitute for handling exceptions in the business logic of your applications.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- :root { --main-color: #30b6dd; <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-vertical" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="VerticalStudentView" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@08b9dbbe718f40f095332fb0aaa0512b" data-block-type="vertical"> <h2 class="hd hd-2 unit-title">L9: Architectural Patterns. Security Patterns</h2> <div class="bookmark-button-wrapper"> <button class="bookmark-button " aria-pressed="false" data-bookmark-id="volodymyr\_kosmirak\_gmail\_com,block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@08b9dbbe718f40f095332fb0aaa0512b" data-bookmarks-api-url="/api/bookmarks/v1/bookmarks/"> </button> <div class="bookmark-tooltip">Bookmark</div> </div> <script> if ($("#seq\_content").length === 0) { $("#contentframe").context.documentElement.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; $(window).context.body.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; } </script> <div class="vert-mod"> <div class="vert vert-0" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@2cd02397611d4f9ea2fe27532d35619d"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@2cd02397611d4f9ea2fe27532d35619d" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Introduction</h3> <p>This lesson is focused on architectural security patterns, which aim to provide extra layers of security to the application. You will learn the three most common ones and their pros and cons. After completing this lesson, you will be able to determine the pattern that suits your system the best.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@95d8563f734a490d8a8846babc4959dc"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@95d8563f734a490d8a8846babc4959dc" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Federated Identity Pattern</h3> <p>Federated identity security pattern provides a solution to several issues and risks for the system. It is used to delegate authentication responsibility to an external identity provider.</p> <p><em>Click on the video to learn more about this pattern. Alternatively, you may click <a href="/assets/courseware/v1/23634ae48a4a10977c71609e011d0cc6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Lesson\_9.\_ASP\_SM5\_Architectural\_Patterns.\_Security\_Patterns.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a> to download a text script to find out what you will learn.</em></p> <div style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.25%;"><iframe src="https://videoportal.epam.com/video/iframe.html?video=3a1BK5o9&amp;resolution=1920x1080#" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; top: 0; left: 0;"></iframe></div> <p></p> <p></p> <p>Federated identity security is useful when your application needs to provide the <strong>Single Sign-On (SSO)</strong> experience to the users. It can also be used when the applications need to authenticate users with multiple partners; in Software as a Service (SaaS) applications where tenants of the SaaS application can authenticate using a suitable identity provider, etc. Let&rsquo;s take a closer look at the way it works.</p> <p><em>Click on the step-by-step interactivity to discover what problems this pattern aims to solve and how this can be conducted.</em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <p><b>Context/Risk</b></p> <p>The basic requirement from the users&rsquo; side is working with multiple applications that are hosted by the organizations they&rsquo;re dealing with. Disadvantages of using different credentials for multiple applications are:</p> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/846f7173b25fce3fe896d8979faf24c2/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_Step\_Context\_Risk.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 140px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <ul> <li>Disjoint user experience. When users have different credentials for different applications, they can forget which credentials correspond to each application.</li> <li>Security vulnerabilities. If a user leaves a company, his account should be deprovisioned at once. It can be overlooked in large organizations.</li> <li>Complicated user management. Administrators should manage users&rsquo; credentials and provide password reminders.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/e7562d4bdf35ca21d505aeae80a2a81f/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_Step\_Intention.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 140px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Intention</b></p> <ul> <li>Eliminate disjointed user experience</li> <li>Minimize security vulnerabilities</li> <li>Simplify user management</li> </ul> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/d20e2b0fe69d442df419f6b999942bd9/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_Step\_Solution.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 140px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Solution</b></p> <p>Separate user authentication from the application code and delegate authentication to a trusted identity provider.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <style><!-- .step-by-step-text .sbs-arrow-wrapper span { position: absolute; The figure illustrates federated identity pattern when a client application needs to access a service that requires authentication. The authentication is performed by an IdP that works in concert with an STS. The IdP issues security tokens that provide information about the authenticated user. This information, referred to as claims, includes the user&rsquo;s identity and might also include other personal information such as role membership and more granular access rights. For better understanding, let&rsquo;s inspect the diagram below.</p> <p><em>Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme.
