Such scenarios are single sign-on in the enterprise, federated identity with multiple partners, and federated identity in SaaS applications. Let&rsquo;s learn more about how this pattern is applicable in the selected scenarios.</p> <p><em>Click on the tabs to learn more about the good use cases for federal identity pattern. </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">Single sign-on </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Multiple partners </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">SaaS applications </button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7457e836e51e0af86516e2b689f4051b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_Dot1\_Single\_sign-on\_in\_the\_enterprise.svg" style="height: 135px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>In this scenario, you have to authenticate employees for corporate cloud-based applications outside the corporate security boundary. Users are not required to sign in every time they visit an application. User experience is similar to using on-premises applications. Once the user is authenticated, he has access to all relevant applications without signing in again.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/e542912a1fd2a64c45f4f0b08edc5258/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_Dot2\_Federated\_identity\_with\_multiple\_partners.svg" style="height: 135px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>Within federated identity with multiple partners scenario, both corporate employees and business partners who don&rsquo;t have accounts in the corporate directory should be authenticated. It is widely used in business-to-business applications, applications that require integration with third-party services, and the situations where several companies with different IT systems merged or shared resources.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f9ebab80d17959089c71747336cb8cdc/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_Dot3\_Federated\_identity\_in\_SaaS\_applications.svg" style="height: 135px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p>Federated identity in SaaS applications scenario is used when independent software vendors provide a ready-to-use service for multiple clients or tenants. A suitable identity provider is used to authenticate a tenant. For example, business users may apply their corporate credentials, while tenant&rsquo;s consumers and clients may use their social identity credentials.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Alongside the scenarios where the federated identity pattern is applicable, there are numerous situations when its usage is not recommended or even forbidden. In order to build a more comprehensive view, let&rsquo;s take a close look at some of such scenarios.</p> <p><em> Click on the flip cards to learn when this pattern might not be useful. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/86a2643fc05881fff6bb6f46ad3811f0/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_Flipcard\_Scenario\_1.svg" style="height: 110px;" /> <p><strong><br />SCENARIO 1</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p style="padding: 5px;">This pattern is not recommended for use in a situation when one identity provider authenticates application users without any requirement to authenticate using any other identity provider. This scenario is used in business applications with a corporate directory accessible within the application for authentication using a VPN or in a cloud-hosted scenario via a virtual network connection between the on-premises directory and the application.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ec1fe13b573a9cf42e089289b83568d1/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_Flipcard\_Scenario\_2.svg" style="height: 110px;" /> <p><strong><br />SCENARIO 2</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p style="padding: 5px;">This pattern is not recommended for use if the application was developed with a different authentication mechanism that applies custom user stores or has no capability to process the negotiation standards used by claims-based technologies. Using retrofitting claims-based authentication and access control can make the application more complicated and less cost-effective.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.dm2-cardsWrap-about.dm2-cardsWrap-about { margin-bottom: 5px; id=&#34;0c9361a73e0d4c558f2a1a1b10009784-problem-title&#34; aria-describedby=&#34;block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@0c9361a73e0d4c558f2a1a1b10009784-problem-progress&#34; tabindex=&#34;-1&#34;&gt; Test Your Knowledge &lt;/h3&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;problem-progress&#34; id=&#34;block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@0c9361a73e0d4c558f2a1a1b10009784-problem-progress&#34;&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;problem&#34;&gt; &lt;div&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;wrapper-problem-response&#34; tabindex=&#34;-1&#34; aria-label=&#34;Question 1&#34; role=&#34;group&#34;&gt;&lt;p&gt; &lt;em&gt;This is a non-graded quiz. When you have selected an answer, click the &amp;#8220;Submit&amp;#8221; button below. Once your answer is submitted, click &amp;#8220;Show Answer&amp;#8221; to see the correct answer. &lt;/em&gt; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt; &lt;p&gt; Let&amp;#8217;s consider a &lt;b&gt;scenario&lt;/b&gt; in a corporate environment where employees have to use five applications that require authentication to access each one of them. If each individual app needs a user to log in, then there are five usernames and passwords. Imagine a case when an employee is suddenly terminated, and his access from these applications needs to be removed immediately. The operations team needs to individually remove the user from 5 different applications, which is difficult to manage and prone to errors. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt; &lt;p&gt; Can federated identity pattern application resolve this issue, or is it a situation when using this pattern should be avoided?&lt;/p&gt; An organization hosts a multi-tenant software as a service (SaaS) application in Microsoft Azure. The application includes a website that tenants can use to manage the application for their own users. The application allows tenants to access the website by using a federated identity generated by Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS) when a user is authenticated by that organization&rsquo;s own Active Directory.</p> <p><em>Click on the hot spots to receive additional information regarding this example. </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 750px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/dd28b576440185b127cbe14291db9741/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L9\_HotSpots.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-1"> <span class="hotspot-icon" style="font-weight: bold;">1</span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>Tenants authenticate with their own identity provider, in this case, ADFS. After successfully authenticating a tenant, ADFS issues a token.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-2"> } } } else { let current = sbsButtons\[i\]; sbsButtons\[i\].onclick = () => { $(textBlocks\[i + 1\]).slideToggle(500); $(current).toggleClass('step-by-step-button-flip'); } } } } }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-7" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@843be8d8a4ed413c82ea30c0bd666370"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@843be8d8a4ed413c82ea30c0bd666370" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Gatekeeper Pattern Overview</h3> <p>Another security pattern is called the gatekeeper. This pattern provides an extra layer of security to your applications and services hosted in the cloud. Let&rsquo;s learn more about the problems this pattern aims to solve and how it can be achieved.</p> <p><em>Click on the flip cards to explore more.</em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/b6d2133464d5167641cd52fe3064c887/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_Flip\_3001\_Context-Risk.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Context/Risk</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Applications expose their functionality to clients by accepting and processing requests. This code usually also performs authentication and validation. This may introduce a vulnerability.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div style="font-size: 120px; color: #ccc;" class="flip-arrow">&rsaquo;</div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c1019719bba9381b57ccd3f1e4c183aa/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_Flip\_3002\_Intention.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Intention</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Minimize the risk of clients gaining access to sensitive information and services by compromising the application&rsquo;s hosting environment.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div style="font-size: 120px; color: #ccc;" class="flip-arrow">&rsaquo;</div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/e3aac0579da15b34b731f58cfd5b2451/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_Flip\_3003\_Solution.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Solution</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>Decouple hosts or tasks that expose public endpoints from the code that processes requests and accesses storage and introduce controlled validation.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Let&rsquo;s figure out how the described solution can be achieved. You can use a facade or a dedicated task that interacts with clients and then hands off the request&mdash;perhaps through a decoupled interface&mdash;to the hosts or tasks that will handle the request. The diagram below provides a high-level overview of this pattern.<br /><br /></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/e14ff6a3c25d6f435c9504d0f649f882/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Gatekeeper\_\_Diagram.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 900px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <style><!-- @media only screen and (max-width: 686px) { .flip-arrow { display: none; } } --></style> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-8" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@b184b4d194c74f5c91236e97d5e38d63"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@b184b4d194c74f5c91236e97d5e38d63" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Gatekeeper Pattern Factors and Use-cases</span></h3> <p>This pattern can be used to simply protect storage, or it can be used as a more comprehensive facade to protect all application functions. Let&rsquo;s explore the main factors to be considered when implying the gatekeeper.</p> <p><em>Click on the hot spots to learn more about these factors. </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 700px; width: 100%; min-height: 100px;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/3e14a79dda38104101e0ebbf038c2c13/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_HotSpots\_3004\_factors.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-21"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The gatekeeper validates all requests and rejects those that don&rsquo;t meet validation requirements.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-22"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The gatekeeper doesn&rsquo;t have access to the trusted host&rsquo;s credentials or keys to access storage and services. If the gatekeeper is compromised, the attacker doesn&rsquo;t get access to this sensitive information.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-23"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>The gatekeeper runs in a limited privilege mode, while the rest of the application runs in the full trust mode required to access storage and services. If the gatekeeper is compromised, it can&rsquo;t directly access the application services or data.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Let&rsquo;s take a closer look at several <b>scenarios</b> when using gatekeeper pattern can be considered a good choice. This pattern is useful for applications that handle sensitive information, expose services that must have a high degree of protection from malicious attacks, or perform mission-critical operations that shouldn&rsquo;t be disrupted. This pattern is also useful for distributed applications where it&rsquo;s necessary to perform request validation separately from the main tasks or to centralize this validation to simplify maintenance and administration. Now, let&rsquo;s move on to the example.</p> <p><em>Click on the dropdown to overview Cloud-Hosted Scenario.</em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Cloud-Hosted Scenario </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <p>In a cloud-hosted scenario, gatekeeper pattern can be implemented by decoupling the gatekeeper role or virtual machine from the trusted roles and services in the application. Do this by using an internal endpoint, a queue, or storage as an intermediate communication mechanism. The figure below illustrates using an internal endpoint.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/bb147aaf73fcbeeba63fd7d9be26514a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3005\_Schema.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 850px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-21 { left: 13%; top: 0%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-22 { left: 41%; top: 0%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-23 { left: 69%; top: 0%; } --></style> <style><!-- p.dm-pic3-about.dm-pic3-about2 { margin-bottom: 5px; } .container-dm-pic3 { margin-bottom: 25px; } .dm-pic3 img { width: 180px; $(this).next().toggle(); }) }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-9" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@1a402041b7dc421896bf0a45e542e13a"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@1a402041b7dc421896bf0a45e542e13a" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Valet Key Pattern</h3> <p>Valet key is a useful pattern for situations when users of a cloud application need to upload or download files. The idea is to create temporary tokens that give limited access to a single blob in a cloud storage and have the client upload or download directly to/from that cloud store rather than through the application. Let&rsquo;s learn more about the issues this pattern is aimed to solve.</p> <p><em>Click on the step-by-step interactivity to explore more.</em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/df3b98785cf7306e6f5851b94fe8b7f4/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3006\_Steps\_Context-Risk.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Context/Risk</b></p> <p>Client programs and web browsers often need to read and write files or data streams to and from an application&rsquo;s storage. Typically, the application will handle the data&rsquo;s movement either by fetching it from storage and streaming it to the client or by reading the uploaded stream from the client and storing it in the data store. However, this approach absorbs valuable resources, such as compute, memory, and bandwidth.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1dfea5434bb1e5b524b6cb23d53c2c07/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3007\_Steps\_Intention.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 140px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Intention</b></p> <p>Applications must securely control access to data in a granular way but still reduce the load on the server by setting up this connection and then allowing the client to communicate directly with the data store to perform the required read or write operations.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/eee4305d73f72b0a3843f79bb2fce510/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3008\_Steps\_Solution.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 140px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p><b>Solution</b></p> <p>Restrict access to the data store&rsquo;s public connection and provide the client with a key or token that the data store can validate. This will provide time-limited access to specific resources and allow only predefined operations such as reading and writing to storage or uploading and downloading in a web browser.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <p>Applications can create and issue valet keys to client devices and web browsers quickly and easily, allowing clients to perform the required operations without asking the application to directly handle the data transfer. This removes the processing overhead and the impact on performance and scalability from the application and the server. The client uses this token to access a specific resource in the data store for only a specific period and with specific restrictions. After the specified period, the key becomes invalid and won&rsquo;t grant access to the resource.</p> <p>The organizational structure of the valet key secure pattern is represented in the scheme below. It provides a clear understanding of how one component is connected to another.<br /><br /></p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/cc0ad5193303e09dd5d84fbc7b8b83e7/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3009\_Schema2.svg" alt="img" style="display: block; $(current).toggleClass('step-by-step-button-flip'); } } } } }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-10" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@4f12a4efd8d649578e66e55a9c54f504"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@4f12a4efd8d649578e66e55a9c54f504" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Valet Key Pattern Use-Cases</span></h3> <p>Let&rsquo;s move on to the valet key pattern use cases. There are five scenarios when implementing this pattern can be the best option. Let&rsquo;s learn more about each of them and figure out the advantages this pattern provides in dealing with actual challenges.</p> <p><em>Scroll to learn more about the effective usage of the valet key pattern.</em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9b0767b5160715c627901c57c95e4f4c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3010\_Scroll\_1.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 130px; height: 130px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;"><span>The pattern allows to decrease resource loading and improve performance and scalability. When using it, resources shouldn&rsquo;t be locked, and the remote server call is not required. It also allows preventing a single point of failure caused by performing a data transfer through the application code. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/0247757326788b602eb3210cf1135379/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3011\_Scroll\_2.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 130px; height: 130px;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;">Valet key is a good solution for minimizing operational cost. It is resource- and cost-effective to allow direct access to stores and queues. Moreover, it can lead to fewer network roundtrips and may reduce the required number of compute resources.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/076a5f3a474907b015c958cc72f4c6bd/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3012\_Scroll\_3.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 130px; height: 130px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;">It is recommended to use a valet key secure pattern in situations when users regularly upload or download data. In particular, this pattern&rsquo;s usage can be effective if the data amount is large or each operation contains large files.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/15b74f48ce00ab574597963854ccc29f/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3013\_Scroll\_4.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 130px; height: 130px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;">This approach is reasonable to use if an application is limited in compute resources because of hosting limitations or cost considerations. The pattern assists even more if there are many concurrent data uploads or downloads as it allows the application not to process the data transfer.</p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/6648d34ceb94b8feb51887adf4bd9645/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3014\_Scroll\_5.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 130px; height: 130px; object-fit: cover;" /></span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 0;">Use the pattern when the data is stored in a remote data store or a different data center. If the application acts as a gatekeeper, the additional bandwidth of transferring the data between data centers may be required, and then between the application and the data store.</p> </div> </div> </div> <p>In some other cases, usage of the valet key pattern can rather be damaging than helpful. Let&rsquo;s pay extra attention to the detailed description of such examples.</p> <p><em>Click on the dots to learn more about when this pattern should be avoided.</em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ad80c78cb2fe8db9107d5cb78510c48d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3015\_Dots\_1.svg" style="height: 120px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>If the application processes the data before it is stored or sent to the client, e.g., if the application executes validation, logs access success, or performs data transformation. However, clients can perform simple operations like compression and decompression.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9fb866ff15fae0a2edfcf8d5e1c89530/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3016\_Dots\_2.svg" style="height: 120px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Using a valet key pattern should also be avoided if the application&rsquo;s design makes it difficult to incorporate the pattern. Keep in mind that using this pattern typically requires a different architectural approach for delivering and receiving data.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1e7638057b80ae0c50dde93cabc1f552/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3017\_Dots\_3.svg" style="height: 120px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Try not to use this pattern if an application needs to maintain audit trails or control how many times the data transfer operation is performed, and the applied valet key mechanism doesn&rsquo;t support notifications that can be used by the server to manage these operations.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 25%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/3113baf804c248f637a7e9a7486f81af/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA-S5-L9\_3018\_Dots\_4.svg" style="height: 120px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 75%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Don&rsquo;t use the valet key pattern if the size of the data is restricted, mainly when performing upload operations. The only possible solution is to control the data size after the operation is executed or check the uploaded data's size after a specified period or according to the schedule.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- body.view-in-course div.container .course-wrapper { display: table; <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-vertical" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="VerticalStudentView" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@152eac51070e450283e434baff4013a8" data-block-type="vertical"> <h2 class="hd hd-2 unit-title">L10: Zero-downtime release</h2> <div class="bookmark-button-wrapper"> <button class="bookmark-button " aria-pressed="false" data-bookmark-id="volodymyr\_kosmirak\_gmail\_com,block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@vertical+block@152eac51070e450283e434baff4013a8" data-bookmarks-api-url="/api/bookmarks/v1/bookmarks/"> </button> <div class="bookmark-tooltip">Bookmark</div> </div> <script> if ($("#seq\_content").length === 0) { $("#contentframe").context.documentElement.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; $(window).context.body.style.backgroundColor = "#fff"; } </script> <div class="vert-mod"> <div class="vert vert-0" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@c44a4a8f4a9b4c92b37c5e7c2821f9f8"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@c44a4a8f4a9b4c92b37c5e7c2821f9f8" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Introduction</h3> <p>The following lesson will cover the release patterns. You will learn what key steps should be taken before users will be redirected to the new version of the application and what are the main pros and cons of every release pattern described below. You also will get some useful practical tips regarding the implementation of this theoretical knowledge into practice.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <style><!-- .base\_image\_container { width: 100% !important; height: 100% !important; } .base\_image\_container img\[alt="Drop target image"\] { width: 100% !important; } --></style> <style><!-- .course-content{position:relative;} .course-content:before { content:''; pointer-events:none; position:absolute; left:0; right:0; top:0; bottom:0; background-repeat-x: no-repeat; background-position-x: center; background-size: 50%; filter: grayscale(1); opacity:0.15; background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/5f6a97f03592cb8dacd3b4d4877fef87/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/EPAM-MastersDegreeProgram\_White.svg'); } --></style> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-1" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@42592c45b0d448d18a2c89ffc2f5c497"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@42592c45b0d448d18a2c89ffc2f5c497" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Zero-Downtime Release Definition</h3> <p>A zero-downtime release, also known as <b>hot deployment</b>, is when the actual process of <b>switching users</b> from one release to another happens <b>nearly immediately</b>. It is essential to be able to roll back a deployment in case it goes wrong. Blue-green deployments and canary release are advanced techniques to do that. They are efficiently used to perform zero-downtime releases.</p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-2" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@4615718f83d84b87ad96262127dd36b1"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@4615718f83d84b87ad96262127dd36b1" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Blue-Green Deployment: Overview</h3> <p>Blue-green deployment is a powerful technique to manage releases. The idea is to have two identical versions of the production environment called blue and green. Users of the system are routed to the green environment, which is currently a designated production.</p> <p><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/d13ee34f667d4460f43d2e6c21b0d5ea/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Blue-green\_deployment-480p-fe2d1554-0e3f-4283-a5c1-9135e7c57934.gif" alt="img" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 650px; margin: 15px auto;" /></p> <p>In some situations, there can be different pieces of hardware or different virtual machines running on the same (or different) hardware. There can also be a single operating environment partitioned into separate zones with separate IP addresses for these two slices.</p> <p>The release of a new version of an application should be performed by the consecutive execution of the set of determined steps. Let&rsquo;s take a closer look at these steps.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the hot spots to overview these steps. </em></p> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1-wrapper"> <div style="text-align: center;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals1" style="box-shadow: none; max-width: auto;"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-info"></div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-container" style="position: relative; display: flex; justify-content: center;"> <div style="position: relative; max-width: 750px; width: 100%;"><img class="dm-sc-img-modals-image custom-image" src="/assets/courseware/v1/8b9a655a3aa9086256a2c918fc05bc08/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3001\_Hotspots\_consecutive\_execution.svg" alt=" Hot spots image" style="max-width: 100%; width: 100%;" /> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-1"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>Deploy the application to blue environment.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-2"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>Let the application warm up (you can do this as you like).</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-3"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>Run smoke tests against the blue environment to ensure it is working correctly.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-m1 dm-sc-img-modals-wrap"><button class="dm-sc-img-modals-btn hotspot hotspot-4"> <span class="hotspot-icon fa fa-plus"></span> </button> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal"> <div class="dm-sc-img-modals-modal-content"><span class="hotspot-icon dm-sc-img-modals-modal-close fa fa-times"></span> <p>Change the router configuration to point to the blue environment instead of the green environment.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span>Now, let&rsquo;s consider an <b>example</b>. Suppose, you have developed a simple cloud-native app&mdash;a mobile game where users earn points by tapping multicolored balloons that fly across the screen. The game&rsquo;s back end is supported by multiple container-based microservices that handle game achievements, scoring, mechanics, communication, and player identification. Now, let&rsquo;s figure out how blue-green deployment is applicable to this <b>scenario</b>.</span></p> <p style="margin-bottom: 15px;"><em>Click on the step-by-step interactivity to view the example.</em></p> <div class="step-by-step-wrapper"> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1baf270f99bc4b245aca8e9b5c3f5464/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3002\_Step\_1.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 130px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Hundreds of users start playing the game after its initial release. They are logging thousands of transactions every minute. Your DevOps team has encouraged you to release early and often, which is why you&rsquo;re about to release a minor update to the mechanics microservice that increases the size and speed of the red balloon.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/07f17fc2666ca19c3fdf61bda4596a09/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3003\_Step\_2.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 130px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>Instead of waiting until midnight to push the update to the production environment (when the lowest number of users are active), you&rsquo;re using a <b>blue-green deployment model</b> to update the app during peak use time. And you are going to do it with zero downtime.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f853edb7096a61fec975dfcb902afc6e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3004\_Step\_3.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 125px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>You are able to do this because you took the mechanics microservice in the production environment (blue) and copied it to an identical&mdash;but separate&mdash;container (green). After you increased the red balloons&rsquo; size and speed in the green environment, it passed through Q/A and staging (which were perhaps automated by an open-source stress test project like Jenkins) before it was pushed to the production environment alongside the active blue environment.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> <div class="step-by-step-text"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9a5d103af622714e8b2d235cba86dc52/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3005\_Step\_4.svg" alt="Title" style="width: 75%; max-width: 120px;" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <p>The ops team can use a load balancer to redirect each user&rsquo;s next transaction from blue to green, and&mdash;once all production traffic is filtered through the green environment&mdash;the blue environment is brought offline. Blue can either stand by as a disaster recovery option or become the container for the next update.</p> </div> </div> <button class="step-by-step-button sbs-arrow-wrapper"> <span></span><span></span><span></span> </button></div> </div> <style><!-- .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-1 { left: 12%; top: 86.7%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-2 { left: 36%; top: 86.7%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-3 { left: 73.5%; top: 86.7%; } .dm-sc-img-modals-btn.hotspot-4 { left: 97.5%; top: 86.7%; } --></style> <style><!-- .step-by-step-text .sbs-arrow-wrapper span { position: absolute; } }); }); }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-3" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@57a7d56b3bcb4459bcc6c577fc0ea2d1"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@57a7d56b3bcb4459bcc6c577fc0ea2d1" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Blue-green Deployment Advantages and Hints</h3> <p>Now, let&rsquo;s pay attention to the advantages of the blue-green deployment, which include minimum downtime and rapid way to rollback, as well as tips for using this pattern.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the flip cards to explore the advantages and hints of using blue-green deployment. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/0eebd26589bb5ac35e4bf4e64f93d0c6/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3006\_Flip\_Advantages.svg" style="height: 135px; padding-bottom: 8px; padding-top: 16px;" /> <p><strong>Advantages</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li><b>Minimum Downtime</b> - switchover takes less than a second to be completed.</li> <li><b>Rapid Way to Rollback</b> - once something went wrong, you can switch the router back to the green environment and use blue environment to debug what went wrong.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/733f696542ea581b000ef683fae03d0d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3007\_Flip\_Hints.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Hints</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <ul> <li>Switch the application into read-only mode just before the switchover.</li> <li>Transactions should be fed to both the new and old databases from the latest version of the application.</li> <li>The application should be designed in a way to let the database migrate independently from the upgrade process.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span>Besides the hints provided above, there are several best practices for the implementation of Blue-green deployment suggested by the community. Their main concerns include choosing load balancing over DNS switching, rolling update execution, monitoring environment with correct alerts, automation, and making the code forward and backward compatible. Let&rsquo;s learn more about each of them.</span></p> <p><span><em>Click on the dots to examine best practices.</em></span></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/e1fba6eff1f113801cad0f9afdf61d17/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3008\_Dots\_1.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Choose Load Balancing Over DNS Switching</h3> <p>When switching between environments, you need to make your domain to eventually point to different servers. Don&rsquo;t go to the DNS records. Instead, use load balancing. Load balancers enable you to set your new servers immediately, without having to depend on the DNS mechanism. The DNS record will always point to the Load Balancer, and you only change the servers behind it. This way you can be absolutely sure that all traffic comes to the new production environment instead of the old one.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/981b190761b27c63dbec4d42d8f4db2a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3009\_Dots\_2.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Execute a Rolling Update</h3> <p>Switching all your servers from an old version to a new one at once may result in downtime. To avoid that, you can execute a &ldquo;rolling update&rdquo;. This means that instead of switching from all Blue servers to all Green servers in a single cut-off, you can work with an integrated environment. Add one new server, retire one old server, and repeat this until all the new servers are inside. One thing to make sure of, though, is that your new code can run alongside your old code because they will be running together side-by-side.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9c71801f9aa0d0c29f8f05503de83932/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3010\_Dots\_3.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Monitor Your Environments with the Correct Alerts</h3> <p>The need to monitor production is obvious but monitoring the non-production environment is also essential. However, non-production monitoring is less critical. Since the same environment can play both as production and non-production, you will need an easy way to toggle the alerting between the two states. This can be achieved by using a different API token for production/non-production reporting to your APM solution or by programmatically changing the alert policy on the APM of the environment when its role changes.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/80f2ad548eb8ed9d2891ac4c7cd9e04b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3011\_Dots\_4.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Automate</h3> <p>You should script as many actions as possible in the switching process instead of doing a manual set of actions. There are some benefits to such an approach. First, the switch will happen faster if its steps are automated. Second, nothing needs to be remembered. Also, it is safer as manual work is more error-prone. What is more, this approach enables self-service: having a switch button running an automated script enables everyone with the right permissions to do it without being dependent on someone that knows the exact steps needed.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7d4602a1993f15c1c47509112a492d77/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3012\_Dots\_5.svg" style="width: 140px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Make Your Code Backward and Forward Compatible</h3> <p>The new and old versions will run side-by-side during the switch process, so make sure both versions can co-exist. To avoid downtime, break the update into a few &ldquo;mini-updates&rdquo;. <b>For example</b>, you&rsquo;re changing a field name from &ldquo;user\_name&rdquo; to &ldquo;username&rdquo;. Release an intermediate version of the code that works with both &ldquo;user\_name&rdquo; and &ldquo;username&rdquo;. Rename the field to &ldquo;username&rdquo; across all records in the database. Release the final code version, supporting &ldquo;username&rdquo;, and remove the old code supporting &ldquo;user\_name&rdquo; completely.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.dm2-cardsWrap-about.dm2-cardsWrap-about { margin-bottom: 5px; align-items: center; margin-bottom: 25px;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/d0bd8a533b6c77d3fc2328f07091974e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3013\_Canary.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 140px; max-width: 30%; flex-grow: 0; flex-shrink: 0;" /> <div style="padding-left: 20px;"> <p>It is usually a safe assumption that you only have one version of your software in production at a time. If you have an extremely large production environment, it&rsquo;s impossible to create a meaningful capacity testing environment (unless your application&rsquo;s architecture employs end-to-end sharing). How do you ensure a new version of your application won&rsquo;t perform poorly?</p> </div> </div> <p>You start by deploying the new version of your software to a subset of your infrastructure, to which no users are routed. When you are happy with the new version, you can start routing a few selected users to it.</p> <p><em>Swipe the illustration to the left to see deployed new version with no routed users and to the right to see the illustration for routing new users.</em></p> <div class="swipe-m-wrapper"> <div class="swipe-m-container"> <div class="swipe-m-inner" style="width: 100%; max-width: 760px;"> <div class="comparison-m-wrapper"> <div class="comparison-m-swipe"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/f9e7773d2c9632fda4dd1dd6a48791f7/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3014\_Swipe\_Left.svg" alt="img2" style="background-color: #fff;" /> <div class="resize-m-swipe"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/1d4388299fa6fbc8c3903b52668d49be/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_3015\_Swipe\_Right.svg" alt="img1" style="background-color: #fff;" /></div> <div class="divider-m-swipe"> <div class="img-comp-slider"></div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>There are different strategies on how to choose which users will see the new version. Let's pay a special attention to the ways of users routing and the scenarios they can be used in.</p> <p><em><span style="font-size: 1em;">Click on the video to overview these strategies</span><span style="font-size: 1em;">. Alternatively, you may click </span></em><em><a style="text-decoration: underline;" href="/assets/courseware/v1/5a729d65f6213c9dd84a273b196cc5ea/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/Lesson\_10.\_ASP\_SM5\_Architectural\_Patterns.\_Release\_Patterns.pdf" target="\_blank">here</a></em><em style="font-size: 1em;"><span style="font-size: 1em;">to download a text script to find out what you will learn.</span></em></p> <div style="position: relative; width: 100%; padding-top: 56.25%;"><iframe src="//videoportal.epam.com/video/iframe.html?video=boMDVyaV&amp;resolution=1920x1080#" allowfullscreen="" style="position: absolute; width: 100%; height: 100%; top: 0; left: 0;" frameborder="0"></iframe></div> <p></p> <p></p> <p></p> <p>When all the users have been routed to the new version, the migrate phase is over. At this point, the old infrastructure can be decompiled. Let&rsquo;s figure out how it can be visualized.</p> <p><em>Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.</em></p> <div class="article\_wrapper\_game"> <div class="pieces" id="piece-1" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/0fdce3a411104190b88874d552685bf3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Puzzle1-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-2" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/4e78aa05ac038ca422276a20cd11a178/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Puzzle2-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-3" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/9633765a6d2083abd0deda2e3f1963e3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Puzzle3-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-4" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/b607695bc014915b2ffd1add9ec10747/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Puzzle4-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-5" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/22129afbbcdbe5f976c159ab3272939a/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Puzzle5-01.svg');"></div> <div class="pieces" id="piece-6" style="background-image: url('/assets/courseware/v1/705bb6192b0bbaa0b86db95ec900d287/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Puzzle6-01.svg');"></div> </div> <div class="image-game-result-container"><button class="play-again-button"> Play again </button> <div class="moves\_amount"></div> </div> <p>Now, let&rsquo;s pay attention to some real-life examples of using canary releases.</p> <style><!-- .article\_wrapper\_game { width: calc(var(--game-pieces-width) \* 3); align-items: center; margin-bottom: 25px;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7017a8dda011d1da6b8bad5338fdfe29/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/facebook-4.svg" alt="some image" style="width: 90px; max-width: 30%; flex-grow: 0; flex-shrink: 0;" /> <div style="padding-left: 40px;"> <p><b>For example</b>, if you have geographically distributed users, you can roll out the new version to a region or a specific location first. If you have multiple brands, you can roll out to a single brand first, etc. Facebook chooses to use a strategy with various canaries, the first one being visible only to their internal employees and having all the Feature Toggles (will be explained further in the lesson) turned on so they can detect problems with new features early.</p> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-6" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@drag-and-drop-v2+block@29632f01138d4517a62a460229faa180"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-drag-and-drop-v2" data-graded="True" data-has-score="True" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="DragAndDropBlock" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@drag-and-drop-v2+block@29632f01138d4517a62a460229faa180" data-block-type="drag-and-drop-v2"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"show\_problem\_header": false, "url\_name": "29632f01138d4517a62a460229faa180", "is\_drag\_disabled": false, "graded": true, "title": "Test Your Knowledge", "display\_zone\_labels": false, "weighted\_max\_score": 0.0, "max\_items\_per\_zone": null, "problem\_text": "\\u003cp\\u003e\\u003cem\\u003eThis is a non-graded quiz. data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Netflix Example</span></h3> <p>In partnership with Google, Netflix has open-sourced Kayenta, a platform for Automated Canary Analysis (ACA). Kayenta leverages lessons learned over the years of delivering rapid and reliable changes into production at Netflix. It is a crucial component of delivery at Netflix as it reduces the risk of making changes in the production environment.</p> <p>Netflix augments the canary release process and uses three clusters, all serving the same traffic with different amounts. Let&rsquo;s pay more attention to these clusters.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the flip cards to figure out which clusters are used. </em></p> <div class="dm2-cardsWrap"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/ca5bf8ef587edf24069dc1e4d4eac17d/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Flip\_card\_1\_Production\_cluster.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Production Cluster</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>The production cluster is unchanged and is the version of the software that is currently running. This cluster may run any number of instances.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/b68ef8b8ef65156f73310597fe745159/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Flip\_card\_2\_Baseline\_cluster.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Baseline Cluster</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>The baseline cluster runs the same version of code and configuration as the production cluster. Typically, three instances are created.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer dm2-cardContainer-inactive"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-front" style="background-color: #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/05fae496bb9a7bc15b1232a0f4c167cc/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Flip\_card\_3\_Canary\_cluster.svg" style="height: 140px;" /> <p><strong>Canary Cluster</strong></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-side dm2-cardContainer-card-back" style="border: 1px solid #60bfd6;"> <div class="dm2-cardContainer-card-info"> <p>The canary cluster runs the proposed changes of code or configuration. As in the baseline cluster, three instances are typical.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>The production cluster receives the majority of traffic, while the baseline and canary each receive a small amount. How this delineation of traffic routing occurs depends on the type of traffic, but a typical configuration leverages a load balancer to add the baseline and canary instances into the regular pool of existing cases. There are two platforms involved in this process in Netflix.</p> <p style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the tabs to learn more about these platforms. </em></p> <div class="tab-wrapper"> <div class="tab-controls"><button class="tab-controls\_\_button active">Spinnaker </button> <button class="tab-controls\_\_button">Kayenta </button></div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/4037d190219f90d58c8371415bbe20eb/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_tabs\_Spinnaker.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 170px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p><em>Spinnaker</em> &mdash; a continuous delivery platform&mdash;handles the lifecycle of the baseline and canary clusters. It runs one or more iterations of the canary analysis step and decides to continue, rollback, or prompt manual intervention to proceed. If the new version is determined to be safe, the deployment is allowed to continue, and the production change is fully rolled out into a new cluster. If not, Spinnaker aborts the canary process, and all traffic will be routed to the production cluster.</p> </div> </div> </div> <div class="tab-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/d5d58baf518157927b6cff361cfe36e2/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_tabs\_Kayenta.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 170px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <p><em>Kayenta</em> is the next-generation automated canary analysis platform and is tightly integrated with Spinnaker. The Kayenta platform is responsible for assessing the risk of a canary release and checks for significant degradation between the baseline and canary. This process comprises two primary stages: metric retrieval (at this step, the key metrics are retrieved from the baseline and canary clusters) and judgment (at this stage, the metrics collected from the baseline and canary).</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><em> Refer <a href="https://netflixtechblog.com/automated-canary-analysis-at-netflix-with-kayenta-3260bc7acc69" target="\_blank">here</a> to learn more about how Netflix uses canary releases. </em></p> <style><!-- p.tab-wrapper-about.tab-wrapper-about-2 { margin-bottom: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;"><em> Click on the dropdowns to learn more about the benefits and hints of the canary releases. </em></p> <div class="container-dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-pic3"> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Benefits </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/c0badf91afb0fd54b24085436b10ba42/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_dropdown\_Benefits.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <ul> <li>It makes rolling back easy: just stop routing users to the bad version, and you can investigate the problem.</li> <li>You can use it for A/B testing by routing some users to the new version and others to the old version.</li> <li>You can check if the application meets capacity requirements by gradually ramping up the load, slowly routing more and more users to the application, and measuring the application&rsquo;s response time and metrics like CPU usage, I/O, and memory usage.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <div class="dm-sc-collaps-wrapper"> <div class="dm-collaps-wrap"><button class="dm-collaps"> <i class="fa fa-angle-down" aria-hidden="true"></i> Hints </button> <div class="dm-collaps-content"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 30%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/82c62277f901fe51a436b4b704ae42c3/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_dropdown\_Hints.svg" style="width: 75%; max-width: 150px;" alt="image" /></div> <div style="width: 70%; align-self: center;"> <ul> <li>It is hard to utilize it if the users have your software installed on their own computers or mobile devices.</li> <li>Any shared resource needs to work with all versions of the application you want to have in production.</li> <li>Supporting multiple versions is painful, so keep the number of canaries to a minimum.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- p.dm-pic3-about.dm-pic3-about2 { margin-bottom: 5px;
