}) }) // \]\]></script> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-9" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@413b772373694d739ffa03ba2c3e08e9"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@413b772373694d739ffa03ba2c3e08e9" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3><span>Canary Release: Good and Bad Use-cases</span></h3> <p>Although canary releases have a variety of advantages (which were already examined above), there are some situations when you should not use this pattern. In order to avoid mistakes, let&rsquo;s explore the good and bad use-cases for canary releases.</p> <p><em>Click on the dots to learn more about when to use and avoid canary releases.</em></p> <div class="slider-linear-wrapper"> <ul class="progress-bar"> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot active"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_connector"></li> <li class="progress-bar\_\_dot"></li> </ul> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/0eb7b91c700e63814ba577220b91c9b4/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_dots\_1\_Use\_canary\_releases.svg" style="width: 165px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Use canary releases</h3> <ul> <li>An application consists of multiple (micro)services that are changing at independent rates, and the verification of functionality must be conducted in a realistic (ideally, production) environment.</li> <li>There is a high operational risk of deploying new functionality, which can be mitigated by experimenting with directing a small percentage of traffic to the new deployment.</li> <li>A service depends on an upstream system that cannot effectively be tested against. The only reliable method to validate a successful integration is to integrate with this service.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> <div class="step"> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/fd14fa811c09e3383c529fa6564e2662/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_dots\_2\_Do\_not\_use\_canary\_releases.svg" style="width: 165px;" alt="IMG" /></div> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-left: 20px;"> <h3>Do not use canary releases</h3> <ul> <li>You are working on a mission, safety, or life-critical system that cannot tolerate failure. No one wants to see the canary release of a nuclear meltdown safety mechanism.</li> <li>End users will be overly sensitive to canary results. For example, extra care would be required if using canary release for the software that manipulates large amounts of financial transactions.</li> <li>The experiment would require the modification of back-end data (or the data store schema) in a way that is not compatible with the current service requirements.</li> </ul> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-10" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@187ed4c5a660417c84d3240db578e508"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@187ed4c5a660417c84d3240db578e508" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <div style="display: flex;"> <div style="width: 80%; align-self: center; padding-right: 20px;"> <h3><span>Feature Flags Releases Description and Use-cases</span></h3> <p>Finally, let&rsquo;s briefly overview feature flags. Feature flags (also known as feature toggles or feature switches) are a software development technique that turns certain functionality on and off during runtime without deploying new code. This allows better control and more experimentation over the full lifecycle of features. The idea behind feature flags is to build conditional feature branches into code in order to make logic available only to specific groups of users at a time. If the flag is &ldquo;on&rdquo;, new code is executed. If the flag is &ldquo;off&rdquo;, the code is skipped.</p> </div> <div style="width: 20%; align-self: center; text-align: center;"><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/5b3bac46378747549413597a30f1ea2b/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_Feature\_Flags\_Releases\_Description\_and\_Use-cases.svg" alt="some image" width="170" /></div> </div> <p>A feature flag release varies from a canary release, as feature flags are used to expose a specific feature to a small subgroup of users. A canary release exposes a particular version of the entire application or service. There are many benefits to incorporating feature toggles into your release process. The following are some common use cases.</p> <p><em>Scroll to discover feature flags use-cases.</em></p> <div class="dm-slideshow-container" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll;"> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Testing in Production </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/64382fabb2ca586562cf1bf61d5e3798/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_scroll\_Testing\_in\_Production.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 140px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-bottom: 0;"><span> <br />Feature flags allow development teams to test new features in production while mitigating the risk of a poor release by providing a way to quickly roll back the feature via a kill switch if necessary. They allow validating the functionality of new feature releases in the real world while minimizing the risk and encourage trunk-based development, which helps prevent merge conflicts from divergent code paths. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong> Quicker Release Cycles </strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/9169dc01613ff6c388aa915746180d10/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_scroll\_Quicker\_Release\_Cycles.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-bottom: 0;"><span> <br />Using feature flags, a team can modify a system&rsquo;s behavior without making disruptive code changes to the live code. Thus, one of the feature flags&rsquo; important benefits is the simplicity of their deployment in the development process. Feature flags decouple feature lifecycle management from code deployment, freeing up the engineering team to work on other tasks. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides dm-fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Rollback / Kill Switch </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/04ef3c1e69d7bad246e573cd16c1a16e/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_scroll\_Rollback\_\_Kill\_Switch.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-bottom: 0;"><span> <br />Using feature flags significantly simplifies enabling or disabling new features. If a bug is discovered in a new feature, it can be rolled back instantly without changing your source code. This is useful for <b>mobile app developers</b>, who can use feature flags to release or roll back new features without going through the lengthy app store review process. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Server-Side A/B Testing </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/be13334dc83e67ace06c60aefa34f9ab/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_scroll\_Server\_Side\_A\_B\_Testing.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-bottom: 0;"><span> <br />Developers can implement A/B tests using feature flags by enabling a feature for half of the segment of users, and disabling the feature for the other half, and seeing how the two perform against each other for a certain metric. Feature flags allow to A/B test various features within products with no need for code deployment. Google, Facebook, Amazon, and Netflix A/B test new features before deploying to their full user base. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Feature Gating </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/7d88b19bfcb1816235489716fa2bce7c/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_scroll\_Feature\_Gating.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-bottom: 0;"><span> <br />Feature flags can be used to implement targeted rollouts of features to a specific subset of your users. This can be great for A/B testing features for specific segments of your audience. Still, it can also be used to release features to only a subset of your users, <b>for example</b>, granting users in your enterprise tier access to features that aren&rsquo;t available in lower tiers. </span></p> </div> </div> <div class="dm-mySlides fade"> <p style="margin-top: 0;"><strong><span> Continuous Deployment </span></strong></p> <div class="dm-mySlides-wrapper"> <p style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100px;"><span><img src="/assets/courseware/v1/cc7ac0fedb81b94ca6c547209e7cca90/asset-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@asset+block/SA\_S5\_L10\_scroll\_Continuous\_Deployment.svg" style="display: block; margin: auto; width: 150px;" /></span></p> <p style="font-size: 15px; margin-bottom: 0;"><span> <br />Feature flags have the ability to allow quick learning. Feature flagging enables companies to continuously deliver and deploy software to their users in a faster way. The use of feature flags allows companies to perform gradual feature rollouts, fix bugs in the code without redeploying, experience a more streamlined development cycle, and do rollbacks of code more easily. </span></p> </div> </div> </div> <style><!-- body.view-in-course div.container .course-wrapper { display: table; } .dm-mySlides { min-width: 380px; border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px; padding: 10px; text-align: center; } .dm-mySlides p { text-align: center; } --></style> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-11" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@0fec4d3a51454e7eba10ff6c5c55f579"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@0fec4d3a51454e7eba10ff6c5c55f579" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Lesson Summary</h3> <p>In the completed lesson, you familiarized yourself with release patterns. In particular, you got acquainted with the description of zero-downtime release, paid attention to blue-green deployment, analyzed its benefits, and were provided with some best practices of how it could be implemented. What is more, you overviewed canary releases and discovered which real-world companies use them. Finally, you were introduced to feature flags releases and explored their main use-cases.</p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-12" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@479dcd9aa88b4f5abc49cd6363b8fce7"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-html xmodule\_display xmodule\_HtmlModule" data-mark-completed-on-view-after-delay="500" data-graded="True" data-has-score="False" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="html" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@html+block@479dcd9aa88b4f5abc49cd6363b8fce7" data-type="HTMLModule" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "HTMLModule"} </script> <h3>Quiz</h3> <p><em> These questions are designed to check your understanding of the key concepts of the lesson. This is a graded quiz. The result of this quiz is going to be included into your cumulative score for Solution Architecture module. <b>Remember</b> that to complete the course successfully you need to have cumulatively at least 70% of correct answers. You have two attempts to do the quiz, so please answer carefully! </em></p> <p></p> <p></p> </div> </div> <div class="vert vert-13" data-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b"> <div class="xblock xblock-student\_view xblock-student\_view-problem xmodule\_display xmodule\_CapaModule" data-graded="True" data-has-score="True" data-runtime-class="LmsRuntime" data-init="XBlockToXModuleShim" data-block-type="problem" data-request-token="3d3be5f685d711ec8d58001dd8b723ea" data-runtime-version="1" data-usage-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b" data-type="Problem" data-course-id="course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021"> <script type="json/xblock-args" class="xblock-json-init-args"> {"xmodule-type": "Problem"} </script> <div id="problem\_a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b" class="problems-wrapper" role="group" aria-labelledby="a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b-problem-title" data-problem-id="block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b" data-url="/courses/course-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021/xblock/block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b/handler/xmodule\_handler" data-problem-score="0.0" data-problem-total-possible="5.0" data-attempts-used="0" data-content=" &lt;h3 class=&#34;hd hd-3 problem-header&#34; id=&#34;a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b-problem-title&#34; aria-describedby=&#34;block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b-problem-progress&#34; tabindex=&#34;-1&#34;&gt; &lt;/h3&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;problem-progress&#34; id=&#34;block-v1:MSDP+SA1.0+2021+type@problem+block@a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b-problem-progress&#34;&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;problem&#34;&gt; &lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;1. Select the statements that are NOT true.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;wrapper-problem-response&#34; tabindex=&#34;-1&#34; aria-label=&#34;Question 1&#34; role=&#34;group&#34;&gt;&lt;div class=&#34;choicegroup capa\_inputtype&#34; id=&#34;inputtype\_a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b\_2\_1&#34;&gt; &lt;fieldset aria-describedby=&#34;status\_a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b\_2\_1&#34;&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;field&#34;&gt; &lt;label id=&#34;a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b\_2\_1-choice\_0-label&#34; id=&#34;input\_a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b\_2\_1\_choice\_0&#34; class=&#34;field-input input-checkbox&#34; value=&#34;choice\_0&#34;/&gt; &lt;span/&gt; Blue-Green deployment requires an additional production-identical environment. &lt;/label&gt; value=&#34;choice\_1&#34;/&gt; &lt;span/&gt; An application consists of multiple (micro)services that are changing at independent rates, and verification of functionality must be conducted in a realistic (ideally production) environment. &lt;/label&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div class=&#34;field&#34;&gt; &lt;label id=&#34;a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b\_6\_1-choice\_2-label&#34; class=&#34;response-label field-label label-inline&#34; aria-describedby=&#34;status\_a96ae010f1344dfd8e171147691b7e6b\_6\_1&#34;&gt; value=&#34;choice\_2&#34;/&gt; &lt;span/&gt; The experiment would require the modification of back-end data (or the data store schema) in a way that is not compatible with the current service requirements. &lt;/label&gt;
